One of them, former Justice Minister Orton Chirwa, and his wife, Vera, are currently under sentence of death here, having been lured back into the country two years ago and charged with treason under a legal system framed by Mr. Chirwa himself. The former minister led one of several largely ineffective exiled Malawian opposition groups. Another exile, Atati Mpakati, was assassinated in Zimbabwe last March. Three Government ministers and one member of Parliament died last month in a mysterious car accident that many people believe was a political killing. Over the years, several thousand people have been imprisoned for political offenses. The number of such detainees now is put by foreigners at 40 to 50. Big Foreign Debt Incurred In recent years, Malawi has run up a crushing foreign debt of $750 million, forcing it to spend 43 percent of its export earnings from tobacco, sugar and tea on repayments. Both the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund are expected to provide loans to help ease the problem, but only in return for domestic changes. There is expected to be pressure, Western economists said, for reorganization of Press Holdings, the country's biggest private company. President Banda holds 90 percent of the company stock, the economists said, supposedly in trust for the nation but used sometimes to finance personal projects. A traveler, for instance, might, while driving on a long and rutted dirt track in the bush, suddenly come upon a village equipped with running water and tarred roads and neat brick bungalows and electricity. Other villages lack these amenities - indeed, are dirt poor - but then, they are not the birthplace of a close relative of the President.

COUNTRY: KENYA (99%); SOMALIA (95%); EASTERN AFRICA (79%);
TEXT: President Daniel arap Moi was inaugurated today for a second full term and put in office a Cabinet that reflects Kenya's present economic pressures as well as the political change the country is undergoing. The new Cabinet, the first personally selected by Moi, also follows tradition by spreading ministerial appointments geographically to appease the country's many ethnic groups and tribes. Moi, reelected last month, a little more than a year after an unsuccessful military coup, has emerged as a stronger leader of this East African country and finally shed the grip of the once powerful supporters of the late Jomo Kenyatta, Kenya's founding father. Two breaks with tradition were Moi's appointment of an apolitical university mathematics professor to head the Finance Ministry and the first Cabinet-level appointment of a Kenyan Somali, from the country's once turbulent northeast border region adjoining Somalia. The once dominant influence of Kenyatta's Kikuyu people continues to wane since his death and the Kikuyus control only four ministries in the new Cabinet, half the number they controlled in the past. The Kikuyus are Kenya's largest ethnic group, making up 20 percent of the country's 17.8 million people. A major change is the absence from the political scene of Charles Njonjo, the powerful attorney general for 17 years under Kenyatta and then member of Parliament and minister under Moi. Njonjo continued as a powerful figure after Kenyatta's death in 1978 with Moi's blessing but was reportedly caught by Moi earlier this year in a political takeover bid. He was dropped from the Cabinet then and has faded into obscurity. A newly elected member of Parliament, Hussein Maalam Mohamed, 34, has been appointed by Moi as minister of state in the president's office. He is the first Kenyan Somali to be given a Cabinet-level post. Mohamed is the younger brother of Lt. Gen. Mahmoud Mohamed, an Army leader and Moi loyalist who crushed the coup attempt last year by dissident Air Force officers. Because of Somalia's claims on parts of northeast Kenya, which is inhabited by ethnic Somalis, and insurgent attacks against Kenyan forces in the region in past years, Kenyan Somalis have been looked upon by the government as harboring divided loyalties. "Somalis have been treated as second-class citizens here," said one Kenyan political observer, adding that the Mohamed brothers' prominent roles may end "this practice and the Somalis' feeling of isolation." Moi's administration still faces a recession-hit economy with problems exacerbated by unsettling levels of corruption. Economic grievances and charges of official corruption were some of the complaints of those who led the coup attempt. After three years of steady economic decline, Kenya has begun to experience a slight upturn this year but the country's economic difficulties are far from ended. Thus Moi's choice of George Saitoti, a University of Nairobi mathematics professor, as finance minister is seen here as "a new seriousness on the part of this government of getting Kenya's financial house in order," said an economic analyst who asked not to be identified. In a belt-tightening speech following his swearing-in this afternoon, Moi, 59, touched on several of the most worrying aspects of Kenya's economy, including a high external debt of $2.9 billion, rising unemployment which is now over 30 percent, the severe economic drain on government resources of 147 government agencies, many of them criticized as being mismanaged, and Kenya's 4 percent annual population growth rate, one of the highest in the world. There will soon be an end to overseas borrowing for development projects, Moi said, and more reliance put on the efficient use of domestic resources. "I will not pretend that this will be easy to do," he said, but the government "will help where we can. We cannot afford to borrow more than we can repay." Kenya was badly hurt beginning in 1979 by the world drop in prices for tea and coffee exports, which provide 40 percent of the country's earnings. Government spending above agreed-upon ceilings led to the suspension in January 1982 of an International Monetary Fund financial aid package. Economic growth--more than 6 percent annually in the 1960s and 1970s--fell to 2.7 percent in 1981 and to 2 percent by 1982. The Kenyan government estimates that the coup attempt resulted in foreign exchange losses of $73 million from reduced tourist revenues (normally 10 percent of foreign exchange earnings), imports of equipment replacements and the transfer of capital out of the country. With increases in tea and coffee prices this year, Kenya's foreign exchange situation has gone from "desperate"--with money on hand to finance less than one month's imports--to a better than two-month level. The country is expected to earn $900 million this year, about $6 million more than last year, and the economic growth rate has climbed to 2.6 percent. Importantly, the IMF signed a new $170 million aid package with Kenya last March after it was able to produce an austerity budget of $1.48 billion. A $60 million budget deficit is made up in part with aid donations from western countries and IMF assistance. "The Kenyans have made some deep cuts in their domestic spending that are good for now but will probably have a negative impact on their economic growth in the long run," said one economist. "They'll need some good luck and continued tight fiscal management for a good while to come," he said.

COUNTRY: NIGERIA (96%); AFRICA (94%); UNITED STATES (79%); WESTERN AFRICA (79%);
TEXT: The abrupt overthrow of Nigeria's fledgling civilian government yesterday ended one of the most important political milestones in black Africa in recent years. The coup sponsored by elements of the country's armed forces--and the reported arrests of the country's civilian politicians, including President Shehu Shagari--extinguished, for the moment at least, a 4 1/2-year-old multiparty democratic government rare in Africa and the Third World. Oil-rich Nigeria--the most populous and wealthiest of black African nations--had been held up as a showcase of political reform in 1979 when it returned to civilian government after 13 years of military rule. Shagari, elected that year, was reelected by a wide margin last August. With a new constitution based on the U.S. model, it was felt that Nigeria's bold experiment with democracy could influence other West African countries to loosen the reins of their one-party states and military dictatorships, the prevalent form of government in Africa. But Nigeria's severe economic problems, brought on by the recent worldwide oil glut, and its tolerance for widespread corruption were soon to mar the nation's model reputation. Those two trends laid the groundwork for yesterday's coup. As world oil demand dropped in recent years, Nigeria's already badly managed economy plunged into chaos. Almost overnight, Shagari's administration, halfway through its first term, had to forsake the promise of abundance for a policy of economic restraint. Food prices soared; unemployment rose. Shagari imposed an import ban that forced many industries to operate at 25 percent of capacity or less. On Thursday, Shagari presented his latest austerity budget to parliament, calling on Nigerians to make further sacrifices as his government struggled to make up a growing deficit and meet the conditions for a badly needed $2.5 billion loan from the International Monetary Fund. It was a far cry from the first two heady years of Nigeria's civilian government, when oil export revenues quadrupled to an unprecedented high of $24 billion. Shagari then embarked on an ambitious rural development program, committing billions of dollars to the agrarian communities where more than 75 percent of the country's approximately 100 million people live. Billions more were earmarked for the new capital, Abuja, as well as for heavy industries and badly needed roads, telecommunications and inexpensive housing. Amid all of the plenty, however, a venal circle of politicians, some of them close to Shagari, began to embezzle funds on a pervasive scale. Critics of the government were practically unanimous in characterizing Shagari as an honest politician, but in the same breath they called him weak for allowing his cronies to raid government coffers unpunished. By the time of the coup, corruption at every level of government had become expected practice. Even with the unprecedented wealth, Shagari's government was unsuccessful in passing it down to the urban and rural poor, who make up the overwhelming majority of the nation's almost 100 million population. A small elite, by comparison, grew increasingly rich. The growing tensions were made more ominous by the country's history of domestic upheaval. Six years after independence from Britain in 1960, Nigeria had its first in a series of bloody military coups. At that time, the Army moved against a civilian government that was widely seen as corrupt and whose blatant rigging of elections had sparked rioting and near anarchy in the country's western region. The first coup led to a military countercoup in mid-1966, followed by a tragic 2 1/2-year civil war, a third coup, a bloody coup attempt and, finally, the voluntary handover of power by the Army to an elected government in 1979. The 1979 elections were tightly supervised by the Army and were widely accepted in Nigeria as free and fair. The second set of elections, held last summer, was supervised by Shagari's civilian government and was widely criticized as being unfairly rigged to favor his party. In their initial proclamation after yesterday's coup, the Nigerian Army officers said they overthrew Shagari's second administration because it was "inept and corrupt." Charges of corruption have become obligatory post-coup allegations, but in Nigeria large numbers of the population will be only too ready to believe the charges.

COUNTRY: NIGERIA (94%); AFRICA (93%); UNITED KINGDOM (79%);
TEXT: The leaders of Nigeria's new military government, unveiling their plans for Africa's troubled giant, are stressing administrative continuity, coupled with economic austerity and a crackdown on public corruption. The new military leader, Maj. Gen. Mohammed Buhari, summoned the country's senior civil servants to a meeting today at which he pledged his government would listen to their advice and seek maximum continuity with the old administration of deposed President Shehu Shagari, according to radio accounts from Lagos monitored here. The whereabouts of Shagari, reportedly arrested in central Nigeria, is still unknown. Buhari, who took power in an apparently bloodless coup Saturday, warned the administrators that the new 16-member Supreme Military Council, which he heads, would not tolerate dishonesty in government. Corruption had been pervasive in the Shagari administration. Buhari suggested corrupt officials would be jailed without trial, saying he would forego "the nonsenses of litigation" in dealing with offenders. Western diplomats and analysts here, while cautioning that it is still too soon to draw a definitive picture, believe Buhari and his fellow officers will follow a conservative financial policy. They pointed to his pledges to honor Nigeria's foreign debts, estimated at more than $15 billion, and to maintain its membership in the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) as signs that he is not planning to lead Nigeria down a radical political or economic path. "All indications so far are that this will be a conventional, conservative Moslem government," said one diplomat who has served in Nigeria. But there is uncertainty about Buhari's ultimate political agenda for Africa's most populous nation. Although Moslems have predominated in government, there are many different religious sects in Nigeria, including large numbers of Christians in the southeast and followers of traditional African beliefs. Religious differences have been a source of political and social strife in the past. Fundamentalist splinter groups of the northern-based Moslems have been blamed for major riots in the north in recent years. Observers here say the 41-year-old infantry commander, a Moslem from northern Nigeria, is considered a conscientious native son who, unlike some of his fellow officers, has had limited contacts with westerners despite his British military education and is a firm believer in national pride. He is believed to have been a leading member of that faction of the Army which resisted handing power back to civilians in 1979. Many analysts here believe Nigeria may be facing a future of successive military governments similar to those that ran the country between 1966 and 1979. Buhari is also considered a strong adherent to the view that only harsh economic medicine can cure Nigeria of its current fiscal ills. If so, he would likely prove willing to complete arrangements for a $2.5 billion loan package from the International Monetary Fund, which was urging the Shagari government to devalue Nigeria's currency and cut back government spending and imports to rescue the country's stricken economy. Earlier last week, Shagari had spelled out a package of economic reforms that he said would begin the painful process of retrenchment. But the new program apparently was not enough to dissuade the military leaders, whose coup plans were probably already in motion, observers here say. Although corruption has long been considered endemic in Nigeria, including under previous military governments, even avid supporters of Nigeria's democracy concede official corruption was so staggering under the civilians that it was likely to undermine Shagari's new plan. Nigeria, one of the United States' leading oil suppliers, has been in serious economic difficulties since the world oil market became glutted and prices began to fall in late 1981. Buhari, who headed the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation before 1979 under the old military government, is expected by many here to take personal charge of the country's oil policy. Officials of Venezuela, another non-Arab OPEC state, today expressed concern that the new government might unilaterally cut prices and increase oil production, setting off a possible oil price war within the organization, Reuter reported today from Caracas. American diplomats who deal with Africa say they have adopted a wait-and-see attitude toward the new government, which heads a country that is the United States' largest African trading partner. The Reagan administration has been criticized by some Africa watchers, who say it has emphasized American interests in southern Africa and friendlier ties with white-ruled South Africa while virtually ignoring what they see as at least equally important interests in countries like Nigeria. U.S. officials say they were quietly lending support to the Shagari government. The State Department had identified Nigeria as one of several Third World nations with growing debt problems that might warrant additional U.S. financial help. But an official said no support was possible until the Shagari government was prepared to crack down convincingly on corruption and institute strong economic measures. One source said Nigerian officials had told western governments privately that nothing could be done until after Shagari's reelection last August because of the incumbent government's fear of alienating the Nigerian electorate. "It would have been impossible to expect Congress and the taxpayers to bail out Nigeria when so many of its financial problems were the result of people stealing money," the source said. But no analyst here today suggested stronger U.S. support could have saved the Shagari government from overthrow. "It's a very, very sad situation but it's an internal question," said one analyst here. "I doubt very much there was anything any of the western democracies could have done."

COUNTRY: NIGERIA (94%); UNITED STATES (93%); AFRICA (92%); UNITED KINGDOM (79%);
TEXT: IN A COUNTRY that has known two earlier coups, a civil war and 13 years of military leadership since becoming independent in 1960, it can be no surprise that democratic government has succumbed again to a military takeover, as it just has in Nigeria. President Shehu Shagari had won resounding reelection last August. But the extent--not the fact --of his margin was attributable to fraud and malpractice of dimensions that left Nigeria a "wounded democracy." The resulting disenchantment, combined with Mr. Shagari's inability to reduce the deep economic distress and pervasive corruption, produced a readiness--in some quarters evidently even a longing--for the sort of firmness and efficiency associated with military rule. The new leader is Maj. Gen. Mohammed Buhari, 41, a British-educated officer of both political and technocratic bent who had a hand in an earlier coup and also served as oil minister. He moved at a moment of his predecessor's certain vulnerability--two days after Mr. Shagari had presented the austerity budget required under the terms of Nigeria's latest credit from the International Monetary Fund. Gen. Buhari made his move, he said, to save the nation from "imminent collapse." He takes upon himself and his brother officers a burden that cannot fail to tax their capabilities to the utmost. The oil glut has left Nigeria, a country almost wholely dependent on oil revenues, struggling to pay its bills and to meet the expectations of its 100 million citizens. A country's resources are not automatically magnified by a coup. As a sometime democracy, the United States' second largest oil supplier, black Africa's most powerful state and a friendly, Western-oriented country, Nigeria has long been of special concern to America. Oil and political considerations aside, Americans have been keenly interested to see whether the democratic enterprise could flourish on post-colonial African soil. Nigeria has been one of the few places on the continent where elected representative government seemed likely to take root. It could still happen. Economic and ethnic strains may push the central national government toward coercion, but an African tradition of self-government and Britain's colonial teachings are still alive. Nigeria is a giant struggling to live up to its own ambitious ideals. Its previous military leaders tried to avoid giving military rule the harsh name it has in most other African countries. Of the many tests before Gen. Buhari, the first is to ensure that arbitrary vengeance is not wreaked upon the deposed civilian leadership, which, whatever its shortcomings, did represent the people's choice.

COUNTRY: NIGERIA
TEXT: Africa's biggest democracy became Africa's biggest dictatorship last weekend. The military overthrow of any popularly elected government is a setback for freedom but it is especially grievous coming in Nigeria. Nigeria's democratic experiment was prepared with care. The military rulers of the 1970's sponsored a new, federalist system inspired by that of the United States, right down to political conventions. They hoped it could contain the tribalism and regionalism that defeated the parliamentary form left behind by the British. For nearly five years, Nigeria's hopes were rewarded. A milestone passed just last summer with the completion of a second round of national elections. Irregularities were not so pervasive as to shadow President Shehu Shagari's re-election mandate - not until ambitious soldiers seized on impatience with corruption and economic decline to produce last weekend's coup. The magnitude of the loss is evident from the way the new strongman dismisses trials for the allegedly corrupt. ''Nonsenses,'' he calls them. Corruption has seemed endemic in Nigeria under civilian and military rule alike - hard to avoid when huge oil revenues pour into an underdeveloped nation. In any case, patronage is probably an indispensable tool in stitching together a diverse and conflict-ridden society into a national political system.  But corruption has also been a real issue, repelling civic-minded Nigerians. In the end it seems to have undermined what should have been President Shagari's biggest asset, the legitimacy of his rule.  Against that background, the proximate cause of Mr. Shagari's demise was the austerity budget he just proposed. That fiscal plan was formulated in the context of debt-rescheduling negotiations with the I.M.F. No mere change in government can lessen Nigeria's huge debt.  The oil glut has devastated Nigeria's economy. What was a boom three years ago has turned into a $12 billion decline in annual oil revenues. Other OPEC countries were hit in the pocketbook; Nigeria, with a far larger population, was hit in the solar plexus.  The alarm that sounded in Nigeria resonates elsewhere. The oil glut, high interest rates and recession are squeezing virtually every economy in the third world. That is not an environment in which democracy can flourish, no matter how well laid the plans. If America cares about democracy in the rest of Africa, Asia and Latin America, it will have to lend more than its political structure.

COUNTRY: NIGERIA (94%); AFRICA (92%);
TEXT: Four months after seizing power, Nigeria's military leaders appear to be suffering an erosion of popular support. Last Dec. 31, Maj. Gen. Mohammed Buhari led a group of young officers in a coup against the civilian Government of President Shehu Shagari, saying the takeover was necessary to save Nigeria, Africa's richest and most populous nation, from economic collapse. The military intervention appeared at the time to enjoy enthusiastic support from a broad range of Nigeria's population. Many intellectuals argued that the corruption and incompetence of the Shagari administration had made drastic action both necessary and inevitable. Traders, merchants and people in the streets welcomed the soldiers and looked forward to a quick improvement in their standard of living. Growing Disappointment Recently, however, there seems to be growing disappointment with both the military Government's approach and pace. ''Since coming to power, this Government has not found a single problem,'' said Dr. Olu Onagoruwa, a prominent lawyer and a longtime opponent of the Shagari administration. ''But it has managed to alienate the judiciary, the press, labor and students - all the groups that supported it just a few months ago.'' Critics of the military Government point out that it has yet to present its budget. Loan negotiations with the International Monetary Fund continue but Western economists say that Nigeria and the I.M.F. appear to be further apart now than during the final days of the Shagari administration. Early indications that General Buhari would agree to devalue Nigeria's currency, liberalize trade and reduce domestic petroleum subsidies have so far not materialized. Prices Have Climbed In addition, prices for food and other essential commodities, which fell in the first weeks after the coup largely because of the presence of soldiers in the marketplaces, have now returned to or exceeded their levels before the coup. Unemployment has been rising, and many of the imported raw materials and spare parts needed to keep factories running have been lacking. Critics note further that political activity and even debate have been banned and some students organizations have been outlawed. There has been a clampdown on Nigeria's press, and the country's traditionally independent judiciary has also seen its role sharply diminished. ''At the moment we're looking at a clear movement toward authoritarian dictatorship,'' said Stanley N. Macebuh, executive editor of The Guardian, an independent newspaper that had often taken the Shagari administration to task. ''It's a trend that disturbs a lot of people, not least those who welcomed the change of government.'' Spokesmen for the military leadership maintain that they know what they are doing and refuse to be rushed. They deny the charges of inaction, saying that steps have been taken. Trials Being Prepared The Government, they say, has put much energy into investigating the corruption of the Shagari administration and in preparing tribunals to try the accused, close to 500 of whom are now under detention. Officials say about 2,000 illegal aliens have been ejected from the country and several thousand people have been detained in a crackdown on suspected criminals and Moslem extremists. They say Nigeria's bloated bureaucracy has been streamlined through the dismissal of thousands of officials and civil servants. Three weeks ago an agreement was reached in London on converting a part of Nigeria's uninsured trade debts into loans. The Government's critics respond that the economic initiatives treat symptoms rather than causes and aid the larger issue of how to restructure Nigeria's economy. A Western diplomat said General Buhari ''could have accomplished so much if he had moved quickly and boldly in the early days when his popularity was still so high and when he could have credibly blamed everything on Shagari.''

COUNTRY: GUINEA (95%); TOGO (94%); AFRICA (94%); COTE D'IVOIRE (93%); MALI (92%); WESTERN AFRICA (79%);
TEXT: Former Prime Minister Diarra Traore of Guinea seized power tonight after President Lansana Conte left the country to attend a meeting of African leaders in Togo. The takeover was announced by Colonel Traore on the Conakry radio, which said later that Colonel Conte, a French-trained army officer, had been declared a ''citizen in exile.'' Colonel Traore did not say whether there had been any bloodshed. 'Intolerable Disorder' Cited He said that after 26 years of dictatorship, nepotism and economic sabotage under former President Ahmed Sekou Toure, Guineans had suffered 15 months of ''disappointment, of intolerable disorder'' which had ruined the hopes raised by the coup led by Colonel Conte in April 1984. Colonel Conte is in the Togolese capital, Lome, for the meeting Friday of 10 African leaders of the Economic Community of West African States. Colonel Conte is current chairman of the group. The Conakry radio, monitored by the British Broadcasting Corporation, broadcast a communique by the Supreme State Council tonight saying the ruling Military Committe of National Recovery, headed by Colonel Conte, had been abolished. It added that the Government ''composed of elements whose major concern was only to personally enrich themselves'' had been dismissed. Colonel Traore and Colonel Conte had ruled together in an uneasy alliance since last year's army takeover shortly after the death of President Toure, who had ruled the country for 26 years. Colonel Traore served as Colonel Conte's Prime Minister until December 1984, when he was demoted to Minister of State for Education. Colonel Conte himself assumed the duties of the Prime Minister. Colonel Conte said then that he had reshuffled his Cabinet and abolished the post of Prime Minister because of what he called incompetence and corruption. In the last few months Guinea's 5.5 million people have become increasingly disillusioned over the lack of improvement in living standards in a country that is potentialy one of Africa's richest. The military's main achievement since the coup last year has been the release of thousands of political prisoners jailed under President Toure. Colonel Conte was reluctant to carry out economic austerity measures for fear of social unrest. These included a devaluation of the country's currency, the syli, a step recommended by the International Monetary Fund. The period since the coup has been marked by a breakdown in law and order, a rise in crime and even some nostalgia for the Toure era. After his demotion, Colonel Traore remained the second-ranking member of the military committee. But analysts said it would only be a matter of time before Colonel Traore, an ambitious army officer who adopted a higher profile than the unassuming President, made his move. Disagreements between them split the armed forces into two groups with strong ethnic overtones, they said. Little is known of Colonel Traore's political leanings or his views on economic matters, but in the months after the coup he appeared to espouse Colonel Conte's pledge of a society more open to foreign investment and free entreprise. His radio statement tonight appeared to confirm that Colonel Conte's inability to act on monetary reforms, including the possibility of Guinea joining the franc zone monetary union, was at the root of his action. ''Today it is more than ever necessary to put an end to footdragging in making political, economic and in particular monetary decisions which are to launch the development of our country,'' he said. A Supreme State Council communique broadcast after Colonel Traore's address urged Conakry residents to stay at home until further notice. In his radio address, Colonel Traore said the ''Supreme State Council'' had decided to take the country's destiny in hand because of the ''disintegration of the situation in the country, the hesitations of the last few months, the partisan struggles with some ethnic coloration, the emergence of egotistical interests, the lust for personal power.'' Guinea, a former French colony, has been independent since 1958. During President Toure's years in power, several coup attempts were crushed or foiled, while Guinea became notorious internationally for human-rights abuses. In October 1982, Amnesty International, the London-based human rights organization, named 78 political prisoners it believed had died and asked the Government to account for more than 2,800 others it said had disappeared. President Toure died in a clinic in the United States during emergency heart surgery in March 1984. Struggle for Succession The coup just eight days later, on April 3, put an end to a struggle for succession, ushering in what the army said would be a new era of freedom for Guineans. The military committee that took power denounced President Toure's rule as a ''ruthless and bloody dictatorship'' and said it would restore civil liberties. Colonel Conte announced the complete liberalization of the economy, based on free enterprise and foreign investment, breaking with President Toure's aim of a socialist Guinea with centralized planning, nationalized industries and collective agriculture. Guinea is one of the world's poorest nations, although it has some of the world's largest deposits of minerals. Guinea's 1981 gross national product was $1.6 billion. The main export is bauxite, which brings in about 80 percent of its foreign revenue. Guinea has about eight billion metric tons of bauxite reserves, the largest in the world, with huge resources yet to be developed. Guinea Government The People's Revolutionary Republic of Guinea, a former French colony in West Africa, was proclaimed an independent country on Oct. 2, 1958. The leader of the Democratic Party of Guinea, Ahmed Sekou Toure, became President and served for 26 years until his death on March 26, 1984. His organization became Guinea's sole party. On April 3, 1984, Col. Lansana Conte installed himself as President, suspended the Constitution and dissolved Parliament, replacing it with the 18-member Military Committee for National Rectification. Mr. Toure's political party was also dissolved. Area and Population Guinea has an area of 94,939 square miles, about twice the size of New York State. According to a mid-1983 estimate, Guinea has a population of 5,430,000. Conakry, the capital, is a city of 525,000 inhabitants. Three-quarters of the population is Moslem, one-quarter animist. Besides French, eight African languages are taught in schools. Economy Guinea is one of the leading world producers of bauxite, which is exported to Western countries and to the Soviet Union. More than 80 percent of the people work in agriculture, where the cash crops are coffee, bananas, palm kernels, peanuts and pineapples. Armed Forces The army, consisting of 8,500 men, is equipped with Soviet, Czechoslovak and Chinese weapons and armored cars. Guinea also has a militia of 9,200 men, a navy of 600 men and an air force of 800 men.

COUNTRY: NIGERIA (99%); UNITED STATES (93%); AFRICA (92%);
TEXT: The Nigerian military government of Maj. Gen. Mohammed Buhari, which struggled for 20 months to cure the country's massive economic problems, was overthrown today in an apparently bloodless coup led by the regime's third-ranking military leader. Maj. Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, 44, a career military officer who has played a pivotal role in three previous Nigerian coups, was named this afternoon on Nigerian television as the country's new president and military commander. The country's air and sea ports were sealed off, communications links with the outside world severed and a dawn-to-dusk curfew announced in major urban centers. Nigeria's land borders have been closed since shortly after the ousted government took power. In an address tonight on Nigerian television, Bagangida said the Buhari government had been "too rigid and uncompromising," had failed to end "economic mismanagement" and had caused "intolerable suffering." He also promised to release several Nigerian journalists who had been jailed under a 16-month-old law restricting criticism of the government. Earlier, in announcing the takeover in Africa's most populous nation, the sixth in the 25 years since Nigeria's independence from Britain, an Army officer said the action was taken because the Buhari government had misused power and wasted the country's resources. "We could not stay passive and watch a small group of individuals misuse power to the detriment of our national aspirations," said Brig. Joshua Dogoniaro on Lagos Radio this morning. Nigeria size and oil wealth, as well as its estimated 100 million population, underpin its influence in Africa. It also is an important trade partner of the United States, which imports about half of the country's oil output. Buhari came to power at the end of 1983 in a military takeover and pledged to resuscitate the Nigerian economy by ending the corruption and economic mismanagement of the 4 1/2-year-old civilian government of Shehu Shagari. The coup that brought Buhari to power was "welcomed by the nation with unprecedented enthusiasm," the Army spokesman said this morning. But, "almost two years later," he added, "it has become clear that the fulfillment of expectations is not forthcoming." The goals of the 1983 takeover "have been betrayed and discarded." Buhari's whereabouts were unclear today. Western diplomats in London said that Buhari had been in Lagos, the Nigerian capital, yesterday. Lagos was reported calm today after the coup. In Washington, the State Department said there was no indication of any dangers to the 7,000-strong American community in Nigeria. "We have had a good relationship with Nigeria based on a convergence of enduring national interests . . . . We expect that this relationship will continue," spokesman Charles E. Redman said. In Santa Barbara, Calif., White House spokesman Larry Speakes said that "Lagos is calm and radio announcements are encouraging peace and calm," The Associated press reported. The toppling of the Shagari government in 1983 brought an end to an experiment in multiparty democratic rule that was regarded as a political milestone in black Africa. Buhari, the new leader, moved quickly to implement his pledges to revive the economy by imposing austerity measures that laid off government workers, slashed social benefits, canceled industrial projects and kept Nigerians from spending their money on imported luxuries. A succession of harsh laws were passed to stop corruption, smuggling, street violence and curb political dissent. The government mounted a highly publicized "war against indiscipline." Buhari's tough policies, however, while helping to trim the deficit and making Nigeria slightly more livable, were not enough to turn around the economy. Nigeria, which boomed in the 1970s, becoming almost completely dependent on its large oil reserves, was not able to recover from a sharp drop in price and demand for oil. Its oil earnings, accounting for about 90 percent of its revenues, are about half what they were in 1980. Inflation is raging at more than 40 percent a year, compared to half that figure 18 months ago, unemployment has surged, there are food shortages and nearly half of the country's export earnings are consumed in servicing a $21 billion foreign debt. Under Buhari, Nigeria had refused to negotiate an agreement with the International Monetary Fund. The agreement, which required Nigeria to sharply devalue its currency, open its markets to imports and cut domestic fuel subsidies, would have bailed the country out of its debt squeeze by allowing it to reschedule loans. But in press interviews this year, Buhari said the IMF's medicine was politically impossible and that Nigeria must solve its own problems by tightenting its belt. He declared that Nigeria is "no longer begging anybody" and warned of "very tough" years ahead for Nigerians. Today's coup, according to diplomatic observers here, indicates that the military officers who orchestrated the 1983 coup and turned power over to Buhari, an experienced administrator, were unwilling to accept his stringent long-term economic prescriptions. One of the leaders of the 1983 New Year's Eve coup was Babangida, the new military leader and Army Chief of Staff on the Supreme Military Council. Although he has no experience as a government administrator, he has a reputation as a a bold and decisive military leader. He made his reputation among lower and middle ranks of the armed forces in 1976 when he walked unarmed into the offices of a radio station and persuaded Army officers attempting a coup to surrender peacefully. According to western diplomats here, a year before Babangida helped foil the 1976 coup attempt, he helped lead a coup that overturned the 9-year-old government of Gen. Yakubu Gowon. Babangida, who received military training in Nigeria, India, Britain and the United States, also is credited with having been a leading organizer of the 1983 coup that toppled Shagari. Diplomats say the general was disappointed when he was passed over in that coup. Babangida also was outranked by Maj. Gen. Tunde Idiagbon, chief of staff of the Supreme Military Council who was responsible for much of the day-to-day management of the government. Babangida is a Moslem from northern Nigeria, one of a succession of northern Moslems, both soldiers and civilians, who have led the country since 1975. In recent months, there have been increasing report of dissatisfaction among Nigeria's southern, mostly Christian population over the dominance of northern Moslems in the government. Support for Buhari reportedly waned sharply in the last year with the imposition of measures restricting freedom of speech and the press. In April 1984, the military government issued a decree that imposed harsh penalties for "disseminating false information about the government." The law muzzled Nigeria's traditionally free press.

COUNTRY: NIGERIA (95%);
TEXT: Military coups are not the ideal mechanism for changing political leadership, but to judge from the first signs, the latest change in Nigeria may be for the better. The military government of Gen. Ibrahim Babangida has quickly eased the repressive policies of the prior military government, releasing political prisoners and easing up on the country's traditionally outspoken press. It also seems more willing to reach agreement with the International Monetary Fund on the assistance needed to tide Nigeria through financial crisis. Nigeria's most recent experiment in democracy, though carefully designed and sponsored by an enlightened army leadership in the late 1970's, foundered in 1983 amid collapsing oil prices and charges of corruption. Then, the generals designated Gen. Mohammed Buhari to guide a recovery that never came for this large but tribally-fragmented society of some 90 million people. General Buhari worsened economic matters by trying to do without the I.M.F.'s financial assistance. Politically, his regime was tainted by repressive steps like the dramatic kidnapping of a Nigerian emigre from London, prolonged detention of political prisoners and constraints on the press. General Babangida's new Government will find no easy initiatives. Any deal with the I.M.F. will require sacrifices involving pride as well as pain. Corruption and tribal conflict are certain to persist for years, if not decades. Yet the new regime has so far embarked on a more constructive course than its predecessor did. More constructive still would be readmitting Nigeria's people to the process of selecting their leaders, and for that, there is ground at least for qualified hope.

COUNTRY: NIGERIA (96%); AFRICA (93%); WESTERN AFRICA (92%);
TEXT: As rain soaked his gold-braided uniform and dribbled from the fingers of his white-gloved hands, the new military leader of Africa's most populous, and highly coup-prone, nation stood at attention Tuesday through an outdoor ceremony marking 25 years of Nigerian independence. The winds and rains of the tropical storm that enveloped Lagos, drenching Maj. Gen. Ibrahim Babangida and 25,000 other Nigerians who crowded into a stadium here, were apt symbols of the political and economic forces that have battered this West African country for the past quarter century. "I hardly need say that the history of our nation in its independent existence has been a checkered one," said Babangida, who in August seized control of the government after orchestrating this West Africa nation's sixth military coup. Three of Nigeria's eight leaders have been assassinated; civilian governments have twice been ousted for alleged incompetence and corruption. The country was riven in the late 1960s by a 30-month-long civil war. Suddenly rich in the 1970s with oil, many of Nigeria's former leaders have been accused of wasting, misusing and stealing much of the money. Now, with a world oil glut, the country is unable to make payments on a $22 billion foreign debt. The general who stood impassively in the warm Lagos rain promised in a prerecorded television speech broadcast Tuesday that his government will break "the vicious cycle of hope and despair, faith and doubt, affluence and poverty, stability and chaos which had characterized the past quarter century of our national life." To that effect, Babangida announced a state of economic emergency for the next 15 months. The emergency is intended, he said, to make Nigeria self-sufficient in food production, to make the economy less dependent on its oil exports and to reduce government interference in private enterprise. Babangida banned the import of two staple foods, rice and corn. He also ordered an end to oil "counter-trade" deals that had been used to import consumer items and processed foods. In addition, Babangida promised that in 1986 his government would announce a plan for a return to an elected civilian government. A source close to the military government said later Tuesday that the plan would be announced Jan. 1, 1986, but that the transition to civilian rule could take as long as three years. Since Babangida came to power, Nigeria has been preoccupied with a debate over whether it should accept a multibillion-dollar International Monetary Fund loan that would ease the country's worsening debt burden. In return for the money, Nigeria would have to accept several politically unpalatable measures, including sharp devaluation of its currency and cuts in consumer fuel subsidies. In his speech, however, Babangida, who had vowed earlier to break the deadlock on the IMF loan, did not say, or even hint, whether his government would take the loan. According to a government official close to the Armed Forces Ruling Council, Nigeria's top law-making body, Babangida's senior military advisers have told him in recent days not to accept the loan. The loan has been widely condemned here as a ploy by western-influenced international lending agencies to undermine Nigeria's sovereignty. "It is a question of national pride," the official said, adding that Babangida has not yet made up his mind on the IMF deal. During Tuesday's ceremony at Tafawa Balewa Square, named for Nigeria's first civilian leader, who was murdered, Babangida stood in the downpour for nearly two hours. The wind and rain finally subsided shortly before noon as the assembled soldiers fired rifles and cannons in salute to Nigeria's silver jubilee of independence. The volleys of gunfire and low-flying aircraft frightened thousands of bats from trees near the stadium, sending them circling above the crowd as the soggy, stern-faced general was driven away in a black Peugeot.

COUNTRY: NIGERIA (98%);
TEXT: Barely a month after seizing power in a quietly managed coup, Nigeria's new President, Maj. Gen. Ibrahim B. Babangida, was reviewing the troops during independence day celebrations. As it happened, it was raining, and the soldiers arrayed before him were drenched. So was the President. ''If my boys stand in the rain, so do I,'' he is reported to have said. That gesture was welcomed by Nigerians who had endured 20 months of rigorously autocratic military rule under another major general. And since that rainy October day, General Babangida, the sixth military man to take over the government since independence 25 years ago, has continued down a path that is a clear departure from that of his predecessors. Again and again during the last five months, the General, a bearish man regarded as a hard worker who is quick to laugh, has put his ear to the ground to hear what his citizens are saying: Do they want to borrow money from the International Monetary Fund? Do they want to return to civilian rule and, if so, in what form? Where should the country's foreign policy head? There is in all this an echo of a populism in conflict with the more conventional notions of military rule on this continent. General Babangida has been accessible to journalists, both foreign and Nigerian. He has toured the country. He has dropped in on birthday parties for the children of soldiers. Nevertheless, an alleged plot to overthrow the Babangida Government was uncovered in December. How real the threat was remains cloudy, but a group of officers, including an army major general, are on trial before a secret military tribunal. If indeed a coup was being planned, as the Government maintains, it could mean that, in moving Nigeria away from corruption, waste and repression spawned by previous regimes, General Babangida is making enemies among those who figure to be his greatest threat - the military. General Babangida responded to the alleged plot with a verbal lashing of his military colleagues. ''I am certain that unless we review our position and take the necessary steps to recapture and reinstate our professional military virtues, we may sooner or later become no better than civilians with guns,'' he said. ''If that happens, we shall have disgraced the military profession and placed the nation in double jeopardy.'' ''The first duty we owe our profession,'' the General continued, ''is actually to belong to it. Our decision to become soldiers must be just that and not an avenue to other things. The determination of policy is not his concern. Right or wrong, to the professional soldiers the state is all.'' With such statements, General Babangida appears to many Nigerians to be slipping out of his military tunic and into a flowing ''riga,'' a robe worn by northern civilians. Indeed, when the General ordered sweeping pay cuts in the public and private sectors, he started with the military. ''When I was the chief of army staff, my perception was restricted to the army,'' he told The Guardian, a newspaper published in Lagos. ''On getting onto this beat, I found there were a lot of other conflicting needs within the country: health, education, rural development problems, etc. I couldn't see it from that point of view when I was chief of army staff.'' And again, in an interview with the British Broadcasting Corporation, General Babangida made clear his conviction that the military was not going to determine Nigeria's political future. ''What type of people, what type of government, who should participate, who should be in government - I think these are questions that are going to be answered by the people themselves,'' he said, ''and as much as possible the Government is not going to interfere in the people's verdict.'' Such deference to the populace, however, risks the appearance of indecisiveness. Recently, a special legal panel ruled that Nigeria's last civilian President, Shehu Shagari, who was overthrown by the military in December l983 after presiding over what are generally recognized as four of the most corrupt years in post-independence Nigeria, was himself innocent of corruption charges and should be freed. Rather than accept the finding, General Babangida has chosen to sample public opinion. In the north, where Muslims make up more than 90 percent of the population, there have been impassioned cries for the release of Mr. Shagari, who, like the General, is a Muslim. In the south, the verdict in his favor has been denounced. If the former President is released, The Guardian wrote, ''The gap between the rulers and the ruled will further widen. There will be a rise in public cynicism, especially in the notions of culpability and official corruption.'' There have been several weeks of confusion, both in the press and among Government officials, over whether Nigeria joined the Islamic Conference Organization during its January meeting in Morocco. Constitutionally, Nigeria is a secular state, but pressure from the Islamic north has in recent years pushed the country closer to the Muslim world. Last week, General Babangida, who had been keeping quiet, finally conceded that the country had indeed accepted membership. But in an apparent effort to defuse public unhappiness in the south, he appointed a committee to study the issue. Whether such caution is a conscious effort to arrive at national consensus or a way of defusing volatile issues through exhaustive public debate, it nevertheless reflects an uncertainty that could hinder the General's ability to cope with the nation's problems. ''He does not want to run the country as a military leader,'' said Dele Giwa, the editor of the influential weekly magazine Newswatch. ''He wants to be as popular and accepted as possible.''

COUNTRY: CONGO, THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE (95%); AFRICA (94%);
TEXT: After more than three years of economic austerity intended to revive Zaire's moribund economy, there are still no signs of economic growth or development, according to Western diplomats, economists and bankers. Yet, in the eyes of many Western countries, Zaire's economic experience has become a test case for Africa of efforts to salvage an economy shattered by mismanagement, corruption and wasteful spending. At the same time, Western diplomats are increasingly seeking to paint a more favorable picture of Zaire, a country where corruption reached legendary heights and whose human-rights record has for years been regarded as among Africa's worst. There is, diplomats say, a new Zaire emerging, albeit painfully, in Africa. 'Reason for Optimism' ''The figures say no development, said a senior international aid official here. ''They say regression. Still, there is reason for optimism.'' Economic austerity has meant higher prices for the average Zairian, few if any services and widespread unemployment in urban areas. In rural Zaire, where 80 percent of the population toils, agriculture has remained at little more than subsistence levels. ''The worst should be over,'' a banker said. ''They've done most of the hard work already.'' Problems in Many Areas Zaire's problems are immense and appear virtually insurmountable, both Zairian and foreign experts agree. These are among the problems: * Education at even the elementary level is getting worse rather than improving. * Health care is at best difficult, and at worst impossible to obtain for the average Zairian. Medicines are exorbitantly priced if they are available at all. * Agricultural production has steadily fallen so that today the country's production of most export crops is less than at independence 26 years ago. * Zaire imports 60 percent of its food. At independence, it was self-sufficient agriculturally. * There remain few passable roads around the country, preventing both the country's large copper-mining company, Gecamines, from efficiently shipping its ore and farmers from transporting produce to local markets. A Monetary Fund Test Nonetheless, Zaire, led by its autocratic president, Mobutu Sese Seko, has become a crucial test of the International Monetary Fund's formula for recovery in Africa. Four years ago, Zaire's economy had effectively collapsed. Mired in billions of dollars of debt incurred during the 1970's when the price of copper, the country's major mineral export, was booming and wallowing in Government corruption perhaps unequaled on the continent, Zaire decided to adhere to an austere regimen of financial and economic measures designed by the International Monetary Fund. Among the steps taken were an immediate raising of prices to farmers, resulting in some increase in agricultural production; a drastic devaluation of the country's currency, the zaire, which set off both a modest increase in exports and eliminated most smuggling, and a radical reorganization in the management of the country's major mining company. Government spending has been slashed, resulting principally in sharp cutbacks in Government workers, teachers being a principal example. This is one of the few examples where any country has been able to stick to I.M.F. prescriptions for three years running, a Western diplomat said. That is important, he said, because in the long pull, this is the place that has the greatest African potential. Debt Is Biggest Restraint Sticking to the I.M.F. plan has meant however, that Zaire has been forced to divert more than half its resources to meet payments on its $4.5 billion foreign debt. This in turn has permitted the Government to spend little on essential social services like health and education and on much needed public works projects like road building, electrification and clean drinking water programs for rural areas. The biggest restraint is debt, an economist said. ''If you do calculations of projected debt service, you find it a drag on the economy,'' he said. ''It is a real restraint on development. I believe debt service will be a significant drain on Zaire's budget for the foreseeable future.'' Another economist said: ''There is general agreement that whatever benefits have accrued to Zaire from the I.M.F. program, few of them are evident to the average citizen. There is no doubt in my mind that the average urban wage earner has a lower real wage than he did four years ago.'' A senior Western diplomat said: ''I think there is increasing discontent within the mind of the average Zairian who is getting no services from government. Even so, I don't think it is going to blow up. They are thinking of social programs.'' Increase in Price of Staples One result of the Government's economic programs has been a dramatic increase in the price of staples such as millet, sorghum and cooking oil over the last couple years. Transportation prices have doubled, and urban jobs are difficult to find. The main benefit of the I.M.F. program, a banker here said, is there is a great deal more certainty in the economy, more order in the economy and more external confidence. Many Western diplomats, as part of their acknowledged desire to see Zaire succeed in its compliance with the I.M.F. program and reinvigorate the economy, go out of their way to depict President Mobutu as a changed man, a leader more tolerant of his opponents and more concerned about his international image. In its 1985 report on human rights in Zaire, the State Department reported that despite the fact that no political opposition to Mr. Mobutu is permitted, there were concerted efforts by the Government to reconcile differences with political dissidents. Yet, the report said, there has been a sharply worsening human-rights situation in eastern Zaire, where low level rebel activity continues. Torture Reported in Prisons In eastern Zaire, the report charged, political killings and disappearances continued. In the rest of the country, the report said, there is little question that mistreatment of detainees, particularly beatings at arrest and during preliminary interrogation, is the rule rather than the exception.

COUNTRY: CONGO, THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE (96%); UNITED STATES (95%); AFRICA (94%); ANGOLA (92%); NICARAGUA (79%);
TEXT: PRESIDENT MOBUTU SESE SEKO of Zaire, who met with President Reagan at the White House last week, is one of Africa's most durable leaders, having seized power in 1965 in the former Belgian Congo. Reagan Administration officials consider the 56-year-old Mr. Mobutu an ally, and he is said to be a channel for covert American aid to Jonas Savimbi's rebels in Angola. But Zaire's economy, despite aid from the International Monetary Fund and World Bank and $70 million a year from the United States, is in dire straits after years of mismanagement and corruption. In Washington, Serge Mukendi, a Zairean dissident, accused Mr. Mobutu of having amassed a fortune of $5 billion, more than Zaire's $4.5 billion foreign debt. And human rights advocates said his single-party Government had committed ''gross and systematic'' abuses. During his Washington visit, President Mobutu discussed Zaire's problems with Clyde Farnsworth of The New York Times. Following are excerpts from their conversation, which was conducted in French and English. Question. Are you one of the world's richest men? Is your wealth greater than Zaire's debt? Answer. I cannot live outside the budget. There is one sole budget, and there is a presidential allowance fund. Where would the money come from? It's just not possible. The budget is published every year. It is known down to the last centime. The World Bank audits us. Money can only leave in regulated amounts, fixed by accord with the I.M.F. I know that we disturb people in some ways and make them unhappy, and so they do everything they can to bring me down. The person that you call Mobutu and his country are victims of disinformation. My enemies say anything to try to bring me down. But I rule only through popular support. All the people are behind me. Human rights violations? They will say anything. But the people know the truth. I am not yet overthrown. I am here. For four years, the World Bank and I.M.F. have controlled everything. Q. Have you been asked to give money to the Nicaraguan contras? A. I don't have it to give.  Q. How close are you to Washington? A. There are 50 independent countries on the continent. A lot of them receive assistance from the U.S. Some appreciate it, some attack the U.S. My country is different. We get very little assistance from the U.S. Whether we do or not, we are friends. Q. What is Zaire's regional role?  A. Zaire and all independent countries of Africa are bound by the charter of the Organization for African Unity. However, there are countries that have quite a bit of money because they have oil. And they don't seem to honor this charter. Sometimes they get militarily involved in the affairs of other countries. I think the occupation of Chad is an excellent example. Chad asked Zaire to help, and we sent 3,000 men to Chad at two different times. Obviously, this was costly. We had to send them Coca-Cola and water by air. We also trained troops from Chad in Zaire. We don't expect thanks necessarily, but our allies should consider the fact that we actually did something like this, simply because we do not accept what Libya is doing. Don't forget that Zaire was the first country in Africa to establish normal diplomatic relations with Israel. So you can see why Zaire is a target of Qaddafi. Savimbi Connection? Q. Do American military supplies go through Zaire to Savimbi in Angola? A. It's simply not true. Q. Do you expect United States help with the I.M.F.? A. President Reagan, in front of the press, made a formal promise to that effect. First there must be a commitment to continue the I.M.F. program. We don't want to continue on the path that almost led to catastrophe. Q. What went wrong? A. We did a perfect job with our commitments for four years. The results have been very negative for our people, but quite positive for the wealthy countries. In other words, Zaire is a net exporter of capital. We have given back more than we actually received to begin with. Zaire will still honor its commitments, but it will no longer be an exporter of capital. In 1986, Zaire paid out $500 million to the international banking and financial community through the I.M.F. However, the international financial community did not give one dollar to Zaire. Seven African countries have experienced food riots in which people died. In Zaire, because of decisions between us and the I.M.F., there have been sacrifices, but no riots and no bloodshed.

COUNTRY: NIGERIA (99%); AFRICA (93%); UNITED STATES (79%);
TEXT: This is the African country that parlayed a $ 100-billion windfall into a national curse. The oil boom from 1973 to 1981 crippled the livelihoods of the farming majority, hooked city people on subsidized imports and saddled the nation with an estimated $ 18-billion debt. As Nigerians have since acknowledged, it was their own inept, corrupt government that squandered much of the oil money. So it borders on the astonishing that Nigeria, having been jolted by two military coups in the past 38 months, is now being lauded by the World Bank and the United States as a role model in Africa for free market reforms and responsible government. "Nigeria has embarked on the most comprehensive economic adjustment program in Africa so far," said Ishrat Husain, resident representative here for the World Bank. "We were never expecting them to do as much as they have done." Nigeria's conversion from corrupt profligate to capitalist exemplar was not entirely voluntary. It was forced by last year's collapse of oil prices. Foreign debt became unpayable. Shippers stopped delivering goods. Economic activity in Africa's most populous country almost ground to a halt. But the past year's radical economic transformation here appears to be more than a last-chance maneuver to avoid default. It derives from the distinctively obdurate nationalism of the Nigerian people and the deft manipulation of that nationalism by Maj. Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, the country's military leader. "Nigerians are so self-centered that they don't make rational decisions when the choices are imposed on them from the outside," said Prince Tony Momoh, minister of information and culture. "Nigerians believe there are things superior to reasoning. Things such as pride." It was pride that kept Nigeria from accepting a loan of $ 2.4 billion from the International Monetary Fund in 1985, the year Babangida seized power in a bloodless coup. The money probably would have prevented the debt crunch that brought this country to its knees last year. Shortly after coming to power, Babangida opened what became known as the "Great IMF Debate." In the debate, a uniquely Nigerian plebiscite-cum-shouting-match that was carried on in the pages of the country's daily press, it soon became clear that the public saw the IMF and its demand for economic reform as insidious instruments of greedy westerners. In addition, many Nigerians, having watched their leaders waste billions of dollars of oil money, said a loan would only increase the national debt by allowing officials to squirrel away more public funds in foreign banks. Babangida abided by the public's will and rejected the IMF loan. Then, he slowly began to put in place what western economists are calling the most rigorous free market reform package ever adopted in an African country. The package meets all of the demands of the IMF. In fact, economists here say it is far tougher than the IMF would have dared to demand. "It has registered on a lot of people in the U.S. government that this is one of the most exciting economic reforms in Africa," said U.S. Ambassador Princeton Lyman. The reforms have led to a drastic devaluation of the naira, the currency whose one-to-one parity with the dollar had been considered an inviolate symbol of Nigerian pride. A dollar now buys nearly four naira. The cherished perquisites of the country's middle class, which had been subsidized by the grossly overvalued naira, fell victim to market forces. Car prices tripled. International air fares, which had been one of the best bargains in the world, doubled. School fees quadrupled for the 100,000 Nigerian families who send their children to study abroad. The reforms abolished an import licensing system that had made millionaires out of hundreds of Nigerian sharpies who used relatives and friends in the Ministry of Trade to obtain import licenses and resold them to businessmen desperate to import spare parts. Now businessmen simply import what they can pay for. Also scrapped were the country's six commodities boards, ineffectual agencies that had for years held down the price of farm produce. Abolition of the cocoa marketing board boosted the price of a ton of cocoa from $ 400 to $ 1,155. In broad outline, the reform package penalized the urban elite in favor of farmers. This is a risky business in Africa, where political power is concentrated among city dwellers. And while the reforms embraced the free enterprise theology that the IMF, World Bank and U.S. government are preaching across Africa, Babangida appears to have persuaded a large portion of the Nigerian public that his reforms are "home-grown." Playing to a nationalism that is more potent here than anywhere else in black Africa, Babangida said in his 1987 budget speech that "our structural adjustment program was produced by Nigerians for Nigerians." "It is a political masterpiece," said Husain, the senior World Bank official. "If he had done exactly the same thing under the aegis of the IMF, there would have been riots or a coup d'etat." The economic adjustment package has so pleased defensive creditors that Nigeria has been able to quietly reschedule most of its debt. Two years ago, 44 percent of export earnings went to service foreign debt. This year, the government says, that burden has been cut in half. While international banks and western governments are delighted with the reform package, it has provoked howls of distress from the country's manufacturers. The reforms sharply reduced the number of imports banned from Nigeria, making local manufacturers vulnerable to world competition for the first time. "The very existence of the industrial sector is seriously threatened," said Chief Jerome Udoji, president of the Manufacturers Association of Nigeria. He warned of mass unemployment, bankruptcies and "a return to the former colonial days of a trade economy." Nigerians are paying a painful price for reform. Average per capita income for the country's 105 million people is 25 percent less now than in 1974. College graduates are all but unable to find professional-level jobs, according to recent press reports here. The nation's factories, according to government figures, operate at less than 30 percent of capacity. These warnings have pushed the government into some minor policy adjustments. But, according to Information Minister Momoh, the government is determined not to shelter uncompetitive local businesses simply because they are Nigerian. "The manufacturers have not yet reconciled themselves to the fact that we are trying to force a market economy on everyone. We are telling people that if things are too expensive, don't buy them. The joy is that it hurts everyone," said Momoh. Homilies on free enterprise and honest government have become standard fare for Nigerian ministers in the past year. But western economists and businessmen say such rhetoric has been slow to change corrupt government contracting methods. Payoffs and kickbacks remain essential ingredients in most government spending processes, these sources say. In addition, the Nigerian government, despite its professed devotion to marketplace solutions, continues to fund expensive projects that have little chance of clearing a profit. The grandiose Adjaokuta steel works, for example, already has cost an estimated $ 3 billion. Experts say it will never make steel at prices competitive with the world market. Despite these blemishes, Nigeria has moved faster and further toward fundamental economic reform than most western observers believed possible when Babangida came to power 20 months ago. Fortunately for the government's survival, the reform has coincided with two years of bumper crops. Local prices of staple foods have fallen in the past year. Unlike most African countries facing several years of austerity as they rebuild their economies, Nigeria also has oil. Correctly managed, the oil revenue, even in a weak world market, can cushion the transition from an oil-addicted to a mixed economy, according to economists. Sustained economic recovery depends on the ability of the present government to survive and keep its reforms in place. "If the government can sustain these changes, Nigeria could be the shining star of Africa," said Husain of the World Bank, which has committed about $ 1 billion in loans to support the reform package. The reforms last month earned the IMF's approval. A standby arrangement, which triggered a move by Nigeria's creditors to stretch out their loans, gives Nigeria the right to borrow up to $ 850 million from the IMF. Proud Nigeria, however, still hates the IMF. According to Momoh, Babangida's government has vowed never to borrow a penny.

COUNTRY: NIGERIA (99%); AFRICA (95%); UNITED STATES (92%); SOUTH AFRICA (79%); WESTERN AFRICA (79%);
TEXT: Things fall apart. That phrase, the title of a novel by Nigerian writer Chinua Achebe, describes this country's fitful passage into modernity. Nigeria is hot, crowded and noisy. Totems of its culture are hard work and armed robbery, doctorates and tribal hatred, family loyalty and fast cars. Its people heap scorn upon themselves as corrupt, inefficient and self-destructive. But even as things fall apart, Nigeria somehow has managed to meld itself into a nation. Against all odds, things come together. Out of the Biafran war, Africa's bloodiest tribal conflict, has come a lasting peace -- a feat of forgiveness remarkable in world history. Out of the berserk corruption of Nigeria's oil boom has come an economic reform package that, if sustained, will be a model for this continent. Out of the failure of two attempts at American-style democracy has emerged a moderate military regime that respects human rights, allows freedom of expression and vows to dissolve itself so that Nigeria can take another crack at democratic government. There are no guarantees these achievements will last in this fractious land. Little about Nigeria fits western images of Africa. The big game is long since dead, gone the way of the American buffalo. Hunger is rarely a problem; the soil is rich, rain is plentiful. Race is a moot issue. White people never could stand the swampy West African heat, so few settled here. Instead, there are millions upon millions of Nigerians -- 105 million is the best recent estimate. One of every six Africans lives in Nigeria, the continent's most populous nation. The country's population is growing at a rate that is among the highest in the world. In less than 50 years, according to a conservative projection, Nigeria will have 618 million people -- more than the present population of all Africa. Images of Nigeria are not nearly as romantic as those of safari Africa. The bush has been invaded by freeways, farms, universities, oil wells, slums, suburbs, breweries and mosques. But these images say far more about what Africa is and where it is going. If the world's poorest continent is going anywhere, Nigeria is likely to get there first. Nigerians themselves are not at all shy about explaining how important their country is. "The world should see Nigeria for what it is: the country with the largest concentration of black people on earth and therefore the torchbearer for the black race," says Prince Tony Momoh, a wealthy businessman, influential traditional leader and minister of information in the Nigerian governmemt. Besides sheer numbers, Nigeria possesses wealth that distinguishes it from the rest of the continent. Its gross national product is bigger than South Africa's and more than half that of all black Africa. It is the world's ninth largest oil producer. At current consumption levels, Nigeria has 35 years of oil and 100 years of natural gas. Above ground, there are tens of thousands of university-trained professionals -- the country produced more college graduates in the 1970s than did all of Africa in colonial times. Africa's only Nobel laureate in literature, Wole Soyinka, is a Nigerian. The nation is the continent's fountainhead for music, art, literature and, most recently, hard-nosed economic reform. Yet the "torchbearer" has a habit of tripping over its own riches and burning itself badly. The oil boom of the 1970s gave Nigeria a $ 100 billion windfall. When the boom ended, the country had an $ 18 billion foreign debt, a population addicted to foreign luxuries and a farm economy that forgot how to grow food. A generation was weaned on avarice. Corruption hypnotized the national psyche. "Big men" ordered gold bathtubs from Europe and set fire to government buildings that contained records linking them to corruption. Lagos, the port capital, became the world's most expensive city. It became notorious for all-day traffic jams, piracy in the harbor and pandemic bribery. In 1977, as the oil money flooded in, Gen. Olusegun Obasanjo, then head of the military government, said that Nigeria is "a place where people are prepared to destroy anything, to cover up any crime, if doing so promotes their economic interest or might." And then there were the coups, the assassinations and the civil war. Six military coups in 26 years, three heads of state murdered. Gen. Murtala Mohammed was shot to death while stuck in traffic. In the 1967-70 Biafran war, nearly a million Nigerians were killed or starved to death. Like most of the countries carved out of colonial Africa, Nigeria is a geographical and historical fluke. It was created by a British colonial governor-general and named by a foreign correspondent from The Times of London (a woman who later married the governor-general). In a region larger than California, Arizona and New Mexico combined, Nigeria brought together tribes that had fought each other for centuries, made countrymen of mutually suspicious Moslems and Christians and gave the gift of citizenship to people who spoke 395 different languages. The Yoruba, of whom there are about 20 million, are one of three major ethnic groups in Nigeria. They descend from an ancient trading civilization and they dominate the country's largest cities. The sensibilities of the Yoruba have helped forge the character of Nigeria. "When a Yoruba man says 'absolutely no,' he means 'let us negotiate,' " explains Bade Ajuwon, a Yoruba man and director of the Institute of African Cultural Studies at the University of Ife. "It is the negotiation, the struggle, that we want. It is our life, our mentality, our blood," says Ajuwon. "The Yoruba have a proverb that says that only the thing for which you have struggled will last." A taste for struggle has charged Nigeria with an aggressiveness unique in Africa. In a country where "absolutely no" means maybe, where a shouting match is a routine warm-up to a business deal, where a man doesn't know if a woman is interested until she tells him to get lost, there is a cultural logic behind Nigeria's penchant for falling apart while coming together. The history of independent black Africa is that of traditional cultures reinventing themselves to accommodate western ideas and technology. It has been a halting, confusing process. Nigeria, with its wealth, its huge pool of educated people, its aggressiveness, has reinvented itself at a higher velocity than the rest of black-ruled Africa. It has not been any smoother here, just faster. Consider the four-lane expressway that connects the country's two largest cities, Lagos and Ibadan. The white metal guard rails that separate oncoming traffic have been pulverized for more than 100 miles by cars gone out of control. The railing lies limp and useless on the median strip like long pieces of overcooked spaghetti. This twisted reminder of mayhem does not prevent traffic from traveling at between 90 and 100 miles an hour, except for cars that are capable of going faster. Every few miles on the median strip, between giant ant hills, the mangled railing and the burned-out, picked-clean skeletons of cars that didn't survive, are billboards that warn: "Slow Down -- Speed Kills." Freeways, built in the 1970s with the oil boom money, are a good place to watch modern urban Nigeria collide with itself and with traditional rural Africa. Market women set up shop on the freeways. They walk to work from nearby farm villages, carrying their wares on their heads and their babies on their backs. As their children play naked on the asphalt shoulders, the women sell yams and forest rats, goat meat and toothpicks, warm beer and cola nuts. Cola nuts are popular with fast drivers. The nuts, bitter with caffeine, keep them awake. This is particularly important at night when the market women go home and the armed robbers come out.
