Unlike much of Africa, there are lots of guns in private hands in Nigeria. Highways offer a place for people who have guns to meet people who have cars and money. Every few months, the voluble Nigerian press explodes in outrage about armed robbery. That happened early this year when the wife of former head of state Gen. Obasanjo, the leader who said his countrymen would commit any crime for money, was shot to death in traffic on a highway in Lagos. Lynda Obasanjo was ordered out of her new Peugeot 505 by four young men with guns. When she failed to move quickly, she was shot several times. She was pulled from the car and left to die in the street. The robbers took the car. Shortly after the murder, Nigeria's two largest news weeklies ran cover stories on "Murder Incorporated" and "Return of the Assassins." In a front-page story, The Sunday Sketch, a Lagos daily, wrote, "Our society is under siege, its citizens are terrorized and dehumanized. Somebody somewhere should wake up and diffuse this siege before we all go out of our minds." Disorienting change has been a given in Nigerian life since the country became independent in 1960. Since then, the economy has turned upside down, boomed as no African economy has ever boomed and then fizzled. Oil all but killed off the farm. Farm exports fell from 90 to 3 percent of total export earnings. The world's leading exporter of palm oil and peanuts became one of the world's leading importers of palm oil and peanuts. Oil took over. Oil money flooded the cities, and so did Nigerians. The percentage of the population living in cities doubled, from 15 to 30 percent, and the number of cities with more than a half-million people jumped from two to nine. Lagos became black Africa's biggest city, with about 4 million people. Primary school enrollment tripled. It is now close to 100 percent. Universities sprang up across the country. As recently as 1985, more than 100,000 Nigerian families had one or more children studying abroad. Each year about 35,000 Nigerian students attend American universities. A generation of Nigerians has grown up in the aggressive pursuit of western-style success. But that pursuit has not obliterated traditional African culture. In a country that comes together by falling apart, cultural dissonance is a way of life. The same daily newspapers that feature turgid analyses of structural adjustment policy also carry news bulletins about regional reduction in bride prices. Well-to-do families, whose children have doctorates from the world's finest universities, routinely appease the spirits of dead elders by placing full-page advertisements in the newspapers. The ads, which always feature a flattering photograph of the departed, remind the spirits that the living still care. Consider the ooni of Ife. Among the Yoruba, the ooni (pronounced OWE-nee) is the top oba or traditional leader. By tradition he is a direct descendant of Oduduwa, who came to earth in the town of Ife (about 150 miles northeast of Lagos) and there fathered the human race. In precolonial Nigeria, the ooni was a religious leader and a warlord. In the colonial era, he was one of many traditional leaders coopted by the British in their system of indirect rule. The current holder of the title, Oba Okunade Sijuwade Olubuse II, rides in a cream-colored 240D stretch Mercedes limousine with a purple and white license plate that says: "Ooni of Ife." When he appears in public, usually clad in gold brocade and slippers, an official trumpeter blasts out a loud riff. As a direct descendant of the progenitor of the human race, the ooni does not grant interviews. But he is mindful of the value of media exposure. To that end, he has retained Basha Alperin, an American woman with media experience. "I do video for the ooni," explains Alperin. She shoots videotape of the ooni receiving petitioners in his palace in Ife, performing religious ceremonies (there are some 400 gods in the pantheon of the Yoruba religion) and traveling on official business. In independent Nigeria, traditional rulers such as the ooni have almost no official power. Most Yoruba are Christian or Moslem. The ooni himself is a millionaire businessman who juggles religious and entrepreneurial obligations. (His late predecessor, a church-going Anglican, was not above using his influence to line his pockets. As head of the Ife District Native Authority, he gave an exclusive concession to exploit Ife Forest to a timber company he partly owned.) It is possible, given enough cash, to buy a traditional title. Many wealthy businessmen have spruced up their image by adding "Chief" or "Oba" to their business cards. Yet Nigerians continue to respect traditional leaders, whose vague authority has survived the colonial administration, two civilian regimes and five changes of military leadership. "No government has ever succeeded in reaching rural areas without using the traditional leaders," says Information Minister Tony Momoh. In the current military regime, obas -- even obas who bought their titles -- are seen by the government as legitimate spokesmen for the demands of local communities. Contradictions rest easy with Nigerians, for whom economic, social and political collisions are the stuff of everyday life. The most striking of these contradictions is the coexistence of the country's masochistic appetite for self-condemnation and its chest-thumping nationalistic pride. Titles of popular books by Nigerians include: "Another Hope Betrayed," "The Trouble With Nigeria" and "Always a Loser -- A Novel About Nigeria." A recent newspaper column about national ineptitude was headlined: "It wouldn't be Nigerian if it worked." Nearly four years ago, the federal government came up with WAI -- the War Against Indiscipline. Unique in Africa, WAI amounted to a government admission that Nigerians are intolerably rude and messy. WAI posters were distributed throughout the country, urging people to stand in line, pick up their garbage and be nicer. In a country that blames itself for squandering billions of dollars in oil revenue, self-flagellation has become a national rite. O. Gbola Ajao, who teaches at the College of Medicine in Ibadan, wrote recently to the New Nigerian newspaper: "Some years ago we were asking about developing a tourist industry in Nigeria. What a laugh! How will any foreigner in his right mind want to come for vacation in a place like Nigeria? Even those of us born there are always looking for one excuse or another to get out of the place." Yet, even as they subject themselves and their leaders to withering condemnation, Nigerians have been extraordinarily intolerant of outside criticism or advice. "Nigerians are not rational," says Tony Momoh, principal spokesman for the military government of Maj. Gen. Ibrahim Babangida. "We would prefer to go hungry to being told what to do. I can't think of any other African country doing such an irrational thing. But there is more to a Nigerian than reasoning." For more than five years, Nigeria rejected a loan from the International Monetary Fund that was conditioned on economic reform. The IMF's demand that Nigeria's currency, the naira, be devalued was popularly viewed as an imperialistic attempt to castrate the country. Other reforms, which threatened the perquisites of the politically powerful middle class, were portrayed in the local press as the sneaky schemes of greedy westerners. When the Babangida government seized power after a bloodless coup in 1985 -- as unpayable foreign debts mounted and oil revenues continued to shrink -- it became clear that prideful opposition to economic reform would bankrupt the country. Unable to overcome Nigeria's pride, Babangida outwitted it. In one of the neatest economic maneuvers in African history, the general told the IMF that Nigeria didn't want the loan. Then, as the country rejoiced in having told the IMF where to go, the military government implemented an IMF-style reform package that western economists describe as the most comprehesive on the continent. The package has led to a liberal rescheduling of foreign debts and eased Nigeria's financial crisis. The reforms, which penalize the urban elite in favor of farmers, are far stricter than officials from the IMF or World Bank say they would have dared demand. And Babangida, a former tank commander with an engaging smile, has sold them to his country as "our structural adjustment program produced by Nigerians for Nigerians." Thus far, with Nigeria's pride appeased, both Babangida and the reforms enjoy wide popularity. In postboom Nigeria, money is tight. With devaluation of the naira, the price of automobiles, foreign schooling and international air travel has increased three-fold. Austerity is a dreary and unavoidable fact of life. But Nigerians seem determined not to let the dreariness get out of hand. In Lagos, Nike Marinho designs and sells formal wear for weddings, birth ceremonies, funerals and installations of obas. The clothing is of traditional design, brilliantly colored, individually tailored, intricately beaded. A bargain outfit for a man or woman costs $ 300 to $ 500. An expensive outfit can run $ 1,200 or more. Marinho says her customers feel obligated to buy three or four outfits for a marriage or a funeral, affairs that usually involve several gatherings over two or three days. She acknowledges that her customers have far less money than they used to. But she says they still buy three or four outfits, often borrowing the money. "We Nigerians are gullible for dressing up," she says. Olagoke Olabisi, dean of the engineering department at Lagos State University, recently purchased four new outfits to wear to the four gatherings commemorating the death of his father. The clothes cost more than Olabisi could afford, he says. Asked if anyone would notice if he were to wear an old outfit or even wear a new outfit twice, Olabisi replied: "I would notice."

COUNTRY: CONGO, THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE (96%); AFRICA (92%); SUB SAHARAN AFRICA (79%);
TEXT: This country is a long-suffering student in the free-market school of how not to be an economic basket case. For four years it courageously has done what the western financial experts said it must do. It has stopped wasting money on white-elephant projects and begun paying farmers prices that give them an incentive to grow food. It has lifted price controls and devalued its currency. That is one view of Zaire, supported by mountains of economic reports and many very long speeches. There is another, decidedly more cynical view, also supported by many observers here. It goes like this: Zaire is a den of unregenerate thieves. Its president and top ministers mouth the free-market lingo that the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and the Reagan administration like to hear, while continuing to fill foreign bank accounts with loot. No government project is begun without payoffs. Payoffs are so ubiquitous and so exorbitant that many projects are never completed. Civil servants regard extortion as a part of their job description. The murky truth about Zaire, sub-Saharan Africa's second largest country, seems to be that both of these views are true and false. Corrupt Zaire is reforming as never before; reforming Zaire is still corrupt. The IMF and World Bank were invited back to Zaire in 1983, after several years' absence, to rescue this country from unpayable debts and its own venality. Their advice, after four years, appears to have taken some of the bite out of what many Africa scholars call the "kleptocratic" state. But not even the western economists who designed and help implement the reforms are willing to say they see a new dawn of good government. "If you think structural adjustment is going to turn Zaire around, you are a bit naive," said one western economist who monitors reform here. "Corruption is an ethic. An economic program does not and cannot change a social malaise." What reform has wrought here in this vast, resource-rich country is a mixed bag. Western governments have agreed not to tempt Zairian officials with more kickback-generating big projects, such as hydroelectric dams or office centers, which the country does not need and cannot afford. And yet, according to a well-informed western diplomat, a public hospital in Kinshasa was completed this year at 200 percent of cost -- 100 percent to build the hospital, 100 percent for payoffs to government officials. The government has ordered that farmers be paid prices that are high enough to motivate them to grow food. Where the prices have been paid, there has been an impressive increase in food production. And yet many middlemen across rural Zaire refuse to cut their exorbitant profits and do not pay fair-market prices to farmers. Consequently, those farmers refuse to grow more food than they need for their families. Zaire remains a food importer in spite of its enormous agricultural potential. The new minister in charge of economic policy is a brilliant, hard-working and honest technocrat who western diplomats agree is the best-qualified Zairian ever to hold such power. And yet the country's authoritarian president, Mobutu Sese Seko, recently saw fit to dispatch a government-owned DC8 airliner to Venezuela 32 times to pick up 5,000 sheep for his private farm. In the halls of the United Nations in New York and in a number of western capitals there has been a lot of sympathetic rhetoric this year about the intractable economic problems of poor African countries such as Zaire. A recent report on Africa's economic crisis appealed to western governments to help the African countries that have "courageously" implemented reform programs. The report said that even as these countries have tried to correct past mistakes and rebuild their economies, they have suffered "a calamitous decline." They have been hit, the report said, with a double whammy of unpayable debts and falling commodity prices, which have dropped to their lowest levels in 30 years. Zaire exemplifies this bad luck. The government says that in the past four years it has paid $ 2 billion in interest on its $ 6 billion foreign debt. This is a quarter of its export earnings over that period and half of the government's budget. Debt payments devoured most of Zaire's new loans from the IMF and the World Bank. In the process, Zaire, which the World Bank lists as the ninth-poorest country in the world, became a net exporter of hard currency. While this was going on, the price of the country's main export, copper, collapsed. Consumer prices rose and life for the common man in Zaire, always miserable, became more so. The country was "risking a social explosion," according to a senior Zairian official. This was not what the U.S. government and other sympathetic donors had in mind when they pressed structural reform on Zaire. Accordingly, this past spring the country was given a debt reprieve. The Paris Club, a group of western creditor governments, granted Zaire six years' grace on its bilateral debts and extended payment periods for up to 15 years. The agreement was, according to an official in Zaire's Ministry of Finance, "without precedent. No country in Africa had been treated as generously before." Since the spring, the World Bank has promised Zaire $ 165 million in loans to support imports. The IMF has come up with another $ 142 million loan, half of which does not have to be repaid for 10 years. Zaire's bad economic fortune and its four years as a quasi-faithful student of structural reform were important factors in its receiving this money. But there was something else involved. This government has friends in Washington. "Our main interest is making sure that this big country, as big as all of Europe, does not fall to pieces, endangering the stability of all of central and southern Africa," said one senior western diplomat here. The United States, which has had a long and secretive relationship with Mobutu's government, is first among those western countries that have kept Zaire from falling to pieces. Last spring, a senior IMF official in Washington reportedly resigned in protest because the U.S. government was pressing the fund to ease lending conditions for Zaire. Sources here say the U.S. government was also a major force in the Paris Club's decision in May to reschedule Zaire's debts. U.S. foreign aid to Zaire is now about $ 60 million a year, the second-highest figure in sub-Saharan Africa. The quid pro quo for American largess goes far beyond Zaire's efforts at free-market reform. It is tied to the country's western orientation and its strategic position in southern Africa. Zaire is the largest, most consistent ally of the United States in the region. The American Embassy in Kinshasa is one of the largest on the continent. U.S. military forces regularly conduct maneuvers in Zaire. According to diplomats here and officials in Washington, Mobutu's government has allowed the Central Intelligence Agency to use the southern Zairian air base of Kamina to airlift arms to rebels fighting the Marxist government in Angola. Representatives of the rebel Union for the Total Liberation of Angola (UNITA) have a secret but semiofficial status at Kinshasa's international airport. A witness saw them meet a commercial airliner there last month and usher foreign journalists around customs and immigration officials. They took the reporters to a private aircraft at the airport and flew them to the war zone in southern Angola. Mobutu has categorically denied any role by Zaire in helping to supply or support the South African- and U.S.-backed UNITA rebels. When asked what the UNITA people were doing at Kinshasa's airport, Zaire's minister of information, Mandungu Bula Nyati, insisted that they were not there. "It is not possible. It cannot be possible," he said. Thomas M. Callaghy, an assistant professor of political science at Columbia University, is one of a number of specialists on Zaire who take the cynical view. He argues that the Mobutu government has adroitly used U.S. strategic interests in southern Africa to keep open the spigots of western money. At the same time, he says, it blocks substantive reforms that would cut into corrupt practices among Mobutu's inner circle of ministers. Shortly after the IMF and World Bank returned to Zaire for another try at economic reform, Callaghy wrote: "There is little in the history of Zaire's economy . . . that would lead most observers to conclude that Mobutu is seriously undertaking substantial economic reforms. Indeed, the corruption and mismanagement which have been associated with Mobutu and his ruling elite are the very elements which keep them in power." Economists and diplomats here who have watched the reform process firsthand in recent years say that Callaghy's bleak view is now only half right. One economist acknowledges that "everything we try to do stops when it cuts too close to the bone" -- meaning Mobutu, his family and his senior ministers. Another says "the solution for getting the most out of your money is not to come here at all." But there is a consensus among western officials directing assistance programs in Zaire that some of the broadest avenues for graft have been closed. As one diplomat said, "Leakage in the system has gone down significantly since 1983. Reform has weeded out those who are there only to steal money." The biggest leak for years was in the revenues of Gecamines, the state mining corporation. In the past, millions of dollars in copper and cobalt revenue disappeared without a trace. Now those revenues are accounted for in a procedure supervised by the World Bank. Besides plugging leaks in the "kleptocratic" system, many western donors are trying to steer clear of the system. They target small-scale aid directly at rural areas, where 70 percent of Zaire's 35 million people live. Most of the money is spent to solve the country's most acute problem, transport. "This whole system puts limits on how far reform can go," said a western diplomat. "You work with what you got."

COUNTRY: NIGERIA (96%); AFRICA (95%); WESTERN AFRICA (79%);
TEXT: Through a car window, a Lagos ''go slow,'' or traffic jam, offers a snapshot of the diminished fortunes of Nigeria, the giant of black Africa. Five years ago, freeways here were clogged with cars bought during an oil boom. Today, traffic clogs behind cars that break down because owners cannot afford spare parts. Traffic also slows when the police set up checkpoints to look for armed robbers. Increasingly, newspapers say, these bandits come from the newly poor middle class. Some Peddle Their Wares Outside the car window, a ''go slow'' victim invariably encounters nimble young men peddling their wares to a captive market. Recent offerings ranged from videocassette tapes to bikini underwear. These are the hallmarks of Nigeria today - entrepreneurial hustle amid economic depression, a fraying social fabric amid a liberalizing political climate. With a gross national product larger than that of South Africa and a population that accounts for one in four black Africans, Nigeria has always played out African trends on a grand scale. As newly independent African countries suffered from instability, this West African nation was one of the shakiest, enduring six coups and three presidential assassinations since independence in 1960. As tribal pressures strained Africa's new nations, Nigeria was torn by the continent's most violent tribal conflict - the Biafra War of 1967 to 1970, in which about a million people died. As development became the new religion, Nigeria put its faith in oil, earning $100 billion in a decade. But oil prices crashed, and Nigeria found itself with a $21 billion foreign debt, an urban population dependent on foreign imports and a rural population that could no longer feed the nation. #2 Courses of Action ''The party was over,'' Remi Ilori, a Nigerian newspaper columnist, wrote recently. ''We awakened to the reality that we had spent colossal sums of money feasting. The tables had to be cleared - so many plates of unfinished food, so many empty bottles of beer.'' Nigeria has embarked on two courses that, once again, are being watched with interest across Africa. Both involve controlled liberalization - one in politics, the other in economics. On the political front, the President, Maj. Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, who was wounded in the Biafra War, announced plans last summer for a phased return to civilian rule by 1992. Determined to create ''a new political generation,'' the gregarious army general moved in September to ban virtually all former politicians from running for office. ''The basic idea is that Nigeria starts with a clean slate,'' said Ray Ekpu, the editor in chief of Newswatch, an independent weekly. The blanket ban met with little outcry from Nigerians. Widespread corruption marred two earlier experiences with civilian rule. A voter registration campaign in recent weeks met with so little interest that state governments threatened to withhold the salaries of civil servants who did not register. ''People still nurse the fear that politicians with their sugar-coated tongues will soon abandon them once voted into power,'' Jimoh Ojedele, a civil servant from Ibadan, said of the low turnout. The next events on the President's political calendar are local elections, which are to be held Dec. 12 on a non-party basis. These elections are to be followed by a constitutional convention, the formation of two political parties, state elections, a national census and a presidential election in 1992. ''It's going to be a rough five years for Babangida to get through,'' a senior Western diplomat here said. Some Nigerians, like Ola Balogun, a film maker, believe that Western-style democracy will not take root in an African society like Nigeria's. ''You are going to have the shadow, but not the substance,'' said Mr. Balogun, who resigned last spring from a board advising the President on Nigeria's political future. ''I think we have to fail a third time before we try something really different.'' Instead of Western-style political parties, Mr. Balogun suggested forming a parliament composed of representatives of groups that traditionally commanded respect in Africa - clans and professional guilds. Just How Many People Live in the Country? A major obstacle to creating a Western-style democracy here is expected to be the carrying out of a national census. Most estimates put the population at 105 million, but no one knows for sure. The last accepted census was in 1963. Two others were canceled because of charges of fraud. Counting heads bears directly on what may become the explosive issue in Nigeria in the late 1980's - religion. Although no one knows whether Nigeria has more Moslems or Christians, most heads of state since independence have been Moslem northerners. But recently, growing Islamic fundamentalism has strained Nigerian religious tolerance. Fundamentalist leaders have called for making Nigeria an Islamic state and for imposing sharia, or Islamic law, throughout the land. Last March, religious animosity boiled over in the north. Three mosques were desecrated and about 100 churches were burned. Stung by the destruction, Christian leaders are raising money to rebuild. ''The Christians are not going to pull out from the north,'' Anthony Olubunmi Okogie, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Lagos, vowed in an interview. ''If one hair of a Christian is plucked out, we will pluck out a Moslem hair. If care is not taken, there will be an eruption.'' Religious polarization, Nigerian commentators warn, could lead to a two-party system where one party represents the Moslem north and the other the Christian south. With the collapse of Nigeria's oil boom, the fundamentalists are believed to have increased their appeal. In early November, President Babangida threatened to silence radical religious leaders, warning, ''Religious bigotry and zealotism have not helped to provide answers to the failures of the past.'' The Facts of Life In Dollars and Cents The fate of General Babangida's political program is inextricably linked to the performance of his economic program. When he took power in a coup two years ago, Nigeria was, in the words of a recent Finance Ministry report, ''on the verge of external bankruptcy.'' Its credit sources had dried up. With the United States traditionally the largest buyer, oil has accounted for 95 percent of Nigeria's exports. But because of dropping energy prices, oil revenues fell from $25 billion in 1980 to $5.6 billion in 1986. At the same time, a million new people joined the labor pool each year. Many Nigerians and Westerners agreed that radical surgery was needed, but nationalist sentiment precluded turning to the International Monetary Fund. Instead, the Government ostentatiously rejected an I.M.F. loan, and then adopted a ''structural adjustment program'' that was far more radical that what the fund would probably have imposed. Fixed exchange rates were abolished and the value of the national currency, the naira, was allowed to float. It dropped from even parity with the dollar to the current rate of well over four to the dollar. Commodity marketing boards were abolished, allowing producer prices to rise. Production of cocoa, cotton and palm oil rebounded. ''The program is an impressive success,'' a European banker here said. As the devaluation suddenly put a true price on imported goods, middle-class Nigerians found that they could no longer afford foreign cars, shopping trips to London and university education in the United States. The next round of austerity is expected to cut deeper. Prices of gasoline, electricity, telephone service, rail travel and mail are to increase soon as Government subsidies are withdrawn. Few Nigerians deny that the present prices are low. A Nigerian pays 65 cents a minute to call London. A Briton pays $1.60 a minute to return the call. At 32 cents a gallon, gasoline here is one-tenth the price of gas in neighboring Chad. Indeed, gas stations near Nigeria's borders routinely sell three times as much as interior stations, oil industry officials say. With the cheapest jet fuel on the west coast of Africa, foreign jetliners never leave Lagos without filling up. Many Nigerians argue that bad service justifies keeping prices low. ''Lagos is roaring again,'' residents say, alluding to the noisy backyard generators that well-to-do residents fire up to cope with daily power cuts. The state power company is generating only 40 percent of capacity. Telephone service is among the worst in West Africa. Of 240,000 lines in this city of five million, 150,000 are working. Businessmen routinely resort to sending telexes or messengers to communicate across town. Although the World Bank plans to provide almost $1 billion in coming years to rehabilitate Nigerian telephone, power and water systems, the coming rate increases have prompted angry debates in the Nigeria's newspapers, among the liveliest in Africa. ''Nigeria's public utilities have a history of mind-boggling waste and inefficiency, overmanning and a corrupt bureaucracy,'' said an editorial in one daily, The Nigerian Tribune. ''In 27 years of independence, this country cannot boast reliable telephones, regular power supply, piped water.'' From the other side, another newspaper, Daily Sketch, inveighed: ''Our Structural Adjustment Program was dreamed up by foreign-based and -dominated financial institutions. Not a few Nigerians believe it is a ghastly nightmare.'' A Poor Climate For Foreign Investors A third part of the economic liberalization - foreign investment outside the oil sector - has yet to materialize. ''Unfortunately, no significant private investment, Nigerian or foreign, is yet in sight,'' Richard L. Kramer, the local director of Arthur Andersen & Company, said at a recent symposium in Lagos. ''The present Government inherited a negative foreign investment climate, which caused almost total lack of foreign investment during the entire past decade.'' According to the World Bank, Africa has the lowest rate of foreign investment of any area in the world. With its huge internal market, Nigeria should be magnet for foreign investment. But businessmen complain of a climate that scares away investors: a 50 percent limit on repatriation of profits, requirements of up to 80 percent Nigerian participation, a hostile and slow-moving bureaucracy, and poor utility service. ''You can talk to top Nigerian officials today who still think that Nigeria is an attractive place. They have no idea what it takes to bring in foreign investment,'' said an American businessman with several years' experience here. ''They have a center-of-the-universe mentality, but 100 million poor people is not a great market.'' Kalu I. Kalu, Nigeria's American-trained Planning Minister, said in an interview that the Government intended ''to create a climate conducive to foreign investment.'' But he added, ''There is always that scare: If we open up, we are going to be dominated by foreign capital.'' A 'Jerusalem' For Diaspora Blacks As Nigeria seeks to pull out of six years of unbroken economic decline, Nigerians are trying to resolve a basic psychological conflict - between the need to mesh smoothly with the rest of the world and their pride as the home to one out of five blacks in the world. Playing to Nigerians' self-image as the world's future black superpower, Bolaji Akinyemi, Nigeria's Foreign Minister, urged his countrymen earlier this year to develop a ''black bomb.'' ''Nigeria has a sacred responsibility to challenge the racial monopoly of nuclear weapons,'' he said. Since then, talk of developing a nuclear weapon has died down. Mr. Akinyemi recently relaxed in his official residence and outlined his view of Nigeria in the world. ''Some of us dream of Nigeria being to blacks in the diaspora what Jerusalem is to Jews in the diaspora,'' he said. He noted that Nigerian ambassadors - often the only representatives of black Africa in many world capitals -are instructed to reserve a third of their guest lists to ''blacks in the diaspora.'' ''We are acutely aware that if we make it in this country, it will shine on the image of the international black community,'' he said. ''If we fail, we will have dented very badly the image of the international black community.''

COUNTRY: CONGO, THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE (96%); CENTRAL AFRICA (79%); UNITED STATES (79%); AFRICA (79%);
TEXT: A drop of sweat slipped onto his brow, perhaps from the heat, perhaps from nervousness, as Nakambo explained how lucky he was to find a job as a private school teacher that pays $10 a week. ''If I were still teaching at a public school, I would be earning just three dollars a week,'' he said, leaning forward in an ocher-colored armchair in his small cinder-block house in the Cite district of Kinshasa, the capital. Ten dollars a week pays for no more than his rent and the two staples in his family's diet: corn and cassava. Yet Nakambo seems better off than most of the 35 million people in this huge Central African nation. At least he can sometimes purchase extras with whatever he earns teaching French to the children of diplomats. With Africa's largest expanse of forest, 13 percent of the world's hydroelectric capacity and huge mineral deposits, Zaire has immense potential. It also has a reputation as one of the world's most egregious examples of economic mismanagement. Formerly the Belgian Congo, Zaire was self-sufficient agriculturally when it became independent in 1960. It now imports over one-fourth its food. Per capita income in Zaire, which is the size of the United States east of the Mississippi, is just $180 a year, 10 percent of the 1960 level and the eighth lowest in the world. In parts of Kinshasa, the infant mortality rate is 20 percent. More than one-third of the nation's children die before the age of five. Economists, diplomats and Western businessmen ascribe these woes to a long list of factors: rampant corruption in the Government of President Mobutu Sese Seko, estimated by the State Department to be worth $5 billion himself; a failure to maintain roads and basic services; extravagant spending on grandiose projects; wide-scale capital flight by the nation's rich, and such external factors as low commodity prices and high interest rates. While President Mobutu, who seized power in 1965, gets high marks for having woven together a nation out of 200 often-feuding tribes, his economic leadership receives far lower grades. According to the World Bank, Zaire's per capita income fell by 3.9 percent a year from 1973 to 1985. Only war-torn Nicaragua did worse. A Society Mismanaged, Repressed and Corrupted ''The political repression is nothing compared with the economic incompetence,'' one Western business executive said. But many economists and Western diplomats note that because Zaire is a repressive, one-party state, Government leaders from the President on down have felt little pressure to improve the situation. Indeed, they enrich themselves from it. Some academic studies have found that only 40 percent of Government funds go to the projects for which they are targeted. Some business executives say 10 percent is a better estimate, with Government officials pocketing the rest. Corruption is so endemic that postal workers often refuse to deliver mail unless they receive a monthly bribe, while phone company employees have been known to disconnect customers' phones unless they receive their ''metabeesh.'' Zairian generals frequently keep their subordinates' pay, and as a result some soldiers shake down private citizens to avoid going hungry. Relatives of Government officials are said to be heavily involved in diamond and ivory smuggling. ''The corruption pattern starts at the very summit of the system,'' said Crawford Young, a University of Wisconsin professor and co-author of ''The Rise and Decline of the Zairian State.'' ''The extent of Zaire's corruption may not be unique, but it is a leading practitioner of the art.'' President Mobutu, whose father was a cook and whose mother was a hotel maid, has 11 homes in Zaire and reportedly owns a 16th-century castle in Spain, a 32-room palace in Switzerland, luxurious residences in Paris and on the French Riviera, and lavish homes in Belgium and the Ivory Coast. He often sends military planes to South Africa to pick up exotic plants and to South America to pick up sheep for his palace in Gbadolite, which has been dubbed ''Versailles in the jungle.'' When confronted with accusations of corruption, the 57-year-old Mr. Mobutu says he is a victim of disinformation and adds that the United States and other countries have corruption, too. ''Everyone is sitting here watching this country deteriorate rapidly,'' said one Western diplomat. ''The thing that needs to be pressed is corruption; but if you press too hard, then you start to destabilize things, and the Big Man doesn't want that.'' Mr. Mobutu has repeatedly blamed civil strife and such external factors as weak commodity prices for the the country's falling standard of living. Declining copper and coffee prices did, in fact, take a serious toll. So did the high interest rates of recent years, which significantly increased Zaire's payments on its now $7 billion foreign debt. Pain Without Gain: A Fling With the I.M.F. The economic situation and debt burden grew so serious that Zaire rescheduled its debt numerous times and repeatedly invited the International Monetary Fund to help manage its economy. In 1983, working with the I.M.F., Zaire slashed its budget deficit, brought down its inflation rate to 20 percent from 100 percent and devalued its currency. Zaire won praise for trying to put its economic house in order. But the measures could not bring instant success. Although price controls on farm goods were lifted to encourage production, for example, a lack of passable roads to ship their goods to market made it unwise for many farmers to plant larger crops. Other measures exacted a heavy toll. The Government laid off 40,000 teachers, slashing education spending to 8 percent of the budget from 24 percent. Wage increases for civil servants trailed far behind inflation, pushing them to seek bribes. ''There are the very rich and the very poor, and austerity plans certainly make things worse for the poor,'' said one banker. In late 1986, Zaire renounced its austerity program, asserting that the $500 million it repaid each year was too painful and was causing a net outflow of funds. Within months, the budget deficit skyrocketed and inflation was back to 100 percent. This decimated purchasing power: the currency, called the zaire, traded at 16 cents in 1983 but is worth a little more than half a cent today. The nation's rich deposited their money in European banks to prevent the emaciation of their holdings. As a result, domestic investment plummeted. Foreign investors were frightened off by inflation and the fact that they pay too high a share of taxes because Zairian businesses often bribe their way out of paying. After coming under heavy criticism from the West, Zaire agreed again last spring to follow an I.M.F. program, but only after winning more favorable repayment terms. Zairian officials and executives complain, however, that since they are plagued by low commodity prices their nation cannot regain economic momentum without substantial debt forgiveness. Today, whatever optimism economists and diplomats felt in 1985 has given way to a deep pessimism that it will take years before Zaire can creep meaningfully forward. There is one bright spot, in the view of many diplomats and foreign bankers: President Mobutu has named a respected economist, Sambwa Pida Mbagui, former head of the Bank of Zaire, to be Prime Minister. Many diplomats say President Mobutu, who often changes prime ministers every six months, has never had a man of such ability as prime minister. Nevertheless, one Western businessman, echoing the views of many others, said: ''If Sambwa really institutes reforms, he will step on so many toes that the high-level jackals will tear out his hide and he'll go down, too.'' An Economy Shorn Of Expertise Many of Zaire's economic woes began in 1973 when Mr. Mobutu launched ''Zairianization,'' under which European-owned businesses were seized and given to Zairians for token compensation. Many of the businesses went to the President's family and cronies, and within two years, Zaire's economy had shrunk by 15 percent. The new owners often had no idea how to manage their holdings. When President Mobutu was forced in 1975 to invite the Europeans back to run the businesses, there was often not much left to run. Another major cause of Zaire's debt burden was President Mobutu's ''edifice complex.'' In downtown Kinshasa, he built a steel-and-glass skyscraper, dubbed the World Trade Center, much of which remains empty. He ordered construction of the $250 million Maluku steel mill, even though Zaire has little iron ore. The mill closed soon after it opened when Zairian officials discovered that they could import steel for half the cost of producing it. The biggest project was a power line running 1,000 miles from the Inga Dam east to the vital Shaba region, whose copper and cobalt produce 60 percent of Zaire's export earnings. The power project was supposed to cost $200 million, but its final price tag, inflated by graft, approached $1 billion. The line was built even though many advisers said it would have cost less than $70 million to erect a new dam in Shaba, but Mr. Mobutu wanted the line so he could cut off all power to often-rebellious Shaba, once called Katanga, if it were to cause trouble again. ''The main obstacle to development is the state,'' said one Zairian political scientist. ''As long as we don't have democracy, we can't control investment projects like the Inga-Shaba line because there is no one to stop the Government from doing foolish things.'' Development experts say Zaire would have been far wiser to spend money to maintain the roads and promote agriculture. In that way it might have been able to remain self-sufficient in food and to reduce its heavy dependence on mining. Road maintenance has been so abysmal that the 1,100-mile drive from Zaire's Atlantic coast to its eastern border, which once took two days, now takes three weeks and is often impossible during the rainy season. ''Transportation is a very, very difficult problem,'' said Dennis Chandler, director of the United States Agency for International Development office in Zaire. ''There's not a whole lot of priority put on maintenance, and that's a weak link in a country this size.'' Sugar-Free Existence: The 'I-Get-By' Life When the teacher Nakambo was asked how he could pay for electricity and clothes, he responded: ''Je me debrouille.'' Probably the most popular phrase in French-speaking Zaire, it means, ''I get by, I manage, I improvise.'' In this nation of debrouillards, getting by means forgoing any number of niceties. If Nakambo could afford it, he would pay the 12 cents to take a bus to work, but instead he walks the four miles each way. Before the latest spurt in inflation, breakfast consisted of bread and sugared tea. ''Sugar we no longer buy. It's too much of a luxury,'' said Nakambo, who did not want his full name disclosed. His house differs little from tens of thousands of others in Kinshasa's endless Cite district: some thrown-together cinder block walls, a sheet of corrugated metal above, a few plaster partitions within. They create a dark, modest living space cluttered with a 20-year-old refrigerator, an old sewing machine, several chairs and a sofa. The eight-by-ten-foot windowless kitchen doubles as a bedroom for his five children. Nakambo's wife, Malaika, occasionally uses the sewing machine to make children's dolls in richly-colored African wraps, which she tries to sell to foreigners. She also used to sell ices to schoolchildren, putting sugared water into long, thin plastic sacks and freezing them. But she can no longer afford sugar and the refrigerator needs a new motor, which she says would cost about $100. While his family scrapes by, Nakambo's biggest fear is of serious illness. A few months ago, a cousin had to have her appendix removed. The operation and hospital stay cost $100, equal to three months' income for many Kinshasans. ''You have to pay off the guard just to be allowed into the hospital,'' Nakambo said. ''Then you have to pay off the nurses to make sure you're looked after. They have to survive too.''

COUNTRY: AFRICA (99%); KENYA (92%); UNITED STATES (79%);
TEXT: Post reporter Blaine Harden, writing from Nairobi last Saturday, said that Africa must share the blame for its own poor economic performance. Harden's analysis refers to the "growing clamor over culpability in Africa's decline," and implies that the industrial nations should not be so ready to accept responsibility. He points out that government interference, inefficiency and corruption in Africa have discouraged foreign investors -- and reduced the very flow of resources the Africans claim is their due. Some of the clamor Harden refers to took place recently in New York, where the United Nations has been reviewing an international recovery effort designed to remedy the deteriorating economic situation in Africa. According to the Africans and the United Nations, things have gotten worse in the past two years, not better, because the industrial countries have failed to live up to their promises of more financial assistance to the African nations. The Africans maintain that they have performed on their side of the deal with the donor countries -- a deal made back in 1986 at a special session of the U.N. General Assembly -- by undertaking dangerous economic reforms. Conditions imposed by the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank closed down inefficient government-run agricultural organizations and monopoly businesses and eliminated subsidies. Many Africans have lost their jobs as a result. Consumer prices have risen, especially in the politically volatile cities, where, in several countries, riots have broken out. Africans complain that the donor and creditor nations promised to find relief for Africa's foreign debt burden, but it continues to grow to the point where, in many cases, debt service payments exceed foreign assistance. And net resource flows from the industrial nations to Africa have actually declined since 1985, although they were slightly up last year. Thus, in spite of reform, Africa's per capita gross domestic product continues to fall. Part of the original 1986 understanding was that the Africans would not insist on bringing global debt relief plans and commodity pricing schemes into the recovery program, but would instead undertake reforms in return for a best-efforts promise by the industrial countries to increase foreign aid and deal effectively with debt on a case-by-case basis. Some Africans now want to go back to their demand for a global debt solution and a better deal on their commodity exports. In addition, many Africans want to do away with the strict conditions applied by the IMF and the World Bank, on the grounds that these donor-imposed economic reforms have unacceptable political consequences. Are the Africans right? Did we renege on our promises? Or are the Africans themselves as much to blame? The truth is that we did what we said we would do -- the best we could. It just hasn't been good enough. So, too, the Africans did what they said they would do -- engage in economic reform. It just hasn't worked as well as we all hoped it would. The fact is that we have slightly increased net resource flows to the continent, and a series of debt relief measures has been undertaken, ranging from the Baker plans, through the expanded lending by the Bank and the Fund to the proposals at the Toronto Summit. There is movement on the debt front, and the Africans should be pleased with the general direction, if not with the immediate results. Rhetoric aside, there does seem to be a building consensus on the kinds of next steps that both Africans and their industrial partners should take. Both agree that significantly more resources for economic growth must be liberated from the debt trap; after the U.S. election, progress might be made on this front. Both agree that concessional assistance should increase; the World Bank and Japan are the most likely sources. And no one will quarrel with the proposition that there is much the Africans themselves can do to improve the investment climate. More importantly, the beginnings of a consensus on conditionality and on the nature of economic reform seems to be in the making. Many believe that some of the economic reforms have tried to go too far too fast. We need to get back to basics in Africa -- more emphasis on fiscal integrity, mobilization of African resources for development, agricultural reform and -- to buffer political repercussions and address urgent social needs -- more spending on health, education and employment programs. These are the right directions. Let's stop blaming each other for less-than-perfect performance and get on with the economic recovery of Africa. The writer is a former deputy assistant secretary of state for African affairs.

COUNTRY: NIGERIA (93%); BRAZIL (79%); GERMANY (55%);
TEXT: Even the winners have lost. Fifteen years after the explosion of oil prices in 1973, the price of petroleum in real terms is not a lot higher than it was just before. But the damage wreaked is far from over. Several countries which thought they had, by divine indulgence, become rich forever are still suffering from the binge. Others are falling ever more hopelessly into debt. Piecemeal efforts have been made to patch the system enough to keep goods and services flowing, but there is still no overall scheme for a reasonably expanding balance to meet the world's needs. Bumbling through has been possible because those responsible did learn something from the Depression about the wages of economic war. The lesson remaining to be learned is that abrupt upheaval with attempts to establish a ''new world economic order'' winds up hurting all. There is no longer any substitute for deliberate cooperation among the world's nations, in economic as well as in security, political and environmental affairs. Helmut Schmidt, the former West German chancellor, startled African officials meeting in Nigeria recently when he said never again could they expect the torrents of capital that poured out of the industrial world in the 1970's. They were created by the sudden shift in terms of trade, flooding oil producers with money turned over to Western banks for investment, wasted, or to a lesser extent used for their own development. That in turn produced the vast third-world debt crisis, which also afflicts some oil producers now, Mexico and Nigeria among them. Top Nigerian economic officials say ruefully that, after all, their country would have been better off if they had never struck it so rich on oil. ''It is like the man who wins a lottery and builds a castle,'' said one. ''He can't maintain it, and then has to borrow or move out.'' Expectations destroy prudence, too-easy money promotes profligacy and corruption, and there is no chance to win again. What remains is ''structural readjustment,'' the most ominous phrase in the third world now. It is International Monetary Fund jargon for the imposed austerity that is undermining the fabric of third world societies as they try to recover and reorganize production. Brazil's fragile democracy is an example of the strain that may be turning into too much to bear. The collapse of commodity prices as a consequence of the industrial world's painful efforts to deal with inflation and then recession after the oil crisis will probably never be turned around. Trade patterns were changed. New materials have been developed. The third industrial revolution has cut dependence on the traditional raw materials that provided livelihood and hopes for development in the nonindustrial world. The lucky ones have been the ''newly industrialized countries,'' which were able to make the best of cheap labor, determined management, with no illusions of either massive aid or sudden unearned wealth while markets were wide open and consumer appetites inflated. Those coming later aren't likely to find the same advantageous conditions. The U.S. imagines it has got over the hump, but it is living on borrowed money. Western Europe knows it has not yet succeeded. Its biggest problem remains unemployment, a chronic average of about 10 percent which masks much higher figures in some countries, notably Spain. Decline of some industries was inevitable, but the rate that made it so hard to absorb was aggravated by the oil crisis. The country most devastated was the one most eager to raise and raise and raise the golden stream - Iran. Other factors contributed, but it was above all the frenzy brought by so much oil money that provoked the Iranian revolution. That led to the Iran-Iraq war and the ruination of both countries. Partly because of the distortions in both rich and poor countries, partly as well because the idea was never acceptable to most people, the proposal of zero growth as a way to make the world cleaner and happier was soon dumped. The Club of Rome had some points, but not the right ones. Now the effort has to be for a new balance, but one more accommodating to the diversity of needs. New frictions are accumulating between knowledge that neglect of the environment is by no means benign and urgent yearning for continuation of the growth stimulated by petrodollars and then stunted. Energy is a key factor. Extensive studies are needed on economic costs that must be included in development plans to assure environmental protection. As the world moves on into a surprising new period, the notion of security must include economic relations.

COUNTRY: KENYA (95%); AFRICA (94%); UNITED STATES (92%); EASTERN AFRICA (92%);
TEXT: The Kenyan government has banned an aggressive business magazine that for two years broke an unwritten rule of journalism in black Africa. The Financial Review did not play it safe. It published detailed articles about alleged corruption and mismanagement at high levels in the Kenyan government. The weekly, with a circulation of about 15,000, named officials allegedly involved in illegal or unethical business practices. It focused on what the magazine's 36-year-old owner and editor, Peter Kareithi, described as "very serious flaws in national economic management." The banning order comes at a delicate time for the international image of Kenya, a poor, debt-burdened East African country whose economy is dependent on tourism and international aid. In Washington, the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Africa is marking up legislation that conditions future U.S. aid to Kenya on State Department certification that human rights -- including freedom of the press -- are respected. Proposed aid for next year totals $ 70 million. Pending low-interest loans and grants from the World Bank, International Monetary Fund and Japan, totaling more than $ 380 million, are conditioned on Kenya's following through on promises for free-market economic reform. The reputation of this closest ally of the United States in East Africa has been impugned by well-documented reports of human rights abuses, including police torture of political dissidents. A prominent human rights lawyer, Gibson Kamau Kuria, who sued the government on behalf of torture victims, was detained for nine months and had his passport taken away. Last week, Rep. David Obey (D-Wis.), who chairs a House subcommittee on appropriations, vowed to cut off all aid to Kenya if Kuria was not given back his passport. In the Financial Review case, a minister of state for internal security, who works in the office of President Daniel arap Moi, released a document here Friday that said the magazine "is declared to be a prohibited publication." The document did not explain why. The banning order came three days after Attorney General Matthew Muli criticized the magazine for "carrying mischievous stories implying that the government has taken over and nationalized" the property of Kenya's wheat millers. Muli demanded an "unconditional" retraction and apology. Editor Kareithi said, "Much as we wish to comply with your request for apology," the facts of the government's actions against the milling companies gave him "difficulties" in knowing how to do so. The story focused on sweeping new regulations published April 10 in the official Kenya Gazette. The regulations empower the government-owned grain board to commandeer private grain storage facilities "at such times as the board may direct, and at such remuneration as the board may determine." The Financial Review quoted several outraged milling company executives. One asked: "What is the world coming to? How can a parastatal [government agency] which has never been known for its efficiency and which has been a constant source of misery to farmers be given such sweeping powers as to control the nerve center of the milling industry?" Governmental protests last week against the magazine article did not dispute its facts. The minister for supplies and marketing, William ole Ntimama, said the article was "written by people who have no interest of this country at heart." The assistant minister for national guidance and political affairs, Shariff Nassir, said, "Although there was press freedom in Kenya, editors should not be left to write whatever they wanted." Kareithi bought the review for $ 37,000 in 1986. In an interview, he said, "We must have known from the beginning what was going to happen, but we were encouraged by government statements about the responsible exercise of freedom of the press. We wanted to demonstrate that it was possible for a Kenyan-owned publication to take bold steps. We wanted to encourage other Kenyans." Kareithi was picked up by police in December and interrogated for a day about stories that displeased the government. The editor said he apologized and returned to work. "The past year has literally been a nightmare for me and my staff. When we sat to discuss a cover story, most of our discussions were not about how to get information, but rather how to report it objectively and honestly without getting in trouble," Kareithi said.

COUNTRY: ANGOLA (96%); CONGO, THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE (94%); UNITED STATES (93%); CENTRAL AFRICA (92%);
TEXT: President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire met with President Bush and members of Congress today and was confronted with expressions of concern about reports of human rights abuses in his Central African country. But Mr. Mobutu was also praised as a peacemaker whose diplomacy was helping bring an end to 14 years of civil war in neighboring Angola. Mr. Mobutu defended Zaire's record on human rights, insisting that abuses had been overstated by critics. In a report this year, the State Department said that freedom of speech, freedom of the press and other rights were ''substantially circumscribed'' in Zaire. It said that ''many human rights abuses stem from endemic corruption'' among Zairian officials. After meeting with Mr. Bush at the White House, Mr. Mobutu said his country had taken steps to improve the protection of human rights. As a result, he said, the United Nations Commission on Human Rights recently removed Zaire from the list of nations subject to special monitoring. 'Incidental Mishaps' Mr. Mobutu seemed to say that any violations of human rights were ''incidental mishaps.'' In a departure ceremony outside the White House, he said, ''Zaire can be ranked among those countries which observe the rule of law, not to be confused or mistaken with any incidental mishaps that are attributable to an administration or to individuals.'' President Mobutu had tea this afternoon with members of the House Foreign Affairs Committee. A person who attended the meeting said that he ''became annoyed, angry and aggressive and delivered long-winded rebuttals'' when members of Congress criticized his record on human rights. Mr. Bush spent 2 hours 15 minutes with the Zairian leader. An Administration official said the President ''raised the issue'' of human rights and expressed concern about ''problems and deficiencies'' in Zaire's record. The President did not mention Zaire's human rights problems in his public farewell statement to Mr. Mobutu. He praised the African leader for helping to bring about a cease-fire in Angola. Leaders of the Angolan Government and rebel forces agreed to the truce last week when they met at Mr. Mobutu's country estate. The Central Intelligence Agency has worked closely with Mr. Mobutu for years. Angolan military commanders and Western diplomats in Zaire say the agency sent weapons through Zaire to the Angolan guerrilla forces led by Jonas Savimbi. Long Incumbency Mr. Mobutu has been President of Zaire since 1965 and was recorded as having won 99 percent of the vote in the last election, in 1984. Mr. Bush and Mr. Mobutu promised that there would be closer economic ties between the two nations. They exchanged paperwork for a treaty to encourage increased American investment. Zaire has been plagued by allegations of corruption and mismanagement. But Mr. Bush today praised Mr. Mobutu's recent commitment to an economic austerity program as a condition for receiving assistance from the International Monetary Fund. Richard A. Boucher, the deputy spokesman for the State Department, said that American officials regularly discussed human rights problems with Zaire. He said that ''President Mobutu has recently taken a number of steps to correct abuses'' of human rights. A study by the House Foreign Affairs Subcommittee on Africa said that Zaire was still ''very repressive.''

COUNTRY: CONGO, THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE (95%); UNITED STATES (79%); BELGIUM (55%);
TEXT: Western economists here say this country's long-moribund economy is showing promising signs of recovery. Since January, Zaire, after years of mismanagement and political instability, has devalued its currency, put a brake on Goverment spending, trimmed civil servants from its bloated bureaucracy and increased tax revenues by tightening collection procedures. These measures, and a perceived new readiness by Zairian officials to tackle their enormous problems with politically unpopular remedies, prompted the International Monetary Fund to assess Zaire's economic performance so far this year as positive and satisfactory. ''The program has been implemented effectively,'' said John Calvin Williams, the I.M.F. representive here, ''and it has already begun to bear fruit in a number of areas.'' For example, Mr. Williams said, since March Zaire's inflation rate has averaged 2.5 percent a month, down from nearly 9 percent a month in 1988. At the same time, he said, the spread between the official and the parallel market exchange has been been reduced to less than 10 percent. For the first six months of this year, revenues from taxes and export receipts have exceeded expenditures, producing a small budget surplus, the first since Zaire gained independence from Belgium nearly 30 years ago. ''In this context, it's a fairly remarkable turnaround,'' said an African diplomat here, noting Zaire's near-legendary reputation for mismanagement, corruption and wasteful spending. The optimism, however, is hedged with caveats. Western and Zairean economists and bankers say it is too early to well whether Goverment officials will stay the course. Although Zaire's economic perfomance this year has been impressive, the statistics have yet to be translated into better living conditions. Per capita income in Zaire, which is the size of the United States east of the Mississippi, is just $150 a year. Analysts here are also concerned about whether the Government will be able to restrain spending in 1990, since it has already committed itself to a number of projects, notably constructing housing and convention space for a summit meeting of French-speaking nations. Costly celebrations are also likely next year on the 30th anniversary of Zaire's independence, the 25th anniversary of the governing party's founding and President Mobutu Seso Seko's 60th birthday. In the early 1980's, Zaire's economy effectively collapsed. The causes were diverse: a slump in the price of copper, agricultural neglect and, by many accounts, seemingly endemic corruption. After some hesitation, Mr. Mobutu threw in his lot with fundamental economic changes prescribed by the international monetary fund and carried out the program with dictatorial powers. He stuck to the I.M.F.'s stringent guidelines, including a string of devaluations. The value of the zire, the nation's currency, is an eighth of what it was in 1979. ''We were the I.M.F.'s best pupil,'' Pay-Pay Wa Syagasighe, the head of Zaire's central bank, said recently. In 1986, however, Zaire abruptly abandoned the program, protesting that it had become a net exporter of capital to Europe and the United States. ''The I.M.F. programs cost us $2 billion in outflows against only $1 billion in inflows,'' President Mobutu complained in an interview last fall. Within months, however, the budget deficit skyrocketed, and inflation was back to 100 percent. Foreign investors began to flee. Last May, after several months of protracted negotiations, the Government signed a new $253 million credit agreement with the I.M.F., under which it again committed itself to an economic reform program. Analysts here say they have been especially impressed by Zairian efforts to crack down on fraud and abuse in the customs service. An economist with an international assistance agency said, ''Everyone is being made to pay customs duties and taxes now, even the previously untouchable political elite, and that has never happened before.''

COUNTRY: AFRICA (99%); UNITED STATES (95%); KENYA (93%); SUB SAHARAN AFRICA (93%); CANADA (92%); LATIN AMERICA (79%); GHANA (79%); CONGO, THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE (79%); FRANCE (78%); GERMANY (78%);
TEXT: The United States today formally agreed to forgive all economic-assistance loans to Kenya, as part of an effort to give economic relief to Africa, including some of the continent's poorest countries. The debt-relief effort, which was announced last July, is also aimed at rewarding African countries that have started to tighten their belts to improve their weak economies. The United States Ambassador here, Smith Hempstone, signed an agreement that covered $44.7 million of Kenya's total outstanding debt of $175 million. The remaining $130 million will be forgiven over the next two years, if Kenya adheres to an economic reform program reached with the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. Total of $735 Million In all, the United States has pledged to cancel debts of $735 million owed by 12 sub-Saharan African countries. The per-capita incomes in those countries range from a low of $150 in Zaire to a high of $390 in Ghana. The debt forgiveness reflects continuing concern about declines in Africa's well-being. ''Over all, Africans are almost as poor today as they were 30 years ago,'' the World Bank said in a major report in November. Of the 44 countries of black Africa, more than half are severely in debt and have structurally weak economies, the World Bank said last month in an assessment of world debt. The economies are weak because of heavy dependence on volatile commodities, like coffee and tea, for exports; rapidly growing populations, and very little investment. Many of the economies have also been buckled by official corruption. Differs From Reagan Policy The decision to forgive the United States' debt is part of a policy adopted by the Bush Administration last year to do more to help the poorest countries. The Reagan Administration had refused to go along with some other Western nations, notably Britain, France, Canada and West Germany, which began canceling the official debts of sub-Saharan countries after an economic summit meeting in Toronto in 1988. The Reagan Administration chose instead to give the countries more time to pay. By the end of 1988, the foreign debt of sub-Saharan Africa was about $140 billion, the World Bank reported. In comparison with Latin America's debt of hundreds of millions of dollars, the sub-Saharan debt is relatively small. But unlike the Latin debt, much of which is owed to commercial banks, Africa's is mostly owed to governments and multilateral agencies like the World Bank. Economists have pointed out that the annual cost of servicing Africa's debt is about $12 billion. As poor as it is, Africa continues to be a net exporter of resources, paying more in debt service than the total of what it receives in foreign aid and earns from commodity exports, according to the United Nations Economic Commission for Africa. Don Harrison, deputy chief of the Planning Analysis and Research Division at the United States Agency for International Development, said that servicing the debt consumed much of the foreign exchange needed to purchase goods and services and supply investment capital for economic growth and development. Kenya Among the Better Off Of the 12 countries where Washington is forgiving its loans, Kenya is one of the most prosperous, with a per-capita income of $330. But even so, Western donors including the United States have expressed concern at the Kenyan Government's growing reliance on foreign aid to pay for spending and budget deficits. The donors have also informed the Kenyans that the Government is seeking too many large-scale commercial loans from abroad for items like aircraft for the national airline and a 60-story office tower. The United States is canceling its economic loans for countries including Nigeria, Ghana, Ivory Coast, Cameroon, Malawi and Madagascar. Some of the loans, dating back 25 years, when Kenya obtained independence from Britain, were granted largely for spending on public works.

COUNTRY: FRANCE (99%); AFRICA (98%); SUB SAHARAN AFRICA (94%); COTE D'IVOIRE (93%); GABON (92%); CENTRAL AFRICAN REPUBLIC (79%); EUROPE (79%); UNITED STATES (79%); WESTERN AFRICA (79%); CONGO, THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE (79%); GERMANY (79%); SENEGAL (79%); NIGER (79%); ASIA (79%); CHAD (79%); EASTERN EUROPE (53%);
TEXT: France is sending signals that it intends to reduce its role in its former possessions in sub-Saharan Africa and that it expects governments in those countries to move toward greater democracy and respect for human rights. Three decades after granting formal independence to its sub-Saharan African empire, France is trying to shed its image as an all-knowing, often generous and sometimes interfering Big Brother in favor of more distant and traditional diplomatic relations, according to officials and analysts. "Now France is fundamentally getting rid of the colonies in favor of normal state-to-state relations," said a French official here. "We still have historic responsibilities here and thus seek no sharp break." In keeping with this new image, France was careful to appear no more than a concerned bystander when demonstrations and strikes recently swept through former colonies as economically, politically and geographically diverse as Gabon, Niger, Senegal and Ivory Coast. Although French troops still are stationed on African soil, they have been non-interventionist, unlike when they restored overthrown President Leon M'Ba in Gabon in 1964, deposed Emperor Bokassa in the Central African Republic in 1979 or helped stop foreign invasions of Chad and Zaire, the analysts said. Government corruption, human rights violations and economic mismanagement in its former colonies have helped weaken the close links that France maintained in these countries to boost its image as a world power and ensure the survival of French as an internationally important language. The policy, which critics called neo-colonialist, appears to have outlived its usefulness for the French, who long justified their hands-on approach by contrasting the benefits of convertible currency and law and order backed by French army garrisons to the economic disorder and violence elsewhere in Africa. Events in Eastern Europe and the prospect of German unification provided an additional rationale for shifting France's limited resources nearer to home -- or to Asia with its promise of better return on investment. French Prime Minister Michel Rocard has said that "France has no moral right nor political intention to drop Africa," and other French officials have echoed his statement. They also have hinted that greater democracy -- and greater respect for law -- are overdue in France's former possessions in Africa. With African agricultural exports sagging and French business retrenching, leaders of these countries have few illusions about Paris's assurances that private investment will take the place of what was once the world's highest per capita aid program. That program brought with it tens of thousands of French officials, businessmen and technicians. With the passing of the Cold War, African leaders are less able to invoke China, Cuba, the Soviet Union or the United States as competitors to France for influence in Africa. In a recent op-ed article in the Paris newspaper Le Monde, a French African specialist criticized French officials for keeping silent about well-documented abuses in the former colonies "for fear of endangering delicate bilateral relations." He argued that French aid "had reached the ultimate point of perversion" by "maintaining crazy regimes and parasitical structures" that have become "the surest obstacles to development." France also has learned the usefulness of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. French officials have discovered that IMF demands for austerity measures can be conveniently invoked to refuse the appeals from African leaders for more funds that for three decades often were answered in Paris.

COUNTRY: AFRICA (98%); KENYA (94%); ZAMBIA (94%); ETHIOPIA (92%); COTE D'IVOIRE (92%); EUROPE (79%); UGANDA (79%); GABON (79%); ZIMBABWE (79%); EASTERN EUROPE (57%);
TEXT: When thousands of Zambians rushed onto the streets of Lusaka last month to celebrate what they thought was a successful overthrow of their longtime President, Kenneth D. Kaunda, they were expressing what citizens in many parts of Africa have been saying more and more: Africa's original big men have been around too long. Corruption, mismanagement and authoritarian rule appear to be catching up with the aging leaders as news spreads about liberalization in Eastern Europe and economic conditions get palpably worse at home. At the Organization of African Unity's annual meeting in Addis Ababa last week, there were polite noises about the need for democracy in Africa, where only about half a dozen countries would pass even an undemanding democracy test. The new chairman of the 51-nation group, President Yoweri Museveni of Uganda, was so bold as to state that democracy was essential for the running of a modern state. But the 46-year-old Mr. Museveni, who has held power only four years and is an unusually engaging performer on the African stage, provides a rare counterpoint to his aging colleagues, many of whom stayed away from the gathering to deal with political troubles at home. The challenges to the old guard stem largely from uniformly depressing economic conditions that affect all segments of society - the young, who make up most of the fast-growing populations, and the middle-aged and elderly, who are weary of stale polemics. In the 1980's, per capita income in most of Africa fell drastically. Expenditures on health, housing and education dropped as governments spent large amounts on armies and condoned corruption in state-run enterprises, and as heavy-handed leadership allowed for little development of a new generation to take over. Riots over food prices in Zambia, which preceded the failed coup attempt, were not the only ones in Africa this year. There have been similar signs of unrest in the Ivory Coast and Gabon. In some countries, particuarly Kenya, where the leaders of the unofficial opposition and nine supporters were arrested July 4 and 5 and are still in detention, calls for multiparty democracy have become a rallying cry to open the political process. Closed Parties In many African one-party states, the party is a closed society that comes to power in rigged elections. Those who fear multiparty states on the grounds that they foster tribalism say Mr. Kaunda and President Daniel arap Moi of Kenya could satisfy the demands for greater political participation by opening up the one party. But so far there have been few signs of that. In Mr. Kaunda's case it has been 26 years since he took charge at the birth of Zambia, formerly Northern Rhodesia. He has ruled with a fatherly benevolence that brooks little criticism, using the United National Independent Party as his instrument. Over the northern border in Zaire, Mr. Kaunda's presidential peer is Mobutu Sese Seko, installed in 1965, five years after independence from Belgium. In May, Mr. Mobutu's Government responded to protests at a university in Lubumbashi by sending troops to the campus. Belgian officials in Brussels say the troops turned off dormitory lights and knocked door to door, killing in cold blood more than 50 students. While Mr. Mobutu has promised that three new political parties will be allowed to operate in Zaire, most diplomats and Zaireans have little illusion that the political spectrum will be meaningfully broadened. East of Zambia, the octogenarian Hastings Kamuzu Banda has presided with unbridled authoritarianism over Malawi, formerly British Nyasaland, since independence in 1964. So far, there has been no widely reported unrest in Malawi - in part, diplomats believe, because the population lives in dread of the police. In the Ivory Coast, President Felix Houphouet-Boigny, who has held power since 1960 and was confronted with street riots earlier this year, has indicated that he will name a successor and step down, but his statements have been vague. In May, President Omar Bongo of Gabon, who has governed for 23 years but has now decided to allow political parties to form, suffered the indignity of seeing 1,000 French troops sent to his country to protect French residents in the wake of riots. The coup attempt in Zambia left more uncertainties, rather than fewer, about that country's future. Mr. Kaunda's personal reputation is not in complete tatters - ''He has kept us in peace for a long time,'' said a Zambian teacher - but urban workers say they cannot afford the doubling of the price of the basic foodstuff, corn meal, that Mr. Kaunda recently annnounced. For many years, Mr. Kaunda has subsidized food prices with revenues from copper, but copper prices have fallen. Zambia's international debt has ballooned to more than $7 billion, reported to be the highest per capita in the world. Mr. Kaunda broke with the International Monetary Fund four years ago, but now has finally swallowed its hard economic adjustment programs, which include the rise in food prices. Mr. Kaunda has agreed to hold a referendum on Oct. 17 on whether to allow more than one party, but diplomats say it is open to question how fair the vote will be. Mr. Kaunda has called those who favor a multiparty system ''wild dogs'' and has warned that more political parties would lead to ''tribalism.'' Zambians, from businessmen to workers, say they can't be sure what will happen next.
