The army's top ranks have been well looked after by Mr. Kaunda, but there are reports of dissatisfaction with pay by junior officers and enlisted men. And if Mr. Kaunda sticks to the I.M.F. program, a Western diplomat said, how long city people will remain quiet is anybody's guess.

COUNTRY: KENYA (97%); UNITED KINGDOM (93%); UNITED STATES (92%); AFRICA (92%); LIBERIA (79%); NIGERIA (79%);
TEXT: Allegations by foreign minister Robert Ouko of high-level corruption in the Kenyan government probably were a key factor in his death last year, a retired Scotland Yard investigator testified today. John Troon, head of a special detachment of British detectives recruited by President Daniel arap Moi to pursue the case, charged that he was inhibited from following this line of inquiry by top Kenyan government officials. He said they declined to grant him interviews and abruptly declared his investigation finished. Troon's report was turned over to the Moi government last year but was never made public. Ouko, a widely respected diplomat, was killed in February 1990. His partially burned body was found, with a single bullet wound in the head, not far from his home in western Kenya. Troon's testimony at a judicial inquiry today in the western city of Kisumu comes as the Kenyan government is reeling from recent charges of kickbacks, bribery and theft of government funds under Moi's rule. A recent report of the International Monetary Fund ranks Kenya fourth among all African nations -- behind Liberia, Nigeria and South Africa -- in terms of capital flight. According to official figures, Kenyans hold $ 2.62 billion in overseas accounts. Diplomats here say this sum -- which has grown rapidly over the past decade, sapping funds needed for development -- reflects not only growing investor uncertainty over Kenya's future, but also an exceptional degree of theft and malfeasance in the government. Kenya, long recognized as one of Africa's most stable nations and a comparative haven for foreign investment, is today suffering a serious crisis of confidence, internally and internationally. Denmark, once one of Kenya's biggest donors, recently announced a freeze on all aid, citing corruption. The U.S. government has halved its aid package to $ 26 million this year. Ouko's killing -- and the government's now nearly 300-day-old official inquiry into it -- continues to spur political discontent. It triggered bloody riots among Ouko's Luo tribe in western Kenya, which in turn helped fuel movements pressing for democracy and accountability in Moi's single-party state. Troon, who retired from Scotland Yard last year, said he believes the killing may have been linked to a sharp disagreement between Ouko and another cabinet member during a visit to Washington in February 1990, about a week before the murder. Earlier witnesses have testified that Ouko engaged in a shouting match with former energy minister Nicholas Biwott, the focus of many accusations of official corruption here. During that visit, Moi met with State Department officials to seek ways to increase investment and foreign aid. The officials reportedly told the Kenyans that the quickest way to do this would be to crack down on corruption to create a healthier climate for business here. Last week, several letters from international aid groups charging corruption among Kenyan leaders were read at the hearings. These letters were solicited by Ouko in early 1990 when, according to witnesses, the foreign minister was preparing a report for Moi on corruption. The letters detailed allegations that top Kenyan officials, most notably Biwott, a confidant of Moi, routinely demanded 10 percent kickbacks for most public projects here. The letters portrayed a government that operated on an overriding principle of personal greed, with Biwott accused of holding hundreds of millions of dollars in overseas accounts. The letter writers alleged that growing numbers of foreign investors were refusing to do business here as long as Kenya's top officials remain in power. Biwott has made no response. The disclosure of the documents came on the heals of published accounts about a report prepared by the U.S. Embassy saying the top layer of the Kenyan government is pervaded by a get-rich-quick philosophy.

COUNTRY: KENYA (96%); UNITED KINGDOM (93%); AFRICA (79%); LIBERIA (79%); NIGERIA
TEXT: When Kenya's Foreign Minister, Robert Ouko, was found dead 20 months ago, an official inquiry suggested that he had somehow shot and burned himself to death in the bush country. A long-suppressed report by a retired Scotland Yard detective now asserts, far more credibly, that Mr. Ouko was killed because he knew too much about high-level corruption. The report is a timely warning to Western governments too tolerant of Kenya's one-party autocracy. Before his death, the Foreign Minister was compiling testimony alleging that close associates of President Daniel arap Moi routinely sought 10 percent kickbacks on public projects. The figure seems conservative given a report by the International Monetary Fund asserting that overseas accounts held by Kenyans have soared to $2.6 billion, a suspicious capital flight exceeded in Africa only by Liberia, Nigeria and South Africa. Small wonder that Mr. Moi's Government has for six months suppressed the findings on Mr. Ouko's death. Small wonder as well that most Western countries have cut back aid to Kenya, which Mr. Moi has ruled high-handedly since 1978. He has manipulated ethnic rivalries, stifled the press and spurned demands for multiparty elections. Mr. Moi's words are blunt, and zoological. "I call on all Kenyans to sing like parrots," was his counsel a few years ago. Recently he threatened to "crush" his political opponents "like rats." The report on Mr. Ouko's death may finally nudge indulgent donor states, especially Britain, that have found a redeeming "stability" in Mr. Moi's misrule. In present circumstances, lavishing foreign aid on Kenya, to vary Mr. Moi's language, would be like pumping money into a rathole.

COUNTRY: CONGO, THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE (95%); UNITED STATES (93%); EUROPE (92%); CENTRAL AFRICA (92%);
TEXT: The newest Prime Minister of this Central African country said today that the Zairian economy faced imminent bankruptcy and that the situation was not likely to improve until President Mobutu Sese Seko was removed from office. On the eve of a visit to the United States and several European capitals, the Prime Minister, Nguza Karl-i-Bond, who was appointed Prime Minister by General Mobutu two weeks ago, also said he would ask Western donors, including the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, to virtually take over the management of Zaire's central bank. Given the widespread corruption and mismanagement in the country, he said, leaders, including himself, were incapable of preventing the economy's spinning out of control. "I'm not a fool, the system is such that I cannot control all these things from this desk," Mr. Nguza said during an hourlong interview in his office here. Thus, he said he would call on Western donors to send financial experts to work with Zairians and help bring some order to this impoverished and debt-burdened nation. Steady Loss of Aid The move would be the first in what could be a lengthy diplomatic process that Zairian officials hope will bring this country renewed respectability among international donors. The United States cut off all development aid to Zaire in June because it was more than a year in arrears on debt payments. And last week, Zaire was to have been expelled from the International Monetary Fund because of its failure to pay its debts. Mr. Nguza said, however, that because of his personal intervention, officials of the fund agreed to postpone formal action until at least February, giving the Prime Minister time to draft an economic rehabilitation program. Mr. Nguza also said the wave of street disorders that recently erupted here could easily re-occur. The rioting and looting was led by disgruntled soldiers who had not been paid for several months. Zaire, with more than 38 million people, is facing a "stomach revolution," Mr. Nguza said, adding that unless the country receives an immediate infusion of humanitarian aid, "the stomach revolution will be fatal to the democratic process." Hunger and Democracy "My belief," he said, "is that when people are starving, they are not free. You're free only when you eat, and not in need of vital necessities. And when people are starving, you cannot bring them to understand or follow you when you're talking about democracy." Mr. Nguza's remarks came before the start today of a long-delayed conference on the nation's political future. Opposition leaders have said they hope to use the forum to either force General Mobutu to resign or strip him of most presidential powers. The Prime Minister is a longtime diplomat and official in Mobutu administrations. Among other things, he has served as Foreign Minister and briefly before as Prime Minister. But under General Mobutu's skillful system of politics -- allowing no one to gain enough standing to be in a position to succeed or oust him -- he has also been condemned to death and, at another point, sentenced to life imprisonment. With this history, he has no reason for gratitude toward the President and identifies himself as an opposition Prime Minister. Even so, the strength of his statement today was surprising. He agreed that it was imperative that General Mobutu be removed from office, but he emphasized that the transition to a multiparty democracy must occur peacefully. By comparison, Mr. Nguza cited recent events in Togo, the West African country where soldiers, seeking to return to power the former military dictator, Gen. Gnassingbe Eyadema, attacked the presidential palace of the reformist civilian Government with tanks and rockets. "I wouldn't like to have to see tanks here around this office," Mr. Nguza remarked, "and have them say, 'You're not going to leave here unless you resign,' and things like that. It's not that I'm afraid, but if we can do it otherwise, why not?" Asked if he believed that President Mobutu was genuinely committed to democratic change, he prefaced his remarks by saying: "I have to be careful as Prime Minister," and then he responded, indirectly: "You have an expression in English, 'You don't teach an old dog new tricks. ' " When Mr. Nguza served as Prime Minister for eight months in 1980, he decided that he could not govern as long as President Mobutu personally controlled all major institutions. He resigned and fled to Belgium. According to news reports at the time, Mr. Nguza accused Mr. Mobutu of skimming off millions of dollars from the central bank, the nationalized Gecamines Mining Company and the Sozacom Mineral Export Company, undermining a program of economic and financial changes. While in Brussels, Mr. Nguza became the leading figure in a loose-knit coalition of opposition groups, and remained abroad until June 1985, after getting assurances that it would be safe to return. Forms Opposition Then in a move that even some of his longtime supporters still find inexplicable, he accepted an offer by General Mobutu to serve as Zaire's Ambassador to the United States. Since then, he has again broken ranks with the Zairian leader, formed an opposition party, the Federal Union of Independent Republicans, and in recent months become one of the President's harshest critics. His decision to rejoin the Mobutu Government as Prime Minister, however, has rekindled suspicions that he is essentially an opportunist, willing to lean whichever way the political winds seem most favorable. Asked how it felt being called a "traitor" by some of his former colleagues in the opposition, Mr. Nguza replied that he had nothing to apologize for, because he remained steadfastly opposed to Mobutu rule.

COUNTRY: CONGO, THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE (96%); UNITED STATES (93%); AFRICA (92%); CENTRAL AFRICA (79%); NIGERIA (79%); SUDAN (79%); SUB SAHARAN AFRICA (79%); BELGIUM (58%);
TEXT: A Madison Avenue hair stylist who calls himself Mr. Andrew says that every two weeks for the last eight years he has traveled here to cut the hair of President Mobutu Sese Seko. Taking into account Mr. Andrew's first-class air travel from New York, hotel accommodations at the luxurious Inter-Continental Hotel and whatever fee he earns, each presidential haircut is estimated to cost the citizens of Zaire at least $5,000. A few blocks away from the Inter-Continental, in a fetid, fly-infested ward of the Kinoise Clinic, Mwanda Ngimbi is slowly starving to death. Mr. Mwanda entered the hospital in May after he was robbed and shot by a bandit. He was well enough to leave the hospital in mid-June. But Mr. Mwanda, who earned about $15 a month as a taxi driver, had no money, and hospital officials are holding him under armed guard until he pays his medical bills, which now total about $450 and are mounting daily. Behind the Desperation Since the hospital is not feeding Mr. Mwanda and he has no money to buy food, he depends on the charity of other patients. But that is not nearly enough, and now, suffering from severe malnutrition, he is too weak even to sit up. If Mr. Mwanda is a symbol of Zaire's desperation, Mr. Andrew is a symbol of its cause: the corruption and mismanagement of the Government. While its impressive natural resources sit largely undeveloped, this sprawling Central African country of nearly 40 million people is one of the world's poorest, and getting poorer at a rate that has been gathering ominous speed since September 1991, when a paroxysm of looting and arson wiped out much of its modern industry. "The vast majority of Zaire is now back to subsistence levels," said Herman Cohen, the American Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, who came here early this month on a fact-finding mission. "And for the first time we're seeing cases of malnutrition." "It has always been serious," he added, "but now it's getting dangerous." So Rich, and Yet So Poor Mbongo Nguodja Harouna, a human rights campaigner whose group, the Voice of the Voiceless, has been trying to win the release of Mr. Mwanda and others in his predicament, said: "People have never suffered like this before.  A lot of them have simply given up hope." Called the Belgian Congo until independence in 1960, Zaire is as big as the United States east of the Mississippi. It is sub-Saharan Africa's second most populous nation, after Nigeria. It is one of the world's major producers of copper and cobalt. It has climatic and soil conditions suitable for growing a wide range of tropical crops, including cotton, rubber, coffee, palm oil and sugar. This potential has long been frittered away by corruption, brutality and random violence. But the notion persisted that if only the "bad Zairians" who surrounded and ill served Mr. Mobutu were reined, in the country would right itself. Few here dared openly blame the President himself. There was also a widespread belief among Zairians that the country was too valuable to the West for it to let the misery continue and that if only the Western powers would turn their attention to solving the crisis Zaire would become the great power it was destined to be. Those days are over. With the end of the cold war, many here have come to realize that the West, and especially the United States, has no intention of rescuing the Zairians from themselves. Repression Is His Weapon "We've supported them, yes, and we supported Mobutu," said a Western diplomat with long experience in Africa. "But those days are long over. It's a painful thing for many of them to realize, but Zaire is no longer of great strategic interest." Even without Western help, Mr. Mobutu hangs on despite a rising public clamor for his removal from the autocratic power he has exercised for 27 years. The President retains his grip through old-fashioned repression. Virtually every night, unmarked vehicles roar through Kinshasa's dusty streets, bearing grim-faced men in khaki uniforms without insignia. A recent report by the Zairian Human Rights League said these men -- known to Kinshasa residents as the "owls" -- were members of Mr. Mobutu's Special Presidential Guard, and had made numerous assaults against those perceived as political threats to the Government. "So many people have been attacked and killed by the owls that we can no longer keep track of them," said Mr. Harouna of the Voice of the Voiceless. But Mr. Mobutu's power has been eroded. He spends most of his time aboard his yacht in the Congo River, and has entered Kinshasa, Zaire's capital, only twice this year, both times briefly and without advance notice, under the cover of night and with a squadron of heavily armed guards. People say that if he were to enter Kinshasa openly and move among this city's five million citizens it is doubtful that he would get out alive, given his tenuous control over the country's security forces. New Constitution Planned Bending to public outrage, Mr. Mobutu's representatives have been meeting with opposition leaders since July 1991 in a national political conference intended to draft a new constitution and set a schedule for multiparty elections. This month the delegates began drafting a new constitution enshrining a multiparty system and elected Etienne Tschisekedi, Mr. Mobutu's most prominent opponent, as Prime Minister of a transitional government. Mr. Mobutu has recognized these changes, but balked at the delegates' symbolic move to change the country's name back to the Congo, nullifying a name change made by Mr. Mobutu in 1971 as part of his policy of ridding the country of vestiges of its colonial legacy. Critics have seized on the name Zaire as a symbol of the President's autocratic rule. The political conference has deferred the name change. It also appears to have fallen short of the opposition's main objective, namely to force Mr. Mobutu from office, or at least strip him of most of his presidential powers. "The one thing that everyone agrees on is that we're a long way from getting rid of Mobutu," an opposition leader said. "He's incredibly tenacious, and appears determined to hold onto power at any cost." Buana Kabwe, chairman of the Zaire League of Human Rights, said: "Everything else in the country may be falling apart, but nothing has changed for Mobutu. He still treats the treasury as if it's his private purse. And he couldn't care less about our suffering." Unpaid Soldiers Mutiny Mr. Mobutu's penchant for conspicuous consumption appears unabated. Among his overseas real-estate holdings, for example, are chateaus in Spain and Belgium, a town house in Paris, a villa near Monte Carlo, an estate in Switzerland, a horse ranch in Portugal and a villa in the Ivory Coast. Last September, Mr. Mobutu's rule seemed about to end. Mutinous soldiers, angered because they had not been paid, began a week of looting and violence. According to a report in July by Africa Watch, a New York-based human rights advocacy group, as the rioting spread throughout the country, it eliminated most of what remained of the modern productive sector, outside of mining. In the Kinshasa area alone, 90,000 jobs were lost, and in the course of the looting at least 240 people were killed. Today, whole sections of the country are under the control of local commanders who routinely ignore orders from Kinshasa. The rioting also led to the evacuation of virtually all expatriate workers -- about 20,000 people, mostly from France, Belgium and the United States. They included most of the country's university professors, teaching hospital staff members, and geologists in the mining industry, as well as a host of Belgian development assistance workers who provided a wide range of services to villages in the interior. Many Seek to Leave The economic collapse since the September riots has been staggering. The annual inflation rate is more than 5,000 percent, largely because the Government abandoned an economic recovery program devised by the International Monetary Fund in early 1990 and increased spending. In January 1990, the national currency traded at about 300 to the dollar; today the rate is about 650,000 to the dollar. The September rioting also prompted many Zairians to join the long lines for visas outside every Western embassy. They include many of this country's best-trained and best-educated citizens. Antoine Beltchira Kalubye, a neurosurgeon at the University of Kinshasa's teaching hospital here, said he knew of at least 100 physicians who had left the country in recent months, most for better paying jobs in South Africa. Senior physicians here make about $75 a month; in South Africa, they can earn about the same amount in a day. Consequently, the quality of medical services has declined, hardly reassuring patients who are already leery of the system after the wide publicity given to cases of patients held hostage for their medical bills. "It has become very bizarre," Dr. Kalubye said. "Nowadays the last place people want to come if they fall sick is the hospital." 'A Long Way to Go' George Nzongola, a Zairian and a professor of African studies at Howard University in Washington who recently returned here after living 18 years abroad, said conditions were worse now than they were before independence. "Under colonialism, the decade of the 50's was a period of prosperity in the Belgian Congo," said Mr. Nzongola, who is a delegate at the national conference. "The colonialists invested in economic and social services. So most people had access to very good schools and ate three meals a day." "One person recently told me that we've gone backward 250 years," Mr. Nzongola added, "I hope he's not right." Asked whether he expected conditions to change, even if Mr. Mobutu were suddenly to disappear from the political scene, Mr. Nzongola shrugged his shoulders. "We've got a long way to go," he said, "and I hope it's not too late." Map of Zaire. Chart: "At a Glance: Zaire" Zaire (called Congo until 1971) was under Belgian control from 1885 to June 1960. A period of instability followed independence until November 1965, when Mobutu Sese Seko seized power in a bloodless coup. He has ruled as an autocrat ever since. Although Zaire was classified by the World Bank as the world's 12th poorest country in 1990, with a per capita income of $220, it is the world's largest producer of cobalt and the second-largest producer of industrial diamonds. Exports of both commodities are believed to have fallen by as much as 50 percent in the last two years. Zaire's other important mineral product is copper, which accounts for 35 to 55 percent of the country's export earnings. Copper production has fallen by 40 percent since 1986. Inflation has sharply eroded the value of the Zairian currency. In April, all Zairian banks closed because of cash shortages. Except for the police and armed forces, most civil servants have not been paid for several months. Zaire's nearly 40 million people are divided among many tribes, with the largest being the Kongo, Kwango-Kwilu, Mongo, Luba, Bwaka and Zande. The majority speak Bantu languages, though the north is linguistically Sudanese. The lingua franca is French. Zaire is the third largest country in Africa, one-quarter the size of the United States. Its dominant geographic feature is the Congo River. With vast forests and plenty of rainfall, Zaire has huge agricultural, logging and hydroelectic potential.

COUNTRY: CONGO, THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE (96%); UNITED STATES (92%); AFRICA (92%); WESTERN AFRICA (79%); CENTRAL AFRICA (79%); NIGERIA (79%);
TEXT: In a fly-infested feeding center on the outskirts of Kinshasa, nearly 200 children gathered listlessly around a huge steaming bowl of milky gruel. This was the only meal of the day for some, and others were eating for the first time in days. There was no laughter or play. Some of the children, no more than tiny skeletons with the faces of emaciated old men, were too weak to move. Relief officials predicted that at least 10 percent of the children would soon die of hunger. Until recent months, severe malnutrition and starvation on this scale were virtually unheard of in Kinshasa, the capital of this central African country and a densely packed river port city of nearly five million people. Unparalleled Since the 1960's "We haven't seen this amount of hunger in West Africa since the Biafran war in Nigeria during the 1960's," said Wayne King, the chief officer for the United States Agency for International Development here, who has worked in Africa for 20 years. A State Department cable in March, in what it called a conservative estimate, said at least 5.2 percent of Zairians, or nearly 1.8 million people, were suffering from "acute malnutrition." The cable recommended that the United States provide emergency short-term food assistance, warning that a delay could make any aid "too little too late." In truth, the acute food problems facing Zaire appear self-inflicted, the result of nearly 30 years of Government corruption and economic ineptitude. Now they have become so severe that they are bending society with their pressure. "It's always been a struggle to live here, but things have never been this bad," said Zanga Yumbi, a local Red Cross official. In many families, she said, food is so scarce that girls are fed one day and boys the next. Some children have been abandoned to die, an extremely rare practice in a society where the extended family system, an informal network of blood ties, often embraces hundreds of people. There were always aunts, uncles or cousins willing to provide housing and food for children whose parents, for whatever reason, could no longer take care of them. But for the first time, diplomats, relief officials and missionaries said, the level of deprivation is so severe and pervasive that even close relatives are reluctant to take in ailing or needy children, and a growing number of parents have been forced to seek help beyond the traditional family connections. Parents Give Up Hope Musongi-Mpwono Munol, the director of the Kizito-Kingabwa Health Center, said nearly 60 percent of the children there had been abandoned -- left to the care of relief organizations and missionaries -- because their parents could no longer afford to feed them. "Many people simply don't have the ability to support all their children anymore, so they are making very difficult choices," said Sister Tacita Laranang, a Roman Catholic nun who works at St. Kizito's feeding center. St. Kizito is one of nearly 30 centers that Doctors Without Borders, a European relief organization, has opened in the last year. Relief organizations that have stepped in receive virtually no assistance from Zaire's troubled Government. And it is not only the children who are suffering. Mrs. Yumbi of the Red Cross said that early in May, an old and sickly woman dressed in rags had been abandoned at the doorstep of a local church. "This would have never happened even five years ago," Mrs. Yumbi said. Kinshasa's deprivation is a poverty that somehow seems a terrible mistake. The food shortages stem not from drought, which devastated food production in Ethiopia in the mid-1980's and more recently in Zimbabwe, Mozambique and other countries in southern Africa for much of the last two years. Nor do the shortages result from violent ethnic and territorial disputes, as in Somalia or the Sudan. Food and Resources Plentiful Indeed, food is relatively plentiful in Kinshasa's central market, and north of Kinshasa stretches an area with more than enough arable land to feed the country's 40 million people. Moreover, Zaire is a leading copper and cobalt producer, the world's largest supplier of industrial diamonds, rich in coffee, timber, palm oil and other agricultural exports, and it also has vast reserves of hydroelectric power. At the top of this country blessed with abundant natural resources and cursed by starvation is one of the world's richest men. Mobutu Sese Seko, the country's autocratic leader for 28 years, has a personal fortune estimated at $4 billion, say African and Western diplomats as well as numerous scholars on Zaire. "In our view, Zaire is not faced with a food shortage per se, but rather an acute food access problem," concluded a recent study by Catholic Relief Services, a group based in the United States. To be sure, chronic malnutrition has long existed in Kinshasa, but the problem has steadily worsened in recent years. The problem became a crisis with rioting in September 1991, when disgruntled soldiers seeking back pay went on a rampage, looting homes and shops and setting off a wave of violence that left dozens dead. Belgium, the former colonial ruler of Zaire, and France deployed troops to help evacuate 30,000 foreigners, mostly Europeans, and to maintain order. Rioting by Soldiers Repeated Rioting erupted again in February when soldiers discovered that the new five-million-zaire bank notes used to pay them were impossible to spend. Heavily armed soldiers seized control of the Parliament building and held several hundred lawmakers hostage, demanding that they order local merchants to accept the new bank notes. Hundreds, including the French Ambassador, were killed. Since then, the economic collapse has been staggering. Many of the foreigners held vital technical and managerial positions -- jobs that most African and Western diplomats believe that Zairians, for now, are incapable of filling. More broadly, Zairian businesses dependent on imported materials, spare parts or machines have faced sharp reductions in production and earnings and laid off tens of thousands of workers. As a result, according to figures provided by the United States Embassy here, before the 1991 riots, unemployment stood at nearly 40 percent, a figure almost unheard of even among Africa's poorest cities. The unemployment rate has continued to rise and is now estimated at 80 percent. Zaire's continuing power struggle between Mr. Mobutu and leaders of the opposition has virtually paralyzed most governmental institutions. Compounding the misery, the annual inflation rate is now about 4,400 percent, partly because of a huge budget deficit that developed after the Government abandoned a broad range of belt-tightening measures devised by the International Monetary Fund in early 1990, and instead increased spending. Since then, Zaire has been declared "non-cooperating" by the monetary fund, and a decision to expel it from the world's leading governmental lending organization is believed to be imminent. Migration to City Slows An enigma that strikes many Western analysts visiting or living in Zaire is why the people appear to tolerate conditions that clearly should produce deep discontent. Despite the economic deprivation of recent years -- hyperinflation and the lack of jobs and housing -- there has been a steady migration of people into the city. But even that may be changing, said Martine Dedeur Warder, a nutritionist with Doctors Without Borders. For one thing, prices for basic food items have become so high here that even the relatively well-to-do are struggling. Mid-level civil service workers, for example, earn about $25 a month, yet a 110-pound sack of corn flour -- enough to feed a family of four for about a week -- costs about $50. To make matters worse, she said, most Government employees have not been paid for at least four months. As a result, Miss Dedeur Warder said, for the first time in recent memory, migration from the villages to the city appears to be slowing, and perhaps even reversing. "People are leaving the city and returning to the bush because they understand there's no food, there are no jobs and there's no money here," she said. "Leaving Kinshasa is a drastic step for many Zairians, but it's one of the few solutions for stopping the misery here." Map of Zaire, indicating Kinshasa

COUNTRY: NIGERIA (97%); AFRICA (93%); UNITED STATES (79%);
TEXT: Nigeria's planned return to civilian rule was suspended today when a commission appointed by the military leaders set aside the results of Saturday's presidential elections. There had been growing indications that the candidate of the Social Democratic Party, Moshood Abiola, was well on his way to a resounding triumph over his rival, Bashir Tofa, of the National Republican Convention. Both had campaigned against military rule. The vote had been heralded by many Nigerians as a historic end to nearly a decade of military rule in Africa's most populous nation. Hope Tainted by Skepticism The election was to be only the third time since independence from Britain in 1960 that a president would rise to office through the ballot box and not through military action. But even before today's announcement, there had been considerable skepticism over whether the military leader, Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, was committed to democratic rule. [This skepticism was reflected in Washington. Though the State Department had no official comment on the election, some Administration officials said they were not surprised that problems had arisen. [While they said they had no reason to believe that General Baba ngida was directly involved in the delay of the return to democracy, "there is a lot of cynicism about the process that has grown up," one official said, "sort of a dark apprehension that it would never happen."] 'A Hidden Agenda' Beko Ransome-Kuti, chairman of the Committee for the Defense of Human Rights, said today that he had long suspected General Babangida was stalling the shift to civilian rule. "He's always had a hidden agenda," to remain in power, Dr. Ransome-Kuti said. General Babangida has postponed a return to civilian rule three times since 1990, and the military authorities have annulled a number of gubernatorial and parliamentary elections, saying they had been compromised by financial improprieties and vote-buying. Since independence, there have been seven successful coups and three of the nation's eight leaders have been assassinated. Two brief periods of civilian rule collapsed after allegations by the military of incompetence and wholesale corruption. A General's Promise Still, General Babangida has said repeatedly in recent speeches and interviews that come what may, the military will return to its barracks on Aug. 27, the eighth anniversary of the coup that brought him to power. Nigeria, with about 90 million people and more than 250 tribal groups, has always been difficult to govern. From 1967 to 1970, the nation was mired in a war to quell secessionists among the mostly Ibo peoples in the Eastern Region known as Biafra. Despite its great natural resources -- Nigeria is Africa's largest oil producer -- the country remains basically poor; per-capita income in 1991 was $250. The suspension of the election results came in response to a suit filed by the Association for a Better Nigeria, a lobbying group of wealthy business executives, politicians and military officers who have led a highly visible campaign urging General Babangida to remain in office at least four more years. The association asserted that the transition to civilian rule had been compromised by widespread vote-tampering and corruption, and on Tuesday the group won a court order instructing the national electoral commission not to release election results. Justice Mohamveg Saleh, the chief judge of the high court in Abuja, the capital, ordered the commission not to publish the results until legal arguments over vote-rigging were heard by the court. This process could take months, effectively nullifying the election and keeping the military in power. This morning Humphrey Nwosu, the chairman of the commission, reportedly met with his staff and officials from the President's office to decide how to respond. Late this afternoon Mr. Nwosu issued a statement saying, in effect, that the Government had no choice but to suspend the elections or face being held in contempt of court. Mr. Nwosu added that he would appeal the court's jurisdiction over the electoral process. Details of Charges The association's suit charged, among other things, that officials of the Social Democratic Party had bribed delegates to the party's nominating convention to vote for Mr. Abiola. It also said that the campaigns of both presidential candidates had increased tension among Nigeria's many ethnic and religious groups, and that if an election were to occur now, it would was likely to "lead to chaos and a breach of public peace." It was difficult to assess the accusations. Many neutral Nigerian analysts said they were not persuaded that these assertions constituted proof of systematic fraud or posed a threat to security. Foreign observers have generally described the elections as free and fair. Even though the decision to set aside the election results stunned many, the reaction among people milling in Lagos's crowded streets and in bars and restaurants tonight was subdued. Salle Lamido, of the Social Democratic Party, said on state television tonight, "The court order is very, very contradictory and that shows the futility of the entire thing. The court has not been fair. I believe at the end of the day justice will prevail." A chart yesterday showing the distribution of ethnic groups in Nigeria misstated the percentage for those who are members of other than the Hausa, Yoruba, Ibo or Fulani. They are 33 percent of the population. Area: 356,667 square mile, more than twice the size of California. Capital: Abuja. Other major cities are Lagos and Ibadan. Population: 88.5 million (1991). It is the most populous country in Africa. Currency: Naira. The exchange rate is about 25 naira to $1 (March 1993). Per-capita G.D.P.: $250 (1991). Exports: Oil makes up 95 percent of Nigeria's exports. Cocoa is the chief export crop. COUNTRY: NIGERIA (99%);
TEXT: With the generals once again in open and absolute command, Nigeria is facing the prospect of economic chaos, political upheaval and perhaps even conflict between its two major tribes, the politically dominant Hausa in the north and the restive Yoruba in the southwest, Nigerians, diplomats and foreign experts say. Some of the experts say the crisis is more dire than any since 1967, when the eastern region called Biafra tried to split away, plunging the country into three years of civil war that cost up to a million lives. The current crisis began when the military Government, which planned for six years to return to civilian rule, abruptly reneged on the promise after presidential elections in June. Amid street protests, the military leader, Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, handed power over to a transitional Government nominally headed by a civilian, Ernest Shonekan. Now that Government has been shoved aside by another military strongman, Gen. Sani Abacha. On Wednesday, General Abacha was installed as Nigeria's seventh military leader since independence from Britain in 1960. He promptly began dismantling the democratic institutions that had been carefully constructed, abolishing national and state assemblies, dissolving the two military-created political parties, removing elected state governors and proscribing all political meetings and associations. General Suspected of Corruption "We did not expect destruction of this magnitude of the democratic structures," Albert Legogie, deputy president of the now-defunct Senate, told The Associated Press. Like many of Nigeria's military rulers, General Abacha is widely thought by diplomats, experts and other Nigerians to be corrupt, with a substantial income from the country's rich oil industry, from construction projects in the new capital, Abuja, and various other Government contracts and building permits. Leaders of Nigerian civil rights and pro-democracy groups assailed General Abacha's seizure of power. A statement from the Civil Liberties Organization called on Nigerians to reject "a power-corrupted military bent on turning free citizens to slaves in their own country." But on Thursday, in a brisk 10-minute address to the nation, General Abacha warned that he was not a man to brook disorder. "Any attempt to test our will will be decisively dealt with," he vowed. But he gave little idea of what he had in mind for an anxious country. He talked vaguely about setting up a constitutional conference to chart Nigeria's future but, in what many read as an ominous sign, he did not set any date for handing power back to civilians. As Defense Minister and before that as army Chief of Staff, General Abacha was a major player in Nigeria's corrupt and politicized military. He helped to engineer the coup that overthrew the last civilian Government in December 1983, and another one that brought General Babangida to power in 1985. Ever since General Babangida stepped aside in August and installed an interim Government under Mr. Shonekan, the 50-year-old General Abacha has been the true power behind the scenes. Some diplomats believe that the two generals had a falling out, and they point out that one of General Abacha's first moves during the brief stewardship of Mr. Shonekan was to remove key military commanders put in place by General Babangida. Tribal and Regional Rivalries Some pronounced General Babangida discredited and finished. But others said that reports of the rift are greatly exaggerated, and they did not rule out an attempt by General Babangida to stage a political comeback at some point. "It could be that Babangida is playing a long game in which he will emerge as a presidential candidate in an election organized by Abacha," said one expert interviewed here. Both generals are Muslims from the Hausa-speaking north, which has traditionally produced top officers and has dominated politics in the country of 90 million people. By contrast, Moshood Abiola, the man who is generally thought to have won the June elections, is a Yoruba from the south, though he, too, is a Muslim. The interim leader, Mr. Shonekan, who never achieved a popular base of support, was likewise a Yoruba. The Yoruba, concentrated around the economic and political center, Lagos, are beginning to "chafe under the northern yoke," as one Nigerian politician put it when interviewed by telephone from Lagos. Referring to the center of Yoruba culture, he said, "People in Abeokuta are wondering why northerners always outmaneuver southerners." The third major section of the country, which produces the oil that brings in 95 percent of export earnings, is the east, where the Ibo predominate. They have not assumed a major role in national life since losing the civil war. Demonstrations in Southwest Most of the strikes and protests against the annulment of the elections occurred in the southwest. The protests were given a lift last week when a court in Lagos ruled that General Babangida had no power to install an interim Government and that the Government was thus illegal. Today, clashes between the police and pro-democracy demonstrators were reported in three southwestern cities, Abeokuta, Akure and Ilorin. Lagos was quiet. Banks, major shops and factories remained closed, as they have been since last week. Those demonstrations were caused by the announcement of a sixfold increase in the price of fuel. The increase was part of a spate of economic reforms undertaken by Mr. Shonekan under the prodding of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. Until the increase, Government fuel subsidies drove the retail price down to about 12 cents a gallon. Because of price differences with surrounding countries, where it sold between $4 and $5 a gallon, smuggling was rife. Much of it involved the military. Despite its oil exports, which produced $11.7 billion in 1992, Nigeria's economy is in trouble. The country's foreign debts amount to about $30 billion, and arrears on its debts total about $5 billion. If General Abacha rolls back the fuel increase in a bid for instant popularity, he would be undercutting the austerity program on which hopes for an economic recovery are pinned.

COUNTRY: FRANCE (97%); AFRICA (97%); WESTERN AFRICA (92%); CENTRAL AFRICA (92%);
TEXT: After decades of fraternal gestures that could barely disguise graft and back-room politics, France's special relations with its former African colonies are undergoing extensive change that could alter the power balance on the continent. The vast swath of territory across West and Central Africa controlled by often ruthless rulers who looked to Paris for funds, instructions and ultimate military salvation no longer serves as a point of conflict among foreign powers, robbing French influence of much of its significance. A new generation of Africans is emerging that no longer seems bound by the old colonial instincts. Outraged by the corrupt regimes and declining living standards that have proved endemic under French tutelage, they are looking elsewhere, especially to the United States, for help and inspiration. In France, young technocrats with enhanced influence under the conservative government of Prime Minister Edouard Balladur are insisting that Paris no longer can afford the moral and financial luxury of propping up autocrats willing to do France's bidding as long as they can loot the treasuries. "The old days when we could handle problems among a few of us are coming to an end," said Fernand Wibaux, a close associate of Jacques Foccart, known as "Monsieur Afrique," who served as the political and intelligence overlord for the continent under President Charles de Gaulle. "We led these African states to independence in 1960, and then we managed to prevent the 'Balkanization' that everybody warned about through the franc zone," Wibaux said, referring to the fixed exchange rates for France's former African colonies set up in 1946 to guarantee economic ties with France. "But now they [current policy-makers] are taking the attitude that you must shoot a dog if you think it has rabies." But behind the guise of paternalistic care lies an ugly image that France has treated black Africa like a cash cow, exploiting its resources and markets, protecting dictators and even using those countries as conduits to channel funds to French political parties. Ten days ago, 13 African countries in the African Financial Community's franc zone announced they would slash the value of their currencies in half, pegging their money at 100 instead of 50 to the French franc, while a 14th country, Comoros, devalued its currency by 25 percent. The action was designed to increase domestic production and investment over time by generating a boost in exports. It was the first time the parity of the franc zone was altered, and the magnitude of the devaluation demonstrated how out of whack the economic relationship between France and its colonies had become. The devaluation already has spurred panic buying that some experts predict will trigger shortages and possibly food riots in places like Niger and the Central African Republic. But some exporters, such as Ivory Coast, the Congo, Gabon and Cameroon, which have resources such as coffee, cocoa, cotton and oil, could find that their sales abroad will increase. The financial shock became inevitable last September, when Balladur informed the African leaders in a letter that France was no longer prepared to serve as lender of last resort. In the future, Balladur said, France would determine its aid policy by doling out money only to those countries that subscribed to terms set by the International Monetary Fund. In doing so, Balladur disregarded advice from France's "old colonialists" who claimed he would end up ceding French influence in the region to the IMF and its ultimate paymaster, the United States. French industry was also troubled by the change, because it would mean that it would no longer enjoy the privileged access and lopsided profits gained through such captive markets. But the franc zone has steadily impoverished the Africans by impeding their ability to export and encouraging them to buy from abroad at the artificially high rate. Meanwhile, corrupt leaders found the system convenient because it allowed them to easily funnel money to secret Swiss bank accounts. The franc zone also helped funnel development aid and kickbacks from industrial contracts back into France to finance political parties, according to diplomats and French officials familiar with the arrangements. Much of the $ 700 million in annual development aid to the former colonies never actually leaves French hands, because a project may be carried out by a French company that in turn may provide a financial kickback to the requisite political channel. In addition, contributions from industrial firms that win major contracts in the former African colonies often are channeled back to politicians who help clinch the deal through local regional councils, according to French and African experts. In the end, French taxpayers ultimately pay for what are subsidies channeled to the political parties. During the 1980s, President Francois Mitterrand and successive Socialist governments encountered fierce criticism when they intervened to save autocrats such as Gabon's Omar Bongo or Benin's Mathieu Kerekou. But at a 1990 French-African summit meeting in La Baule, only months after the Berlin Wall had fallen, Mitterrand signaled that France would link its cooperation in Africa to those rulers "who make efforts along the path toward greater liberty." The initiative led to 23 elections in the past three years, but has not caused too much grumbling among the autocrats. In a disputed election held in December in Gabon, Bongo was praised by France for getting "elected" to his fifth seven-year term in spite of his record.

COUNTRY: AFRICA (98%); COTE D'IVOIRE (95%); SUB SAHARAN AFRICA (94%); WESTERN AFRICA (92%); HOLY SEE (90%); FRANCE (90%);
TEXT: Felix Houphouet-Boigny, the longtime president of this West African nation, died at 88 last December. In this jungle-enclosed city, his birthplace, stand the monuments to his grandiose ambitions -- for himself and for Africa's economic future. Few sub-Saharan African countries achieved anything like the economic success Ivory Coast enjoyed during the 1960s and 1970s under Houphouet-Boigny's firm hand. Lifted by French investment and rising production of cash crops, Ivorian personal incomes soared as the economy hit double-digit rates of expansion in some years. Steel and glass skyscrapers went up in the coastal city of Abidjan as it blossomed into a seaside playground for European expatriates. In Yamoussoukro, the newly declared, underpopulated inland capital, no expense was spared on avenues wide enough for jumbo jets, thousands of streetlights, three universities, half a dozen hotels, an airport, car dealerships, a radio and microwave transmission tower, landscaped gardens, playing fields, artificial lakes, the world's largest Catholic basilica (a replica -- but on a far grander scale -- of St. Peter's Basilica in Vatican City) and a presidential family palace guarded by crocodiles and stone walls more than a mile around. Yamoussoukro was "the ultra-modern prefiguration of the Africa of tomorrow," exhorted a hotel brochure from the early 1980s. But now the promised future has arrived, and it is none too exhilarating. Since 1980, personal incomes in Ivory Coast have shrunk by a staggering 50 percent. Debt has soared to about $ 18 billion, leaving the country with one of the highest rates of debt per capita in the world. The economy has been contracting steadily since 1987, dragging Ivory Coast from its earlier middle income status toward the ranks of the world's poorest economies. And Yamoussoukro's extravagance, far from the crowning symbol of Houphouet-Boigny's Ivorian miracle, today looks to have been "a terrible economic step," said Joseph Yao, director of the Ivorian Center for Economic and Social Research. "One of the basics of economics is that you create before you distribute," he added. "In Africa, we started distributing and figured we would create later." Across sub-Saharan Africa, more than two dozen countries and tens of millions of impoverished people are paying the price for years of misdirected investment, unbalanced development, squandered savings, government mismanagement and corruption, ineffective foreign aid programs, falling commodity prices and the brutal imperatives of a global economy that is leaving Africa behind while it races toward the next century. On average, the region's economy shrunk 1.2 percent each year between 1980 and 1991, according to the World Bank. It has recovered slightly since then, according to the African Development Bank, but not enough to keep pace with swelling populations. The bank's forecast for 1994 is more of the same, at best. As a consequence, rising numbers of Africans are sliding into poverty as each year passes. To many African economists, politicians and businessmen, the decline is especially galling because it has occurred while other areas of the developing world -- southeast Asia, China, India and much of Latin America -- have expanded economically, in some cases by leaps and bounds. Consider Nigeria and Indonesia, for instance -- both oil-rich and heavily populated at independence. In 1973, when world oil prices first boomed, their per capita economies were the same size -- which is to say, very small. By 1990, average incomes in Indonesia had doubled, but in Nigeria they had fallen, despite billions of dollars in windfall revenues. Ghana and South Korea had the same per capita incomes just 35 years ago. Today the average South Korean is richer than the average Portuguese, but the average Ghanaian is poorer than he or she was 20 years ago. To an overwhelming majority of Western economists at lending institutions such as the World Bank, and to increasing numbers of their African counterparts, the cause of this disparity -- and of Ivory Coast's failed miracle -- is no great mystery. It boils down, they say, to disastrous economic policies. In a detailed survey of the sub-Saharan African economy published by the World Bank in February, the bank's economists rated the economic policies of 26 regional governments on a scale from "good" to "very poor." Not a single African government was rated good, and only one, Ghana, was judged adequate. Nearly half were rated poor or very poor, including Ivory Coast, which ranked near the bottom. Most African governments intervene heavily and inefficiently in nearly every economic sector. Hundreds of uncompetitive state-owned monopolies smother business competition. High taxes and tariffs throttle international trade and foreign investment. Unsustainable price subsidies and welfare benefits for city dwellers lead to heavy government borrowing and, in some cases, high rates of inflation. Artificially high exchange rates for many African currencies, which make it easier for urban African elites to buy cheap luxury imports, smother exports and punish farmers in the countryside, where most of Africa's poorest live. Corruption and theft by African government leaders and their allies sap national savings that might otherwise be reinvested in productive businesses. "This is my country too, so I have the right to work without giving someone money underneath the table," complained Bergson Koffi, a U.S.-trained Ivorian businessman who said he has spent about $ 1 million since 1986 trying unsuccessfully to get licenses for a new cellular phone company. Koffi alleged that government employees involved in potentially competitive deals block his progress. "They're trying to make me waste time so I will give up," he said. Many businessmen do just that. As the pressures of failed economic policies have caused African economies to shrink, political instability and ethnic conflict have risen, frightening off foreign investors and crippling local businesses. Japanese car and truck makers, for example, keep their inventories floating on container ships off the East African coast, only docking when they have an order, because they judge it too risky and inefficient to keep their vehicles in showrooms, according to the Harvard Business School. One worsening problem is a relative lack of skilled managers. Unlike in other regions of the Third World, African governments did not use heavy control over their economies after independence to force rapid industrialization, with its side benefits of new technologies and trained work forces. Instead, they relied on agricultural and mineral exports, which among other things provided easy money for crooked governments. Today, nine out of 10 dollars earned from African exports come from raw materials and agricultural crops, by far the highest percentage worldwide. As in Ivory Coast, such African resource exports typically pass through inefficient government-controlled marketing boards that are widely described as money machines for government ministers and their political allies. Farmers themselves are heavily taxed, directly and indirectly. "It was a clear political choice that the government will control all the money coming into the country" from cocoa and coffee exports, said Ivorian businessman Mahamadou Sylla. "The whole system was based on that. ... The president and the government wanted this power." Yet the total pool of money available has steadily declined. That is partly because Africa's dependence on commodity exports is at odds with a basic global economic trend toward increased manufacturing. As more countries shovel resources into the global trading economy, and as more wealth around the world is created by adding value with manufacturing and new technologies, the relative importance -- and relative price -- of many African resources has declined. Small and fragile to begin with, sub-Saharan Africa's industrial sector has shrunk even faster during the last decade than its overall economy, according to the Overseas Development Institute. New foreign investment in African industry, although growing, is a tiny fraction of such investment worldwide. Western banks, governments and multilateral agencies sometimes reinforce failure in Africa with poorly designed or self-interested loan and aid programs, according to some critics, both Western and African. In West Africa, for example, France spends what diplomats estimate as $ 2 billion to $ 5 billion annually to subsidize former colonies that today pursue what many Western economists see as highly inefficient economic policies. The World Bank, under what bankers and diplomats describe as heavy French pressure, has kicked in large sums to support these West African governments, including Ivory Coast. Some Western-funded economic policies that many economists see as inefficient for Africans have nonetheless benefited Western business and political interests, said economists, diplomats and businessmen. Japanese and European aid programs to Africa heavily emphasize credits tied to the purchase of machinery from the donor's own corporations. Businessmen in Tokyo and London come up with ideas about how African countries can use their products, then try to sell these aid ideas to their governments. "If you look at the amount of money the [World] Bank and the French government poured into the economy to support these weaknesses, it's really quite scandalous," said development economist Roger Riddell. World Bank officials say that while some of their past policies may be debatable, the bulk of responsibility for failure lies with recipient African governments. And lately, World Bank economists argue, there are signs of new commitment to economic reform in many sub-Saharan African countries. Indeed, while the region's overall economic picture is gloomy, there are pockets of exception where governments have aggressively pursued free-market-oriented reform programs and have been rewarded with persistent economic growth. In Ghana, where President Jerry Rawlings has stuck with painful reforms for a decade, the economy has grown by an average 5 to 6 percent each year since 1983. The World Bank, which desperately needs an African success story to serve as a model for its economic prescriptions, hails Ghana as a regional leader. As with Ivory Coast earlier, however, the question is whether Ghana's achievements will last. A decade of robust growth has pulled Ghana from the deep economic pit into which it had fallen by the early 1980s. Investment has been redirected to rural areas. New businesses are opening, the infrastructure is improving, and some foreign and expatriate Ghanaian investors are starting to speak confidently of the future. Yet some economists argue that with a swelling population, even Ghana's respectable growth rates are not good enough. Technology-driven industrial investment has been slow to materialize. Although the government has not squandered revenue on grandiose white elephants such as Ivory Coast's Yamoussoukro, Ghana has been hesitant to privatize state businesses or to loosen its grip on commodity marketing boards. Why don't more African governments adopt free-market-oriented programs similar to Ghana's? One key reason, Africans and outside analysts say, is political. The failed economic policies pursued by many African leaders for the last three decades have not been entirely irrational: They were often constructed to enrich undemocratic leaders and to appease the urban populations that pose the greatest political threat to these leaders. Government control of the economy, overvalued exchange rates, lavish subsidies and other similar policies allow otherwise weak or illegitimate African politicians to buy off opponents and build empires of patronage, especially in urban areas that are key to political control. Free market reform as prescribed by the World Bank often means pulling the plug on these political lifelines, most dramatically in the cities. Urban revolt in the aftermath of economic liberalization "is a frightening prospect," said D.F. Annan, speaker of Ghana's parliament. In Ghana, the revolt never came. But in other African countries, "IMF riots," as they are called, have become a regular -- and to African political leaders, often terrifying -- consequence of attempted economic change. Yet in this African trap of immovable leaders and irresistible economic decline, a new generation of Africans increasingly insists that something has to give. In politics, these younger Africans are the driving force of the continent's nascent democracy movement. In economics, despite the high government-imposed barriers, they represent a new wave of entrepreneurial, sometimes Western-trained managers who want Africa to succeed as Asia and much of Latin America already have done. Many of these younger, business-minded Africans are visible in relatively prosperous, dynamic cities such as Accra and Abidjan. Among them is Luc Tanoh, a young Ivorian computer engineer and businessman who is struggling to succeed amid Ivory Coast's economic rubble. "With a new generation coming, a new civilization is emerging. Young Africans born after independence, trained in their country ... are really the resources lacking in the past. "If today Africa is not able to seize this opportunity, the young human resources, then we will really be in trouble."  Staff researcher Alice Crites in Washington and special correspondent Cindy Shiner in Abidjan contributed to this report.

COUNTRY: AFRICA (99%); ZIMBABWE (94%); SOUTH AFRICA (93%); UNITED STATES (93%); SOMALIA (92%); ANGOLA (92%); DJIBOUTI (92%); FRANCE (90%); RWANDA (79%); EUROPE (79%); LIBERIA (79%); SUB SAHARAN AFRICA (79%); SUDAN (79%); UNITED KINGDOM (79%);
TEXT: When Nelson Mandela was sworn in as president of South Africa in May, the last of the three great conflicts that have shaped the modern history of Africa came to an end. Apartheid was vanquished. The struggle against colonialism ended in victory when Djibouti won independence from France in 1977 and British-controlled Rhodesia became independent Zimbabwe in 1980. The end of the Cold War also put an end to the proxy conflicts between Moscow and Washington that ravaged the continent from Angola to Somalia. Angola's war continues, but it is no longer a contest between Moscow and Washington. These historic developments ought to have been unrelieved good news for sub-Saharan Africa. But in many countries, what loomed as an era of promise dissolved into one of drift and disorder as Africa was increasingly left to its own devices. Except for televised disasters, and triumphs like Mandela's inauguration, Africa largely disappeared from the agenda of the major powers after the conflicts that interested them came to an end. With its limited economic clout and endemic corruption, and without the moral imperative of the movement against South Africa's apartheid system of racial separation, Africa no longer commands the same level of international concern as it did when rivals elsewhere needed African votes in the United Nations. Now mostly on its own, Africa has entered another period of struggle, perhaps more brutal than the first three: order against chaos. In the gloomiest forecasts, the disintegrations of Somalia, Rwanda, Liberia and Sudan project Africa's future, with the centrifugal forces in many countries compounded by international indifference. "Africa is left adrift at a time of economic crisis, perpetuating its sense of marginalization, frustration and anger over its seeming abandonment," scholars John W. Harbeson and Donald Rothchild wrote in "Africa in World Politics." "The picture that emerged at the end of the 1980s was one of increasing African peripheralization," they wrote. "The explanation for this phenomenon varied, but it included the end of the Cold War, the industrialized countries' disillusionment with the economic and political performance of the African states, and the growing preoccupation of the developed countries with their own economic problems." The CIA demonstrated this point in June when it floated a plan to close 15 stations in Africa to save money. Africa was targeted because the agency was never really interested in it anyway, a senior CIA official said. "We have never been in Africa to report on Africa," he said. "We went into Africa as part of the covert activity of the Cold War," because it was easier to recruit Cuban and East European agents there than in their home countries. The British international relief agency Oxfam, in a report last year, complained that the industrialized nations, "preoccupied with more 'strategic' concerns elsewhere ... have allowed Africa, the world's most impoverished region, to become increasingly marginalized. "Financial resource flows are stagnating in real terms, debt-relief measures have been inadequate, and there has been no attempt to improve the region's external trade environment," Oxfam said. "To make matters worse, the international donor community and multilateral agencies -- the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund -- continue to insist on economic policy reforms which have manifestly failed to generate recovery, while imposing huge social costs." In a speech last May, James Gustave Speth, director of the United Nations Development Program, argued that it was in developed nations' self-interest to help Africa. If they do not, he said, disease, poverty and environmental degradation in Africa will ensure that "our own shores" will be affected by "illegal aliens, refugees, drugs, crime" and other problems from Africa. But he also noted that most nations' attention is focused elsewhere. Russia, once a looming military presence in the Horn of Africa and patron of leftist regimes from Ethiopia to Mozambique, has all but withdrawn from the continent. The United States, which was heavily engaged in Africa as a counterweight to the Soviets, has "no strategic interests in Africa," according to Pentagon doctrine. Among the industrialized nations, the United States ranks last in percentage of gross national product devoted to African aid. Except for diplomatic involvement, Britain, Belgium and Portugal mostly disappeared from Africa when they surrendered their colonies there. Japanese investment is minimal. Among the major powers, only France remains actively committed in Africa, with troops in seven countries, extensive economic and political ties and effective control of the currency of its former colonies in West Africa. "We have intervened in Africa whenever an unacceptable situation had to be remedied," former French president Valery Giscard d'Estaing once said -- a comment that applied perfectly to the recent, two-month French military intervention in Rwanda. So thin is U.S. political and economic interest in Africa that one of the panels at a recent White House conference on Africa was devoted to the subject of "constituency building" -- how to get more people to care. Donald McHenry, former U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, said the United States has "a general responsibility [for Africa] in the interests of mankind, and given the melting pot nature of our society it carries something of a special interest as the origin of 10 or 12 percent of our population." But McHenry suggested that direct U.S. interest in Africa is limited to heading off disasters such as the Rwandan refugee crisis, because "when disaster occurs, man-made or nature, we are going to end up paying for some of it." U.S. policy makers and some independent analysts say South Africa is capable of vigorous economic growth that will also contribute to the development of its neighbors. But "whereas South Africa and the southern African region increasingly command our attention for both economic and political reasons, much of the rest of the continent is becoming more marginal in terms of U.S. national interest priorities," said Walter H. Kansteiner, White House Africa policy director in the Bush administration. Western thinking about sub-Saharan Africa appears generally divided along the lines of optimism vs. pessimism. The optimists see a new generation of realistic African leaders adopting economic and political reforms that could lead to peace and prosperity. They also see indigenous peace and human rights movements increasingly asserting themselves and putting pressure on leaders to abandon repressive policies. The pessimists see an accelerating slide into the chaos and anarchy tearing apart Somalia, Rwanda, Sudan, Liberia and Angola. In both views, what happens to Africa in the coming decade is largely up to the Africans, not to the foreign powers that for decades manipulated Africa for their own ends. The most pessimistic prospect was offered by Robert D. Kaplan in an apocalyptic article in the February issue of Atlantic Monthly, "The Coming Anarchy." According to Kaplan, overpopulation, crime, corruption and the ready availability of weapons will doom virtually all of West Africa to lapse into malarial anarchy. He predicted a breakdown of civilization as "foreign embassies are shut down, states collapse, and contact with the outside world takes place through dangerous, disease-ridden coastal trading posts." Envisioning a lawless era in which the writ of government will not extend to the African interior, Kaplan said Africa "faces cataclysms that could make the Ethiopian and Somalian famines pale in comparison." President Clinton and each of his senior foreign policy advisers have read Kaplan's article, a White House official said recently. According to White House National Security Adviser Anthony Lake, an Africa specialist, the challenge facing the outside world is figuring out how to help Africa avoid the nightmare predicted by Kaplan and achieve instead "a culture of tolerance, a flowering of civil society and the protection of human dignity throughout the continent." But the tools available to achieve that lofty goal do not include an increase in direct U.S. aid, which is holding steady at about $ 800 million a year, much of it directed at South Africa. Instead, U.S. policy envisions a new political and economic climate in Africa that will encourage indigenous development and foreign investment. Some analysts dismiss that as pie in the sky. But others -- including the U.N. Development Program's Speth and Michael Clough, Africa policy specialist at the Council on Foreign Relations -- argue that U.S. and other foreign aid in the past has done more harm than good as Africans squandered it on extravagant projects and arms purchases. Clough, who was Africa issues director for the Clinton transition team, wrote in his book "Free at Last?" that the bulk of U.S. assistance to Africa during the Cold War went to six countries: Ethiopia, Kenya, Liberia, Somalia, Sudan and Zaire. "By any standard, this is not a list of African success stories," he wrote. Clough said in an interview that the argument over aid funding levels is "absurd" because amounts available will never be enough to make a significant difference. That being the case, he said the Clinton administration's evolving long-term approach, stressing human rights and free markets to stimulate economic growth and thus head off disasters such as the one in Somalia, "makes sense in Africa." But he questioned whether it can succeed, because "there is very little political payoff" in Africa and "nobody except Lake cares about Africa anyway." Optimists about Africa said in interviews that it is necessary to distinguish between failed states such as Somalia and old-fashioned African "big man" dictatorships such as Togo on the one hand and the more open, stable countries with new pragmatic rulers on the other. This list includes Benin, Eritrea, Mali, Zambia and Uganda as well as South Africa. Africans "want the same things everybody else wants," said Vivian Lowery Derryck, president of the African American Institute in New York, and they are throwing their support to leaders and movements that hold the promise of delivering. She predicted that Sudan and possibly Zaire will break apart, but she said there are several countries where "pragmatic" leaders have come to power and where it is reasonable for foreigners to consider investing. "There is a new class of African business people emerging who are not victims of the past," said Frank Savage, a prominent African-American financier whose Alliance Capital Corp. has set up an Africa investment fund. "They were born after independence. All they want now is a higher standard of living." "You would be amazed at how many countries have adopted structural adjustments" that make them economically attractive, he said. "It may still be a little early for a lot of investors, but it's time to look at countries that may be investor-friendly," such as Ghana, he said. Savage said the worldwide "commodity cycle" is favorable to Africa as prices rise in a general economic recovery. A test of his evaluation, and of Africa's interest for potential investors, is scheduled for mid-October, when a major international oil and gas conference assembles in Cape Town, South Africa. This event -- of a type common in Houston, London and Singapore but virtually unknown in Africa -- will bring together oil and gas executives and government officials from all across Africa to assess the natural gas potential of Mozambique, offshore oil exploration in Cameroon, recent natural gas discoveries in Namibia and a score of similar issues. Invitations to this conference from its sponsor, the authoritative trade journal Petroleum Intelligence Weekly, stress that "many African nations are actively promoting investment through extensive deregulation, privatization and divestment policies." That is just what the Clinton administration likes to hear, but often does not. "The policies this administration supports are not necessarily supported by African leaders," an administration official said. "Democracy, open markets, the development of indigenous human rights groups, rural empowerment -- these are not necessarily what African leaders want. They imply political development." But Africans increasingly understand the need for popular participation in political and economic life, said Roble Olhaye, Djibouti's ambassador to the United Nations. "They know corruption, nepotism, waste and human rights abuses have to go," he said in an interview. "That is the order of the day."

COUNTRY: GAMBIA (96%); AFRICA (92%); UNITED STATES (92%);
TEXT: To the Editor: For more than eight years Gambia followed International Monetary Fund austerity programs. In return, the I.M.F. ignored widespread, conspicuous corruption and mismanagement. While the average Gambian bore the brunt, the Government, with the help of "surplus" United States arms, formed a semiliterate army, which deposed the Government. Last year the I.M.F. rated Gambia third in macroeconomic policy in Africa. Belonging to the fund's list of well-behaved countries has become a harbinger of social instability. In a desperate search for a long-absent success story, the I.M.F. has helped hand my country to power-hungry soldiers by asking people to sacrifice while ignoring official corruption. ABDOURAHMAN TOURAY New York, Sept. 7, 1994

COUNTRY: CONGO, THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE (96%); UNITED STATES (94%); AFRICA (94%); EUROPE (79%); LEBANON (79%);
TEXT: Unnoticed amid all the celebrity dignitaries making the diplomatic rounds in Washington recently was a man from Zaire seeking support from the Clinton administration as he tackles the daunting task of restoring economic stability and governmental credibility in his huge country. The administration, which is quietly but doggedly looking for ways to promote stability and economic reform in Africa, wants Prime Minister Kengo wa Dondo to succeed, officials said. But it is restricted in how much it can help him, partly by laws limiting aid to Zaire and partly by uncertainty over how much distance Kengo has really put between himself and Zairian President Mobutu Sese Seko. The meetings between Kengo and administration officials were nuts-and-bolts diplomatic work, far from the televised glamour of summits with Boris Yeltsin or red-carpet greetings for Nelson Mandela. But the lack of glitter did not diminish the size of the stakes. Kengo is trying to turn around a potentially rich nation of 40 million people, one quarter the size of the United States in area, that long ago descended into a morass of corruption and ineptitude. Mobutu and other senior officials have reportedly enriched themselves by looting the state while roads, schools and other public facilities fell into ruin and the authority of the central government dwindled. U.S. policy is to encourage what one official called "credible and transparent elections" next year that would choose a successor to Mobutu, whom Washington once relied on as an anticommunist ally but no longer needs. The Clinton administration has been preaching that Africa's post-independence era of "big man" rule is over and telling Africans that democracy and open markets are the keys to a prosperous future. "We are not going to support flawed elections that would validate a transition from Mobutu to Mobutu," the official said. Kengo, who was prime minister under Mobutu twice before, is now part of Mobutu's restless opposition, chosen by a self-appointed transitional parliament to serve until July 1995, when elections are scheduled. His selection ended a two-year period in which Zaire was virtually paralyzed by having two rival governments, one run by Mobutu and one run by Etienne Tshiskedi, who was chosen prime minister by a national conference in 1992 and still lays claim to the title.
