"Since I was elected," Kengo said in an interview, "Mobutu's actions have shown that he is cooperating with the government. We can only judge him on his behavior. Will he change his mind in a month or two months? We don't know." Kengo challenged Mobutu in dramatic fashion last month when he broke up a racket that was smuggling Zairian currency into the country from printers in Europe without delivering it to the central bank. He ordered the closure of a Lebanese-owned firm allegedly involved in the shipment, withdrew the license of an air freight company that flew in the 30 tons of bills and ordered suspects prosecuted. The U.S. Embassy in Kinshasa issued a statement supporting Kengo and the crackdown, saying "this effort is of vital importance and ... the credibility of the Zairian government depends directly upon its accomplishment. ... The United States supports the prime minister in this difficult undertaking." It is not clear why Mobutu, who still controls the army, tolerated this challenge to what one official here called "the kleptocracy." One possibility is that he has resigned himself to leaving office next year and wants to avoid provoking the Zairian public in ways that might threaten his wealth. Asked if Mobutu is still enriching himself at the expense of the state, Kengo replied, "Right now there is nothing to be taken away anymore, because there are no more productive companies." He said Zaire's diamond exports produce little revenue for the government because military officers and non-Zairian diamond merchants control the trade. An administration official said Kengo is "a legitimate transition figure" because as a nonnative of Zaire he cannot run for president himself. He said that "if Kengo can curb abuses and limit corruption, and if he can establish a reasonable economic program to satisfy the International Monetary Fund and if he can establish a legitimate political process leading to free elections, then he is worthy of a lot of support. That's a lot of ifs." "Kengo has made a courageous effort to limit Mobutu's power, at some risk to himself," said an administration official who met with him. Washington's problem in trying to support him, this official said, is that current law prohibits direct aid to a government in arrears on U.S. loans, which Zaire is, to the tune of $ 800 million. The fiscal 1995 foreign aid bill, he said, prohibits use of any of the U.S. African Development Fund for Zaire. "We will try to find other ways to be helpful," he said.

COUNTRY: CONGO, THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE (92%); LATIN AMERICA (79%); ARGENTINA (79%); UNITED STATES (79%); EUROPE (79%); HAITI (79%); RUSSIAN FEDERATION (72%); EASTERN EUROPE (57%); FRANCE (56%);
TEXT: WITH THE arrival of James D. Wolfensohn this month, the World Bank will have at its head a man well-equipped to deal with what is arguably the most destructive economic condition hurting low- and middle-income countries -- flight capital. I'm talking about money that moves out of developing and transitional economies into Western bank accounts by means illegal or undocumented. This is not the same as Western speculative capital that flows in and out of emerging markets. That's perfectly legal. Flight capital is hot money from African, Latin American, eastern European and former Soviet countries surreptitiously passing by collusive and illicit means into New York, Miami, London, Paris, Hamburg and Swiss banks. In the process, it distorts free trade, negates foreign aid, worsens inflation, diminishes tax revenues, undermines structural adjustment, delays and imperils democracy and firmly entrenches poverty. Shouldn't a situation that has bled hundreds of billions of dollars, perhaps a half-trillion, from the world's poor receive diligent attention? Theoretically, yes, but how do you solve a problem that most political and economic leaders scarcely want to admit exists? Published financial statistics provide no reliable measure of flight capital, but privately conducted analyses indicate that its magnitude is on the order of $ 50 billion to $ 80 billion annually.  This exceeds the yearly total of foreign aid appropriations of Western governments. Furthermore, a dollar remaining in a developing economy is easily worth several dollars of external assistance. If more money comes out as flight capital than is allocated as foreign aid, and if the deleterious impact of flight capital is a multiple of sums spent on foreign aid, then something is very wrong with the way we are dealing with development issues. Flight capital has impoverished many countries and virtually destroyed others. Zaire has been squeezed back into the 19th century through the disappearance from official coffers of billions of dollars in mineral revenues and external aid. Argentina has experienced flight capital since the 1800s. South Africa suffered from a large flow of flight capital over the past decade, as political violence grew and majority rule approached. Russia has exported so much flight capital -- an estimated $ 50 billion over five years -- that it is difficult to find much evidence of the funds thus far provided by the West. Between Papa Doc, Baby Doc and the generals, Haiti has been bled dry. The list goes on. There are three principal means by which flight capital moves across borders. Black market currency deals coupled with petty smuggling is the smaller part of the problem. Official misappropriation, that is, theft by government officers is a bigger problem. When a dictator, for example Zaire's Mobutu, wants to stash money overseas, he may simply direct the central bank to effect the transfer, usually out of an offshore reserves account. A corrupt leader without dictatorial powers may use a middleman to negotiate the transaction, usually in return for some official concession or contract. Both result in depletion of the country's external reserves, enhancement of the leaders' foreign wealth -- and no questions asked by recipient Western financial institutions. At roughly $ 10 billion to $ 20 billion annually, official misappropriation is not insignificant, and this figure does not include any of the oil-rich kingdoms and sultanates where what is and isn't flight capital is rather moot. The most widely used but deeply concealed means of generating flight capital, however, is trade mispricing, a common element in international transactions. It is particularly preferred in the private sector because it is invisible and tax free. Typically, the owner or manager of a business conspires with the overseas seller of imports or buyer of exports to include an undocumented commission ("kickback," "tangenti," "dessous-de-table") on the transaction, and the excess funds generated are deposited into an overseas bank account. For example, most traders dealing with Central and South America know that, more often than not, bananas come out with invoices showing less than the real price while linerboard to manufacture export cartons goes in over-invoiced. And, of course, mispricing and misappropriation frequently come together, as with a $ 7 million shipment of U.S. wheat that ended up costing Ivory Coast $ 70 million. Manipulation of trade values occurs on some 30 to 60 percent of import and export transactions of many countries, especially in Latin America and Africa. Commission levels commonly range from 5 to 15 percent. Diversion of 100 percent of the proceeds of some exports out of Russia and other republics of the former Soviet Union is especially troubling to these economies at the present time. Drainage out of poorer countries and transitional economies by the mechanism of trade mispricing alone is on the order of $ 30 billion to $ 50 billion annually. For years, World Bank and IMF officials have sold economic reform programs to poorer countries using the argument, among others, that with correct economic policies flight capital accumulated overseas will in reasonable measure flow back. To the contrary, it is evident that, once out, flight capital rarely returns. The only significant exception is Mexico, largely because it is the only Third World country bordering on a major industrialized democracy. One big reason why few people want to deal with flight capital is that blame lies with both those who generate it and those who solicit and receive it. Flight capital is cooperation among the world's powerful for exploitation of the world's weak. The fact is that for every illegal dollar, pound, franc or mark that moves out of poorer countries, there is a Western trader, manufacturer or financier that directly or indirectly facilitates its receipt. How, then, is it possible to curtail this problem, when many vested interests in richer and poorer countries prefer the status quo? Five reforms would help to ground flight capital: Require the World Bank and IMF -- and urge other international institutions and aid donors -- to strengthen provisions in their own contracts to make flight capital arising from multilateral and bilateral funding onerous and improbable. This will set a tone that will eventually affect private contracts as well. Require countries receiving World Bank and IMF funding to adopt measures that maximize the transparency of trade transactions, such as trade inspection services coupled with uncomplicated buyer/seller declarations. Removing the invisibility of kickbacks removes most kickbacks. Encourage multinational corporations worldwide to adopt policies barring over- and under-invoicing. Securing orders at the expense of the poor forestalls market growth and is in the long term self-defeating. Influence Western bankers -- at the minimum -- to cease soliciting flight capital from foreign countries. Leave bank secrecy laws in place but forego abetting the outflow of money contrary to most nations' laws. Urge Western governments -- with the United States taking the lead -- to combat official misappropriations by more readily freezing the assets of corrupt leaders in or out of office. By contrast to the rest of the developing world, the East Asian private sector has -- for reasons both civic and cultural -- participated far less frequently in illegal transfers of money into Western bank accounts. The Asian decision to keep money at home or in investments that bring profits home has given birth to sound economic policies that protect and multiply retained wealth. While trickle-down economics is at work in Asia, however, trickle-out economics is at work elsewhere. Unfortunately, the East Asian model is not at this time transferable to Africa, Latin America and former communist states. And a disservice is done to other countries by blithely ignoring that flight capital is an overarching reality for much of the globe. Addressing this problem in a sustained manner can correct a serious distortion in the global economy, maximize the benefit of declining foreign aid expenditures and within a reasonable time reverse the course of poverty's growth. Raymond Baker, director of Overecho Associates, has worked extensively on development issues in Latin America, Asia and Africa.

COUNTRY: NIGERIA (99%); UNITED STATES (95%); AFRICA (94%); WESTERN AFRICA (79%);
TEXT: In the world according to Nigeria's military rulers, the United States is carrying out a plot hatched long ago to destroy black Africa's most populous country. In addition, the government insists that it did not annul the June 1993 presidential election, which was to return the nation to civilian rule. And one more thing: Nigerians snared in wrongdoing abroad are not really Nigerians. They are posing as Nigerians because they long to be identified with West Africa's most powerful country. With a blitz of revisionist history, Nigeria's military has undertaken to combat international outrage after it executed nine opponents, including playwright Ken Saro-Wiwa, last month. The campaign has included a video titled "Not in Our Character," a flurry of rallies -- including a Million Man March -- and creation of a 50-man committee whose main task is to buff Nigeria's image. Those in power "engage in a total distortion of facts," said Nosa Igiebor, editor of Tell, an opposition magazine. "They portray themselves as victims, and they actually believe that. All of this is supposed to be a substitute for substantive changes." Such campaigns are nothing new to the estimated 100 million people of Nigeria. During nearly three decades in power, military rulers repeatedly have fashioned similar efforts to fight foreign critics. The most recent was the War on Indiscipline and Corruption that Gen. Sani Abacha launched after taking power in late 1993. But that effort did little to distract foreign governments and human rights groups, who continued to lambaste the regime as one of sub-Saharan Africa's most abusive and corrupt. That criticism reached a zenith last month after Abacha's Provisional Ruling Council confirmed death sentences on Saro-Wiwa and the others, convicted in connection with the slayings of four traditional leaders last year. The nine were hanged 10 days after their trial ended. Threats of sanctions that accompanied the resulting international anger goaded Nigeria into its propaganda war, the centerpiece being a huge pro-government demonstration earlier this month. Dubbed Nigeria's version of the Louis Farrakhan-led Million Man March on Washington in October, it featured hundreds of thousands of Nigerians descending on Abuja, the federal capital. Officials maintained that the march was planned by ordinary citizens, although the government arranged for the participants to fly free to the capital, provided food money and placards and promised some demonstrators up to $ 50. Many demonstrators admitted they did not comprehend their placards; some held them upside down. Nigeria has made the United States and Britain primary targets of such rallies. Nigeria's most severe Western critics, they threatened stiff sanctions and recalled their ambassadors after the executions. "America wants to control us," said Walter Ofonagoro, the minister of information and culture, during a session with foreign reporters this month. "The Cold War is over, so they think we have to obey whatever they tell us." Ofonagoro, Ivy League-educated, described a "secret trade war" that he said the United States is waging against Nigeria. As for the persistent perception that the country's military rulers annuled the 1993 vote, "The courts canceled the election," he said. The reported winner, businessman Moshood Abiola, was imprisoned. "The judge said the vote was rife with irregularities. It was not a free and fair election," said Ofonagoro. In fact, then-ruler Ibrahim Babangida, who had repeatedly pushed back the vote, wiped out the election, charging that the proceedings were a fraud. The action prompted the United States to halt aid. Nigeria's rulers also are scrambling to cleanse the image of Nigerians living abroad. In recent years, hundreds have been arrested on drug charges and for engaging in fraudulent schemes, making many countries wary of awarding them visas. But in the video "Not in Our Character," Col. Ike Nwosu suggested that there has been a mistake. "What has happened," the colonel said, "is that people want to associate themselves with being Nigerians, with the result that when they want to engage in nefarious activities they use Nigeria as a cover." The video, which purports to provide historical context for Nigeria's economic and social crises, acknowledges that the nation is far from perfect but asserts that malfeasance and corruption are "not in our character." The video blames economic woes on "internationally imposed economic policies," a slap at World Bank and International Monetary Fund efforts to help Nigeria right its economy during the 1980s. The video also assails foreign governments for criticizing Nigeria's stumbling attempts to establish democracy, calling such nations "disingenuous and dishonest." The narrator insists that it took the United States and Britain "centuries . . . to produce viable liberal democratic institutions." Ultimately, the narrator says, "most of the problems that confront Nigeria today are rooted in our colonial history." Nigeria gained its independence from Britain in 1960; the military has held power for most of the time since then. The propaganda efforts stretch down to an area of southern Nigeria known as Ogoniland, the oil-rich region of Saro-Wiwa and the others executed. Officials in Rivers state, where Ogoniland sits, have invited reporters in to investigate accusations by members of the indigenous Ogoni ethnic group. The Ogonis contend that a rush to extract oil had resulted in environmental devastation of their homeland and that they had been deprived of any economic benefits deriving from the oil production. In an interview, Col. Dauda Musa Komo, the Rivers state administrator, said the government "is not in a defensive mood. . . . We just want people to know the facts." Later he added that "military-bashing has become a fashionable thing. . . . But there is no truth in the accusation that the military [are in charge] just because they want power." Igiebor, the magazine editor, said of the government's public relations effort, "Ordinary Nigerians are not moved by these shenanigans."

COUNTRY: KENYA (99%); AFRICA (93%); EASTERN AFRICA (93%); UGANDA (92%); UNITED STATES (79%);
TEXT: When President Daniel arap Moi flew to Uganda last week for talks with other East African leaders, he traveled in luxury aboard a brand-new private jet that the taxpayers of this cash-strapped country bought last month for about $50 million. As the jet lifted off from the airport, it banked over the rutted and potholed two-lane highway from Nairobi to Mombasa, Kenya's major port. A vital artery for business, the road is perhaps the most visible symbol of the dilapidated state of the country's infrastructure. On good days, the going is bumpy. On rainy days the road is impassable. Some opposition leaders and diplomats here assert that the jet and the road illustrate what is wrong with the Government's economic priorities: a longstanding tendency among politicians to let personal prestige outweigh the public interest. President Moi purchased the jet, a sleek Dutch-made Fokker, at the same time that his Government was seeking a $50 million low-interest loan from the World Bank to repair the road. Since newspapers disclosed the purchase of the jet in November, Government officials have argued that the expense is justified because in the past the President has had to take one of Kenya Airway's two jets out of service every time he travels. The airplane is one of several expenditures not listed in Kenya's budget that have jeopardized aid from the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, as well as from other countries, diplomats and officials at international development banks said. The officials and diplomats, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said the jet and two other budget-busting projects of questionable worth have come up during talks this week between the Government and a joint mission from the Bank and the I.M.F. The two sides are trying to hammer out a plan for economic reform that would allow the I.M.F. to release hundreds of millions of dollars in blocked aid. The stakes are high for Kenya, an economic engine for eastern Africa. Hanging in the balance are $200 million in direct aid from the I.M.F. and nearly $166 million in loans from the World Bank for roads and other infrastructure projects that are needed to attract foreign investment. The talks are also being watched by Western countries, including the United States, and several have said the I.M.F.'s decision will be a bellwether for them. Only a fraction of the $800 million donor countries pledged to Kenya in November 1994 has been disbursed because of the stalled negotiations, diplomats said. Neither the I.M.F. nor the World Bank would comment on the talks. But diplomats and people familiar with the talks say the main sticking points have been the Government's inability to stamp out official corruption and the kind of pork-barrel and prestige spending typified by the President's new airplane. Besides the jet, the Government is spending about $85 million to build an international airport at Eldoret, the heart of the President's home state in eastern Kenya. Parliament never approved the project -- the money was tucked away in a special debt service fund in this year's spending plan. It was also hidden from World Bank auditors who scrutinized the budget until a newspaper reported its existence. The Government has argued that the airport is needed because of an economic boom in the area. The growth there has been fueled in large part by flower merchants, who now truck their goods to Nairobi, over pitted roads, for air shipment to Europe. In another deal done without competitive bidding or legislative approval, the Government recently awarded a multi-million-dollar contract to a French company to manufacture identification cards. Paradoxically, the controversies over the airport and the jet come to light as Kenya has made big strides over the last three years toward improving its moribund economy. Last week, the Government suspended a score of high-ranking port officials on corruption charges. Urged by the I.M.F., it has also eliminated import licenses, squeezed the money supply and liberalized trade. As a result, interest rates are down, and the economy grew by 5 percent in 1995, after several years of stagnation. Inflation, which had hit 100 percent in 1993, stayed below 7 percent in 1995. But the population continues to grow faster than the economy, local economists said. So Kenyans, with an average annual income of $1,200, are in reality getting poorer. "It's a mixed bag," said one diplomat who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "They would not have achieved what they achieved last year if they hadn't been doing certain things right. But the question is, would they have had 8 percent growth without the corruption."

COUNTRY: FRANCE (98%); AFRICA (98%); WESTERN AFRICA (95%); COTE D'IVOIRE (94%); EUROPEAN UNION MEMBER STATES (93%); BURKINA FASO (92%); EUROPE (92%); BENIN (92%); TOGO (79%); SENEGAL (79%); NIGER (79%); SUB SAHARAN AFRICA (79%); CENTRAL AFRICA (79%); MALI (79%); EASTERN EUROPE (51%);
TEXT: Despite political turmoil and tightened international aid budgets, France's former colonies in West Africa have begun to shake off a decade of economic doldrums, benefiting from a temporary combination of good luck and monetary reform. World commodity prices rose suddenly in 1994, boosting economies greatly dependent on exports of cocoa, rubber, cotton, tropical woods and other primary products. As a result, seven former French West African colonies -- Benin, Burkina Faso, Ivory Coast, Mali, Niger, Senegal and Togo -- posted average gross domestic product gains of 6 percent in 1995. Significantly, the economy of the group's locomotive, Ivory Coast, reversed years of recession and grew by 7 percent. These results were just what specialists predicted when France shocked 14 former sub-Saharan African colonies in January 1994 by forcing a 50 percent devaluation of their common currency -- the first realignment between the French franc and African franc since 1948. But just as specialists also had forecast, the overall performance of France's former Central African possessions was less impressive, even though they are potentially better off. No statistics on their economic performance have been issued for 1995, which experts interpret as an indication of unresolved political difficulties, bloated state payrolls and economic mismanagement. Many French-speaking African nations initially had feared the 1994 devaluation was the first step toward radical reduction of the generous aid that successive regimes in Paris had underwritten since the countries gained independence in 1960. French-speaking Africa had a record of government corruption, coups and stagnant growth, and France was confronted by its most serious economic crisis since World War II, a combination many analysts believed would lead the government of prime minister Edouard Balladur to carry out just such an agonizing reappraisal. But such fears disappeared last May when Jacques Chirac, a politician with a wide network of African friends, was elected president of France. So popular was his victory in French-speaking Africa that an Ivory Coast newspaper splashed the words "We Won" on its front page. Chirac single-handedly went to bat for Africa despite France's record unemployment, high interest rates and worrisome budget deficit. Alone among Western countries, France at his insistence virtually has maintained its level of assistance to the region at about $ 9 billion a year. That aid, largest among the Group of Seven industrialized democracies, is almost three times more than the slashed U.S. commitment. Last June, Chirac also forced reluctant European Union partners to renew for five years an annual $ 3.44 billion aid package for the southern hemisphere despite their preference for helping the emerging democracies of Eastern Europe, who are themselves potential EU members. In return, the EU donors insisted on closely linking aid to African countries to their respect for democratic practices, human rights and good governance. The stipulations signaled that exasperated donors were no longer routinely willing to condone the excesses of authoritarian mismanagement, dictatorial rule and human rights abuses. Although the new toughness in European aid decisions seems to have brought a measure of reform, African specialists have urged caution, pointing to some backsliding on commitments to fair elections, multi-party democracy and rigorous financial accounting. Indeed, the Rwandan government was rebuffed when it expelled 39 international humanitarian relief agencies and asked the European Union to deliver directly the tens of millions of dollars in aid money the agencies had previously administered. On the human rights front, Cameroon, a haven for extremists from Rwanda's Hutu ethnic majority, arrested Col. Theoneste Bagosera last month on charges of instigating the murder of about a half-million members of the Tutsi minority in 1994. He and 11 other former senior Rwandan officials wanted by the International War Crimes Tribunal investigating the slaughter were to be transferred to The Hague to face trial. In another example, the International Monetary Fund froze aid negotiations with Niger immediately after a military coup ousted the country's first democratically elected president in January. The EU quickly suspended its assistance. France interrupted all but humanitarian aid. The coup leaders caved in this month, agreeing to set new, democratic presidential elections for September as the price for resuming the aid. Although Chirac was initially critical of the devaluation, once in office he embraced the Balladur reforms, subordinating bilateral French aid to acceptance of IMF and World Bank reforms aimed at cutting bureaucratic fat and straightening out tangled finances. Chirac also renewed France's commitment to further democracy, first enunciated in 1990. "The time of gifts is over," said a senior French specialist, explaining this year's 3 percent cutback in French aid. "The Africans know we cannot help them on the same scale as during the past 35 years." Officials tracking French African economies at the Paris-based Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development decry the region's lack of meaningful private capital investment. Joao Vale de Almeida, a EU spokesman dealing with Africa, said he is worried that the "lack of a success story" on the continent could lead to steep aid cuts when the present agreement expires in 2000. Stoking such pessimism is the failure of concerted donor efforts to force reform on France's former Central African possessions, which include the oil-producing states of Cameroon, Congo and Gabon. The Congo is potentially rich, but has mortgaged its oil revenues until 2012 and refused to reduce its bloated civil service and state corporation payrolls. The finances of Gabon are also precarious, as are those of Cameroon. All three countries have resisted full implementation of IMF reforms. In north-central Africa, Chad is only now emerging from decades of little wars, sometimes involving Libya, at other times pitting southern Bantu farmers against northern Saharan nomads. This month, a referendum approved a constitution providing for a strong presidency, in a significant step toward returning Chad to a state of law. But such a back-to-basics approach has limits, as the politics of Nigeria's tiny neighbor, Benin, demonstrated last month. One-time Marxist Mathieu Kerekou was elected president, despite a messy economic and human rights record in his 17-year reign ending in 1990.

COUNTRY: GHANA (95%); WESTERN AFRICA (93%); AFRICA (92%); BURKINA FASO (79%); COTE D'IVOIRE (79%); NIGER (79%); MALI (79%); GUINEA (79%);
TEXT: Just beyond the yellow "no trespassing" sign, a burly fellow who calls himself Jangu-man stood ankle deep in chemical-laced black muck. He scooped some of it into a wooden gutter with a dented old army helmet and washed it, letting promising particles gather into a porous brown cloth. Quicksand-like pits have claimed the lives of at least five young men working in the moonscape around the Obuasi gold fields this year, and security forces have killed three and arrested 17 others. But Jangu-man, whose name means "wild one," displayed the confidence of a giddy gambler with nothing left to lose, someone for whom the lure of gold was stronger than the fear of getting shot. Working on the run-off from soil that has already been processed with cyanide and arsenic at Ghana's leading industrial mine, Jangu-man is one of thousands of illegal gold miners across the country who often risk their health and their lives for a chance to strike it rich, or more often, just to keep themselves fed. The men gather around large-scale, licensed mining operations, living off what the big companies throw away or have not yet gotten to. There is plenty to go around, and Ghana, the former Gold Coast, is rapidly becoming a leading producer. Its Ashanti Goldfields Co. is now the world's 10th biggest producer, with its annual yield having grown in the past decade from 200 ounces to nearly 1 million. Ashanti, the only West African company listed on the New York Stock Exchange, is leading West Africa into a gold boom that could help the region pull itself out of years of economic decline. Ashanti's expertise is being sought by such regional nations as Mali, Niger, Guinea, Ivory Coast, Burkina Faso and others that have watched Ghana's growth rate climb and its status soar in international circles that have often looked on West African governments with disdain because of their historic reputation for mismanagement and corruption. But fears are mounting over the growing tension between the illegal miners and mining companies in Ghana, as unemployed youths become more desperate to grab a piece of the wealth they see being extracted from around their villages. Economic reforms inspired by the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund have helped to boost foreign investment here, but they have also inspired resentment among local inhabitants who have reaped little from free-market innovations. "There's no doubt that gold mining is precipitating a fairly steady increase in social tensions," a Western diplomat said. "This is not a trickle-down type of prospecting," he added. "It has enriched a small number of people at the top but certainly not that many at the bottom. "You see some fancy cars around town, nice houses, but the lower 40 percent of the population is certainly no better off than they were a generation ago," he said. At least 1,000 illegal miners, known as galamsey, a local word that means "sell it quick," armed themselves with blow guns, clubs, knives and machetes last month and attacked Ashanti security men who tried to run them off a particularly rich site. The miners also stole about 50,000 chickens from the company's poultry farm, ransacked the buildings and injured three policemen. "The whites, they are making all the money; the government must institute a law to employ the local inhabitants here," said Blay Marshall Wellington, a secondary school teacher in Tarkwa, a town south of Obuasi. Local residents complain that foreign mining companies overlook them in favor of employees from Accra, the capital. Gold extraction and processing, however, has become increasingly mechanized and often requires the skills of an educated work force. Few local youths are qualified for jobs at Ashanti, having discarded their pencils for shovels when they were as young as 10 years old. The galamsey have been prospecting since Ashanti was established 100 years ago. Their gold fever drives them to extremes even though many of them earn little more than a few dollars a month after laboring six days a week, from sunrise to sunset, in the tropical heat. Five galamsey died of carbon monoxide poisoning in March while trying to pump water from an underground trench. In April, a group of illegal miners ransacked a meteorological station for thermometers containing mercury -- a toxic element they use with their bare hands to process the gold. Mercury can penetrate the skin to lodge in body tissue and bone and can seriously damage the nervous system. In January, the military was called in to drive more than 4,000 galamsey from a forest reserve after they had cut down 55 acres of trees in two months while prospecting. "Even if there are a lot of jobs, I'd do this because I find this work very lucrative," said Anthony Yeboah, 35. "Farming is too hard. With cocoa it is five to 10 years before you have a product." The illegal miners sometimes find themselves ignored by their own communities even though they often bring more money into their villages than the big mines do. "One of the problems is when you are not with one of these companies people will not even look at you," said John Kweku, 21, an illegal miner. The government of President Jerry Rawlings has responded to the tension between the galamsey and mining companies by boosting security at the mines and granting more concessions to individual miners. In effect, the government seems to be trying to strike a balance between its use of tax revenues and foreign exchange generated by large-scale gold mining to boost development and its efforts to appease the galamsey so they do not scare off foreign investors. Ghana's gross domestic product has increased by an annual average of 4 percent over the past four years. Mineral exports have accounted for about 40 percent of the country's gross foreign exchange earnings since 1992, compared to about 15 percent in the 1980s. "This is one of the world's richest gold areas," the Western diplomat said. "With the new extracting processes, West Africa will be one of three or four of the significant gold-bearing areas in the world." Mining companies from South Africa, Australia, Canada and the United States that operate here often recruit their own security because many local police receive hush money from the galamsey. South African companies are particularly interested in keeping good relations with the illegal miners. "They knew enough that they couldn't do it a la South Africa or there would have been major trouble," said one South African miner, referring to racial tension there prior to the end of white minority rule in 1993. "You are running the risk of the sort of the political brand of 'Here come all those racist South Africans kicking all the locals off-site.' " Mining companies in Ghana routinely pay high compensation to communities displaced by surface mining. But the funds often end up lining the pockets of local chiefs and district assemblymen, not in the hands of the most needy. "It is only the galamsey that have saved the situation" in many communities," said school principal E.K. Ayensu. "And now the mining companies are asking them to move away from the concessions."

COUNTRY: AFRICA (94%); UGANDA (94%); UNITED STATES (92%);
TEXT: DURING HER recent trip to Africa, Hillary Clinton visited nations that belie the basket-case stereotypes often attached to the entire continent. In Uganda, for example, she praised that nation's democratization, its economic reforms, the "stunning growth rate" of its economy and its commitment to primary education for all. Whether Uganda can make good on that revolutionary promise of universal primary schooling is to a large extent being decided in Washington this week and next. Top officials from the Clinton administration and counterparts from other wealthy nations, meeting at the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, are debating how to implement a debt relief initiative for developing countries. The terms of debate are dry, but what's at stake is the possibility of reform and renewal. Many developing countries are so burdened by debt that a huge portion of their national income, including the aid they receive, is immediately recycled to banks and governments to the north. Uganda spends about seven times as much on debt repayment as on primary education, while about one-third of its children can't go to school at all -- although education is a crucial prerequisite for development. Blame this heavy burden first and foremost on the poor countries themselves, and on the corrupt regimes that squandered aid year after year. Nations where such regimes still hold sway should be cut off. But last fall, with strong U.S. leadership, the world's leading lenders agreed that nations with a strong commitment to, and record of, reform should get some debt relief, or else even the best policies wouldn't save them. Now lenders will decide which countries will benefit, when and by how much. Some officials want to move slowly, either because they never liked debt relief in the first place or to use the promise of forgiveness as leverage to promote further reform. But reformers throughout the developing world need evidence that this debt initiative is for real -- that swallowing the medicine of economic reform really will bring rewards. For that credibility to be achieved, Uganda, with its long and impressive track record, should be given as much help as possible, and other deserving nations should follow swiftly behind.

COUNTRY: CONGO, THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE (93%); CENTRAL AFRICA (79%);
TEXT: Every day, Western businessmen in suits and ties risk riding in creaking elevators at the Ministry of Mines, an imposing 20-story building on the main street of this capital. They wait on chairs with foam protruding from the cushions for audiences with officials of the new Government in order to buy the right to go into malaria-infested jungles. A Western mining executive, standing before a geological map hanging on the wall outside the minister's office, explained why. "This is all money," he said, his hand sweeping an arc over the eastern rim of this vast country, passing over symbols for cobalt, zinc, magnesium, iron, copper, diamonds and gold. The businessman would not give his name, nor that of his company. If he could have, he would probably have denied his presence in the country. His partner in front of the map would not utter a single word while a reporter was present. The stealth and secrecy reflect a fiercely competitive atmosphere here as mining companies vie for concessions in "potentially the wealthiest country in the world," as the man in front of the map called it. No mineral trader wants to let a competitor know where his lode is. An Australian mining executive said there might be 250 tons of gold, worth $3 billion, to be mined in Congo, the Central African giant formerly called Zaire. At the moment, the gold riches are virtually untouched, he said. Congo is believed to have 80 percent of the world's cobalt reserves. Its copper mines are said to be capable of yielding 500,000 tons a year; they now yield no more than 50,000. The wealth has always been here, of course. But the avarice of the country's longtime former ruler, Mobutu Sese Seko -- bribes were required to get in, and then a share of the action went to a Mobutu crony once business became profitable -- scared away foreign investors for decades. Now, after the collapse of Mr. Mobutu's rule, it is seen as a new day here for business. Laurent Kabila, who was sworn in as president last month after an eight-month push ending the country's civil war, has a guerrilla past and uncertain plans for the future. But his ministers talk like capitalists and have vowed to end corruption. "Everything I've seen shows they want to govern honestly, that they want foreign investment," said W. S. Turner, general manager of Anvil Mining, an Australian company that has signed a copper-mining contract with the new Government. "As long as that philosophy is there, we're happy to be part of it." The new Government has slashed the fee for a diamond trading license to $50,000 from $150,000. "We are trying not to be too greedy; we want to be humble," Finance Minister Mwana Mawampanga said. Besides, the state was not really losing anything in cutting the fee; the money, he said, used to go largely into the pockets of Mr. Mobutu and his friends, not into the treasury. There is also a desire for more companies to trade in diamonds. "We need competition, so our people get the best prices for their products," said Mr. Mawampanga, who has advanced economics degrees from Penn State and the University of Kentucky. One monopoly the Government says it intends to break is that of De Beers Consolidated Mines, the South African diamond group under the Anglo American Corporation that was the only company to buy the production of the Congolese state diamond company during the Mobutu era. The Government has not yet decided what it will do with the diamond-mining company, the Societe Miniere de Bakwang, known as MIBA, or with the state mining company known as Gecamines. But officials said in recent interviews that the Government was exploring the possibility of selling large interests in both to one or more international companies. "We want a market economy," Mr. Mawampanga said. "But we want to ask those companies who come to invest in our country to be good corporate citizens." The potential for outside investment extends beyond the nation's mineral wealth, with staggering possibilities for public works contracts. In a country of perhaps 50 million people in an area comparable to the United States east of the Mississippi, there is less than 1,500 miles of paved road. Much of the country is not served by telephone. But for now, the focus of the action is in the ground. From Poland to South Africa, from Canada and the United States to Australia and Japan, the mining companies are coming, small, medium and large. The Ministry of Mines says possible investors include another Australian company, Rhodes Mining, as well as several Canadian ones like the Barrick Gold Corporation and the Caledonia Mining Corporation. A Government mining official, Jean-Claude Muyambo, said that many of the companies were trying to take advantage of the lack of experience at the Ministry of Mines. Mr. Muyambo, who is 32, was a human rights lawyer until the new Minister of Mines, Mututulo Kambale, a former professor of English at a teachers' college, asked him to help out. "They think they are smarter than we are," said Mr. Muyambo, whose dark suit, white shirt and tie would have blended in at a New York City law firm but who looked alien in his squalid office -- the carpets beyond threadbare, the walls stained and wires protruding from holes in the ceiling where there should be light fixtures. He said the companies proposed contracts that gave them the right to explore, mine and trade, while paying an amount based only on the right to explore. "When we tell them something is wrong with the contract, they think we want bribes," Mr. Muyambo said. With the stakes so high and Government officials so poor, how is it going to be possible to stop the corruption? "It's a very good question," Bernard Maneno, a senior official in the Ministry of Mines, said with a heavy sigh. But the Government will have to do so if it is serious about attracting foreign investment, Mr. Turner of Anvil Mining said. "On the technical side, the risks are very low," he said, adding that the mineral deposits were high grade, easy to find, easy to mine and easy to process. "The big issue, he continued, "is the political risk. The Government doesn't have to do very much to create the right political climate." A start for Mr. Kabila, Mr. Turner said, would be to create a multiparty democracy. That, he said, would help bring in the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, whose financing may be required for large-scale mining projects. And a democracy could give rise to the rules and stable institutions that would spur business confidence in investing in Congo. But the new President has for the present banned political party activity and declared elections to be two years away. So for now, potential investors simply remain hopeful his Government will succeed, and that hope has encouraged all manner of participants in a new gold rush. The other day, Al Andersen, a missionary with the Baptist International Church of Congo, was in the Ministry of Mines in search of a concession. The church's land, it seems, holds a gold deposit. Where? Mr. Andersen, as if taking a cue from the big mining companies' approach, put his hands over the map to cover up the area, in a gesture of mock secrecy. "I don't want everyone to know where our mines are," he said. "Nobody else is here yet. All the big guys are over there," he said, pointing to the east.

COUNTRY: KENYA (95%); CONGO, THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE (79%);
TEXT: The International Monetary Fund, stepping up efforts to combat corruption in the developing world, has adopted a new policy of denying financial assistance to countries where graft threatens to undermine their economic recovery programs. And showing that it means business, the IMF -- which in the past has based most of its lending decisions strictly on economic criteria -- is cutting off a $ 220 million loan to Kenya because of the refusal of Kenyan authorities to clean up pervasive bribery and self-enrichment. Kenya's currency has plunged as much as 20 percent this week as a result. The moves are among the most significant in a series of recent measures taken against corruption by aid agencies, Western governments and international organizations. They come in the wake of criticism aimed at the IMF and other aid donors over the blind eye that they allegedly turned toward rampant bribe-taking in Zaire during much of Mobutu Sese Seko's 32-year reign. Mobutu's corruption and repression spurred a rebellion that toppled him in May, and the nation was renamed Congo. The IMF's new policy, enshrined in guidelines approved Monday by its board, does not mean that IMF money will be withheld from any country where payoffs are common. Rather, it amounts to a warning that the IMF may pull the plug on a country when it believes corruption to be so corrosive as to endanger the attainment of goals specified in a recovery plan. "Financial assistance from the IMF . . . could be suspended or delayed on account of poor governance," the guidelines state, "if there is reason to believe it could have significant macroeconomic implications that threaten the successful implementation of the program, or if it puts in doubt the purpose of the use of IMF resources." "The guidelines are very important," said Frank Vogl, vice chairman of Transparency International, an anti-corruption advocacy group. "It's long overdue that multilateral organizations involved in financing developing countries place on a par with macro policies the basic soundness of the government institutions with which they're dealing." The cutoff of the loan to Kenya, he added, "sends a signal, especially because the guidelines are being issued at around the same time." Kenyan President Daniel arap Moi blasted the IMF's decision as "purely political," according to press reports from Nairobi. The developments reflect a rising determination in Western capitals, especially Washington, to crack down on corruption. IMF Managing Director Michel Camdessus and World Bank President James D. Wolfensohn have vowed in major policy addresses to take action based on research showing that bribe-taking by public officials tends to impede development, because scarce government funds are funneled into unproductive investments to earn payoffs. The guidelines state that the IMF should not "interfere in domestic or foreign politics" of a borrowing country. But they call for its employees to point out the economic consequences of corrupt practices that they may perceive during the periodic consultations they hold with government officials from the IMF's 131 member countries. And in the cases of countries borrowing from the IMF that have been judged to be seriously plagued by corruption, its staff might insist, for example, on "the removal of individuals from involvement in particular operations where corruption had occurred," according to the guidelines. The Kenya loan was suspended late last week because anti-corruption measures the government was taking "fall short of meeting the clearly expressed concerns of IMF member countries in the area of governance," according to an IMF statement. The suspension came just before the board's approval of the guidelines. An IMF official said the move was "probably the first time that we have said openly that governance issues were at stake" in such a decision. The suspension followed the Kenyan government's dismissal of its top customs official, Samuel Chebii, who is widely regarded as a crusader for cleaning up corruption in the nation's notoriously graft-ridden ports.

COUNTRY: KENYA (93%); HONG KONG (92%); UNITED STATES (92%); ASIA (79%); CAMBODIA
TEXT: At their last annual meeting for the world's finance ministers, the World Bank's president, James D. Wolfensohn, and the International Monetary Fund's managing director, Michel Camdessus, announced that for the first time they would use their leverage with poorer nations to stamp out corruption and to promote better governance. As the finance ministers prepare to gather in Hong Kong next month for the next annual meeting, the first fruits of that new policy are starting to become visible. This month the Monetary Fund sent the Kenya shilling and the Nairobi stock market into a tailspin. It suspended a $220 million loan to Kenya after President Daniel arap Moi failed to create the powerful new anticorruption authority the fund had demanded and to reinstate Samuel Chebii, who had been dismissed as Commissioner for Customs and Excise. Mr. Chebii had earned a formidable reputation for combating graft, to the Government's evident discomfort. At the same time, the fund's executive board, which represents its member governments, formally agreed that all such assistance to third-world countries can be suspended as a matter of course in the future if government corruption is found to be having an adverse effect on a nation's economic development. The World Bank uses the faith and credit of its member countries to borrow inexpensively on financial markets and lends that money to poorer nations. The fund makes loans to distressed governments provided that they adopt policies it favors. While the fund said it was not changing its traditional view that reducing inflation, controlling Government spending and promoting "macroeconomic stability" remain the principal keys to growth, it made clear that it would put increased emphasis on fighting corruption and promoting better governance in countries it aids. Financial assistance "could be suspended or delayed on account of poor governance, if there is reason to believe it could have significant macroeconomic implications," state new guidelines on governance questions adopted by the fund's board earlier this month. The fund also showed a new readiness this month to interpret what it means by good governance quite broadly when it persuaded Romania to cancel a planned $1 billion purchase of 96 Cobra attack helicopters from an American company, Bell Helicopter, a division of Textron Inc. Romania had hoped the purchase of sophisticated American military hardware would speed its entry into NATO, although the alliance's secretary general, Javier Solana, said the purchase was unnecessary. The fund contended that such a large arms purchase risked disrupting the economic reforms to which Romania had agreed in return for a loan, by shifting money away from health and education programs that the fund considers more important for the country's successful transition to capitalism. Last year the fund also showed its teeth in Asia by suspending disbursements on a $120 million loan to Cambodia for six months after anticipated Government revenues from logging concessions did not materialize. Next month, it will be the World Bank's turn to publish a three-pronged plan for combatting corruption and promoting better governance. The bank already took the first step last year when it tightened procurement rules governing contracts financed by the $19 billion in loans it disburses annually, saying it will disqualify companies it considers corrupt and require those bidding for contracts to open their books to the bank's auditors. The bank also is to recruit more procurement specialists to oversee the awarding of contracts, at an annual cost of $13 million, and to encourage third-world governments to include a pledge in projects it finances to take steps to prevent bribery. Finally, it plans to step up assistance to governments developing anticorruption strategies. It is already helping several countries develop strategies, including Latvia, Tanzania, Uganda and Ukraine. Unlike the fund -- which usually makes just one loan to a government and which can suspend it at will -- the bank tends to have several loans outstanding at the same time in various sectors of any third-world country's economy where conditions may vary considerably. So it plans a more selective approach to delinquent countries, making decisions on its lending on a project-by-project basis until it is satisfied with the way they are all being run. "You will see us giving a much higher profile to governance and corruption concerns in a selective way, delaying disbursement until we are satisfied, or suspending it altogether" said Masood Ahmed, who is coordinating the bank's new policies in this area. In an early example of this approach, Mr. Wolfensohn recently delayed the $70 million second installment of a $150 million loan to a Kenyan energy project because of doubts about the way it was being run. He also delayed a health services loan to Kenya until the bank was satisfied with procurement procedures. The bank also has suspended operations in several countries where it believes its money is unlikely to benefit ordinary people because of endemic corruption and inefficiency -- including Nigeria, the Sudan, Congo and Afghanistan. In deciding to fight corruption and promote better government, both institutions have had to reinterpret requirements in their own bylaws that all lending should be based on economic considerations alone and should take no account of a country's politics. In its new governance guidelines, the fund makes clear that its judgments still "should not be influenced by the nature of a political regime of a country, nor should it interfere in domestic or foreign politics of any member." But it also concedes that staff "may need to be prepared to face some tension in the working relationship with country authorities in specific cases potentially involving corrupt practices." Both institutions now contend that corruption and bad governance are in themselves obstacles to economic development, as are poor education, inadequate infrastructure and an ineffective health care system, all of which they have previously accepted as within the scope of their responsibility.

COUNTRY: KENYA (94%); RWANDA (92%); AFRICA (92%); EASTERN AFRICA (92%); UGANDA (92%);
TEXT: The International Monetary Fund and the World Bank have provided the summer's most welcome change in the way global finance and business operate. But they have also furnished a jarring reminder to prognosticators that things often fail to work out as we think they will. Kenya is at the center of the international bankers' reforms and the failure of past conventional wisdom. Because of corruption, the two world financial institutions have suspended loans to the government of President Daniel arap Moi, who also faces bloody street protests because of his dictatorial rule. When I lived in Kenya in the early 1970s as Africa correspondent for The Post, there were two firm bits of conventional wisdom about that beautiful East African nation: One was that Moi, a politician of limited intellectual ability who hailed from a minor tribe, was a transitional figure who could not survive long as president. The other was that Kenya's resources, international visibility and dynamic society should enable it to overcome its crippling internal ethnic rivalries and become a great African success story. Neither prediction looks very good today. Moi's unshakable hold on power for nearly 20 years has been accompanied by a steady decline in the nation's stability and prosperity. There can be little doubt now that the two factors are intimately connected. When the Central Intelligence Agency commissioned an independent study on why states fail two years ago, political leadership was listed among the leading indicators of national catastrophe. East Africa today provides confirmation of this in several ways. Uganda and Rwanda, after enduring terrible bloodlettings and economic collapse, have emerged from their times of trouble with secure and assertive political leadership. Rwanda's Paul Kagame and Uganda's Yoweri Museveni have, through their support of change in the Congo, sketched the basis for a promising regional alliance that is likely to gain increasing international support. But they still must overcome the other failed-state criteria the CIA-commissioned study lists: infant mortality, population pressure, closed trade borders, weather, ethnic tensions and more. The study recommended an official "watch list" of countries that get in the trouble zone. It is unclear if the agency ever established such an indelicate document for policymakers. A Michelin guide to political turmoil could be a bestseller in international circles. But you can understand the agency's reluctance to acknowledge that it is watching for three-star hellholes to come. Imagine the hurt feelings, and expulsions of spooks, that would follow. Would a country like Kenya make such a list today, despite all the advantages it still has over its neighbors? It is a measure of Kenya's intrinsic strength that it has been going downhill every year for two decades in the eyes of many of its citizens, former residents and visitors, but still works as a center of global tourism and as a regional headquarters for business and international organizations. The pragmatism of founding President Jomo Kenyatta and his advisers -- as well as the munificence of Kenya's glorious wildlife reserves, tea and coffee plantations and seaside resorts -- gave Moi a substantial heritage to squander after he came to power in 1978, on Kenyatta's death. Moi had been chosen as Kenyatta's vice president in part to secure a tribal alliance between Kenyatta's Kikuyu and Moi's Kalinjin followers. The Kikuyu politicians who squabbled over succeeding Kenyatta let Moi come to power on the theory that they could easily manipulate him and toss him aside later. That was a disastrous miscalculation. Moi divided and conquered the Kikuyu, shuffling the army and internal security commands into the hands of his tribesmen and allies. He let corruption flourish to buy off his more pliable opponents, using harsher measures against others. But Moi's misrule is now being challenged in the streets of Nairobi, where his police killed five demonstrators in one recent protest, and in the board rooms of the world's leading international financial institutions. In a departure from past practice, the International Monetary Fund this month suspended a $ 220 million loan to Kenya because Moi failed to create a strong anti-corruption authority demanded by the fund. The World Bank has also recently delayed smaller loans to Kenya because of concern about corruption. This apparently coordinated squeeze on official corruption in Kenya -- and presumably elsewhere in the future -- is a welcome innovation. International organizations have for too long averted their eyes and treated corruption as an internal matter beyond their reach. Flagrant corruption that is tolerated or assisted by national governments is not a matter of sovereignty. It is a cancer on the international system as well as on the national state. It should be identified and fought far more quickly than it has been in the past. The predicament becomes even more acute as Russia and China pursue their efforts to integrate into the global economy. The forms of corruption that plague these two ex-centrally planned economies differ, but raise many of the same problems present in Kenya. Corruption on a national scale is a proper target for international condemnation and action as well as intelligence scrutiny.

COUNTRY: KENYA (99%); UNITED STATES (92%); EUROPE (79%); JAPAN (79%);
TEXT: A Kenyan court charged 62 suspects today with robbery and violence during a raid on a police station that began a week of attacks around this port city that some observers said were politically motivated. Despite the political turmoil, the International Monetary Fund said it was sending a team to Kenya for talks on resuming aid. "To show our goodwill in this respect, I have asked a mission to leave immediately for Nairobi," the Fund's managing director, Michel Camdessus, told reporters in Washington. He said the decision followed a personal appeal from President Daniel arap Moi. The I.M.F. suspended a $205 million, three-year loan to Kenya on July 31 citing concerns over corruption. The World Bank followed suit and delayed disbursements. Mr. Moi, 73 and in power since 1978, faces elections later this year for which no date has been set. He had accused the I.M.F. of acting on political grounds. The 62 suspects in Mombasa court were accused of robbing the police station at Likoni on Aug. 13, killing a policeman, stealing weapons including 40 rifles and damaging property. They were also charged with arson and taking an unlawful oath binding them to kill if called on to do so. The maximum penalty for robbery with violence is death. The accused included Amir Hamisi Ali Banda, prayer leader of a mosque south of Mombasa, and Ali Said Chidzondo, chairman of the unregistered National African Democratic Union. All denied the charges and were scheduled to appear again in two weeks. Security forces beat the opposition leader Raila Odinga and damaged his car today when he tried to visit the Likoni police station with other opposition activists, local journalists said. "One of them hit me with the butt of his gun on the side of my head," Mr. Odinga told reporters."This confirms our fears that the Government has something to hide." A police spokesman, Peter Kimanthi, said he was unaware of the incident. But he confirmed that the police had shot and killed a man at Tiwi village south of Mombasa on Wednesday. This took the toll from nine days of violence to 40 dead. Six policemen and seven civilians including five attackers were killed on Aug. 13 in the well-organized attack on the Likoni police station, just south of Mombasa. Mr. Kimanthi said the police recovered a rifle today and 50 rounds of ammunition and arrested 101 people, taking the number of arrests since Aug. 13 to at least 410. President Moi and the opposition have blamed each other for fueling tribal tensions on the coast. Missions of 10 European countries, the United States and Japan welcomed an agreement in principle by Government and opposition to start talks before elections. "We urge both sides to enter into dialogue in the spirit of compromise and with the commitment to agree on reforms necessary to ensure free and fair elections," they said in a statement. The attacks on the coast, the center of Kenya's tourism and its top foreign currency earner, have shaken the industry and tour operators say cancellations have increased. Tourism earned $465 million in 1996 and is Kenya's top employer. About 60 percent of last year's 770,000 tourists went to beaches to the north and south of Mombasa.

COUNTRY: KENYA (99%); UNITED STATES (93%);
TEXT: The United States criticized corruption and violence in Kenya today and warned the government that international donors might not resume aid on the basis of old promises. Gunmen shot and killed two Kenyans in a raid on a church south of the Indian Ocean city of Mombasa today, taking the death toll from 10 days of ethnic attacks in the area to 42. President Daniel arap Moi arrived on his first visit to the turbulent coast. He was due to visit the Mombasa Agricultural Show scheduled to open Monday. U.S. Ambassador Prudence Bushnell said in a hard-hitting speech in Nairobi that "Kenya is sending very mixed signals at a time when it is host to ominous events." She added that Kenyan leaders said they did not want violence while clashes were breaking out in Nairobi, on the Indian Ocean coast and elsewhere. "Kenya's government says it is serious about economic reforms and combating corruption, yet it has chosen to risk economic instability rather than see its promises through to completion," she said. "We hear commitments to free and fair elections, but the political playing field remains decidedly uneven." The violence has rocked Kenya's tourist coast since an Aug. 13 raid on police posts at Likoni, outside Mombasa city. Thousands of people have fled the region south of Mombasa and returned to their homes deeper in Kenya since the troubles began. Coast natives accuse outsiders of taking many of the jobs and homes, and much of the land available along the Kenyan coast. Police have been hunting down thugs armed with rifles and machetes in the past nine days. More than 400 people have been arrested. The church raiders shot into a compound packed with 2,500 people who had taken refuge there, killing a man and a woman and seriously wounding a policeman in the mouth, witnesses said. Bushnell said the government had to choose to reduce services or raise taxes to cover a $ 141 million shortfall in this year's budget because International Monetary Fund aid has been blocked. The Kenyan shilling strengthened today after news that an IMF delegation would arrive Monday in Nairobi to decide on a date for resuming negotiations on a key aid package, which was halted July 31 because of high-level graft. Moi has blamed the opposition for fueling ethnic tensions. The opposition charges that Moi's supporters are responsible for the violence. Moi, 73, in power for 19 years, has promised some political reforms and dialogue but has refused to talk to an opposition-backed alliance that has held rallies since May to support political change.

COUNTRY: KENYA (96%);
TEXT: The political stalemate that has led to violence here over the last six months has been broken, after President Daniel arap Moi's agreement last week with opposition leaders on reforms that would level the playing field somewhat before the coming election. Opposition leaders and diplomats said it remained to be seen if the governing party would carry out the reforms as promised, or if the police and local officials would follow the laws once they were enacted. But as debate began on the bills in Parliament, hopes for a peaceful election began rising here in the capital as well as in the port city of Mombasa, where more than 50 people have been killed in ethnic clashes since August. "It looks like a big breakthrough," a diplomat said, insisting on anonymity. "The big question is: will the reforms be implemented in sufficiently good faith?" Diplomats said the proposed reforms are not mere window dressing. If passed, they would mark significant concessions by Mr. Moi, who only three months ago vowed that he would allow no political changes before the general election, which must be held by the end of this year. Mr. Moi, 73, has been in power since 1979 and is a product of the one-party system erected by Jomo Kenyatta, the country's first President. He resisted multiparty democracy until 1992, when domestic and international pressure finally forced Kenya's Government to change. But for the first free election in 1992, Mr. Moi's party -- the Kenya African National Union -- used the machinery of the state to undercut challengers. Mr. Moi garnered the largest block of votes, about 38 percent, because the opposition splintered along tribal lines and could not unite behind a single candidate. This year, the major opposition leaders vowed they would not take part in the election unless the rules were changed to give challengers a better chance and unless civil liberties were expanded. More than a dozen people were killed in prodemocracy demonstrations over the summer. The unrest undermined Kenya's tourist industry and battered its currency. With the economy reeling, Mr. Moi and his Cabinet appeared to be in trouble just a month ago. Not only was Kenya facing international condemnation for violently breaking up demonstrations, but it was also fending off threats from the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund to suspend aid because of official corruption. Over the last three weeks, however, moderate backbenchers from the governing party reached out to moderate opposition leaders in Parliament and found some common ground, politicians and diplomats said. Some older opposition politicians said the umbrella coalition that had organized the summer's protests had been taken over by radicals intent on overthrowing Mr. Moi rather than changing the Constitution. Many moderates in the coalition became disenchanted with the movement after protesters beat two police officers to death at a rally in early August. "I found out that we had reached a stage where, for us who were purely for reforms, we were being taken for a ride," said Martin Shikuku, an opposition party leader and presidential aspirant. "We folded up the umbrella, and we went into discussions, and the result is that we have managed to get much more than we envisioned." Later Mr. Moi endorsed the raft of reforms that moderates on both sides of the aisle had hammered out in Parliament. Diplomats say his change of heart appears to be motivated partly by the threat of a loss of foreign aid and tourism. But in practice, the proposed bills have also divided his political enemies and tripped up the coalition of civil-rights advocates, clergy and politicians who had been pressing for constitutional change. Some of the more radical civil-rights advocates and opposition leaders are still holding out for greater changes, saying the proposed reforms are cosmetic. But they are having trouble rallying support. A protest called last weekend to burn voter-registration cards drew only a handful of people. The reformers' umbrella coalition -- known as the National Convention Executive Council -- has called off strikes scheduled for Wednesday and Thursday. Among other things, the bills would do away with sedition laws that give the Government the right to hold people without trial for political reasons, and would grant greater freedom of assembly. They would also make the police department independent of the governing party and make it a felony for the police to harass or jail people on political grounds. The reforms would also expand the electoral commission to give opposition parties 10 more seats.

COUNTRY: AFRICA (95%); UNITED STATES (94%); EUROPE (92%); ASIA (92%); ERITREA (79%); RWANDA (79%); NORTH AMERICA (79%); JAPAN (79%); EUROPEAN UNION MEMBER STATES (71%);
TEXT: U.N. AMBASSADOR Bill Richardson set off for Africa last week bad-mouthing his own chances of success. Yet the U.N. ambassador managed to secure from Congo President Laurent Kabila a promise to allow, finally, a U.N. investigation of massacres and human rights abuses. It's too soon to know whether these welcome words will be backed up with action. But it's not too soon for the United Nations, United States and other interested parties to take maximum advantage of the opening Ambassador Richardson and President Kabila have provided. "We are looking at a more coherent overall policy for the Great Lakes region," Secretary of State Madeleine Albright said yesterday. That's an urgent task. The turmoil that has rocked financial markets from Asia to North America to Europe in recent days has left Africa largely unscathed -- not because Africa is more economically sound but because it so much less integrated into the world economy. At a time like this, that might seem an advantage -- but it's not. While incomes in Asia have grown over the past two decades -- and will likely continue to grow despite the current troubles -- Africa risks being left behind altogether. Now, though, a new generation of self-made, self-confident leaders has come to power in much of the continent, from South Africa north to Eritrea. Their record is short thus far and mixed, but many of them proclaim a commitment to reining in corruption, promoting economic growth, fostering more responsive government and tying their nations to the world economy. The Great Lakes region at the continent's heart, and particularly Congo with its 65 million people, are crucial to this movement, and to Africa's stability. Mr. Kabila's performance thus far has been disappointing -- particularly his refusal to permit a U.N. inquiry into credible allegations of massacres and terrible mistreatment of refugees. He and others in the region are suspicious of the United Nations and Western nations, in part because they propped up the dictator Mobutu for so many years, in part because the West did little to prevent genocidal massacres in Rwanda in 1994. That resentment, however, cannot excuse Mr. Kabila's stonewalling. His progress makes possible a measure of progress in other parts of the West's relationship with Congo. The World Bank and International Monetary Fund should join with the United Nations, the United States, Japan and the European Union to fashion a constructive policy. One element must be relief from Mobutu's massive debts. Aid and trade must figure in too. This isn't something the United States can do alone, but it's something that isn't likely to happen at all without U.S. leadership.

COUNTRY: KENYA (97%); UNITED STATES (94%);
TEXT: No one has to tell Bernard Mulei that the Kenyan economy is in deep trouble. He hawks tours to passers-by in downtown Nairobi, and these days tourists are as scarce as the endangered species he entices them to see. "High season, we used to get five or six tourists a day," he said, as he scanned the busy street for foreigners and found none. "Now you might get one. Some guys go two or three weeks without getting anything." A month after President Daniel arap Moi won re-election to a fifth term, his Government is facing the monumental task of putting back together an economy shattered by torrential rains, political upheaval, ethnic violence, a steep drop in tourism and the suspension of foreign aid. Diplomats have taken the opportunity in recent weeks to push Mr. Moi and his allies once again to take a stronger stand against official corruption, suggesting that a resumption of foreign aid and low-interest loans to Kenya might hinge on such actions. "Kenya's between a rock and a hard place economically," one diplomat said, speaking on the condition of anonymity. "They really need this money. That's the only leverage we have." Some diplomats have also used their leverage to urge the Government to do more to stop ethnic clashes in the Rift Valley, which have taken at least 100 lives in the last three weeks. Coming after months of political tension and demonstrations, the violence has scared away investors and tourists, business leaders said. Though the election on Dec. 29 was generally peaceful, since then Mr. Moi's supporters from his Kalenjin ethnic group have clashed repeatedly in the Rift Valley with Kikuyu people, who by and large supported their kinsman, Mwai Kibaki, the runner-up. The police and local authorities have been slow to respond to attacks on Kikuyu families, diplomats said. The United States has been at the forefront in pressuring Mr. Moi to put an end to the violence. Last weekend, the Rev. Jesse Jackson, President Clinton's special envoy for democracy, visited the region where the killing has been taking place, talked to victims and then met with President Moi on Monday. In the meeting, Mr. Jackson said, he told Mr. Moi that regardless of how the violence began, the United States was expecting some "hands-on" leadership from Mr. Moi in bringing the clashes under control. He also urged opposition leaders, who have accused Mr. Moi of orchestrating the attacks, to "cool down provocative rhetoric." Mr. Jackson said that Kenya's economic recovery was being crippled by the violence, and he suggested that aid from the United States and American support for loans might be jeopardized. "There is a debate about who started it," Mr. Jackson said. "There can be no debate about whose responsibility it is to end it. The Government must do it." Mr. Jackson's visit came as Kenyan officials met with a delegation from the International Monetary Fund for the first time since the Washington-based lending institution suspended a $205 million low-interest loan to Kenya last July, citing rampant corruption among top officials. Issues in the talks included several promises Kenya made last August to persuade the fund to restore the loans, including a commitment to crack down on official graft and improve efficiency among civil servants. The fund's decision on resuming aid is seen as critical to Kenya's economic future. It is usually a guidepost for other donor countries, who together provide about $500 million in aid annually. A series of disasters have beset Kenya's economy in the last six months. Heavy rains and floods wiped out roads and bridges, twice cutting the main highway to the port of Mombasa in the last month. The rains have destroyed crops as well, crippling production of coffee, tea, corn, wheat, beans, rice and sugar. The drop-off has hurt exports and caused local prices to soar. The deluges have also caused epidemics of malaria and cholera, overburdening a creaking health care system at a time when nurses were on strike. The floods also contributed to an outbreak of Rift Valley Fever, a rare illness that has killed at least 600 people and thousands of livestock in the last three months. The political and ethnic turbulence before the December election also hurt this nation of game parks and beach resorts, where tourism is the largest earner of foreign exchange. Kenya's balance of payments was hit hard by a $280 million decline in tourism receipts because of ethnic clashes on the Indian Ocean coast in the second half of 1997.
