Then in January, when more clashes over land and political allegiances erupted between Kikuyu and Kalenjin ethnic groups in the Rift Valley, tourists and foreign investors continued to keep their distance. "Foreign investors are not very comfortable with the political situation right now," said Lincoln Ndwiga, a Nairobi stockbroker. "They are the big players. If they shy away, so do the local investors." To make fiscal matters worse, strikes in December forced the Government to agree to labor settlements with teachers and other civil servants that provided for a tripling of salaries, which is likely to add millions in unexpected expenditures to the $3.1 billion annual budget. "We definitely need an important infusion of foreign aid," the new Foreign Minister, Bonaya Adhi Godana, said. "Obviously we would be glad to have had it not only restored but increased." These problems would have been tough for any government to handle, but there is ample evidence that Kenya's has not been particularly well managed in recent years, diplomats and foreign economists say. The country's infrastructure has visibly crumbled in the last five years, despite millions of dollars in loans from the World Bank for improving roads. On average, the Government completes only about 3 percent of its capital projects each year, a fraction of the average for most countries.  Even though the World Bank has approved nearly $600 million in loans for major projects, it has been able to disburse only about $30 million because the Government has been so slow to get projects off the ground, officials said. In addition, Kenya's civil payroll is bloated with nearly 485,000 workers. The country is also paying horrendously high interest rates of more than 25 percent on its treasury bills and commercial debts. About a third of the budget goes for debt service, most of it to domestic banks. The budget deficit is expected to balloon to around 4 percent of this year's domestic output. Few resources are left over for building roads, hospitals, schools. "This is catastrophic," said one diplomat, speaking on condition of anonymity. "You can't develop a country with these kinds of numbers." Map of Kenya showing the location of the Rift Valley: The Rift Valley has repeatedly been hit by ethnic clashes.

COUNTRY: CONGO, THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE (96%); AFRICA (94%); CENTRAL AFRICA (79%);
TEXT: For a brief moment last May, when his fighters swept into this capital and put an end to Africa's longest dictatorship, Laurent Kabila, the new President, loomed huge on the political stage as a national hero and as Africa's brightest star. But the last year has seen one of Africa's most dramatic unravelings of a political honeymoon. From the nightclubs of Kinshasa, where couples dance the dombolo, a step created to mock the President's ponderous style, to the offices of both African and Western diplomats who once toasted him, people are already concluding that the bright promise of Mr. Kabila's presidency has all but evaporated and wondering aloud how things could have gone so wrong. The people of Congo, formerly Zaire, cheered Mr. Kabila, hoping for an end to years of poverty and decline under the corrupt rule of Mobutu Sese Seko. The neighboring countries that sponsored his seven-month insurgency boldly predicted a new era of stability and growth. Western donors and foreign investors were eager to do business again with a country whose vast inventory of mineral wealth had earned it the sobriquet of Central Africa's geological scandal under Mr. Mobutu. But a year later, cross-border violence still percolates in the country's east. Ethnic tensions, both new and old, abound. Mining investment has been slowed in part because the Government broke off some of its early contracts and investors are leery of instability. And with the new Government increasingly inclined toward the repressive tactics of its predecessors, dreams of democracy have begun to fade. "We were so happy to see the arrival of Kabila's fighters that we all went into the streets to applaud them, our children brought them water to drink, our wives supplied them food," Crespin Muteba, a 54-year-old, long-unpaid postal worker, said as his friends shook their heads in acknowledgment. "People were expecting a sweet future for our country, but what he has served us instead is bitter lemon." Foreign donors have all but recoiled from promises of major reconstruction assistance for the country because the new Government's dictatorial tendencies -- from its decision to rule by decree, ban opposition political activity and sharply proscribe work by human rights groups -- that have increasingly drawn unflattering comparison to Mr. Mobutu. Asked in a rare interview what kind of balance sheet he himself would draw up for his one-year-old rule, Mr. Kabila recently told the French radio, "The successes are many and the failures almost nonexistent." But an African diplomat from a country whose Government had strongly backed Mr. Kabila offered a starkly different take. "Sometimes you just have to scratch your head and wonder what it is with this leadership," he said. "When they came to power, they had the world at their feet. But ever since it is almost as if they had deliberately gone out of their way to turn people off." Mr. Kabila's defeat of the Mobutu dictatorship was hailed as a model of African nations' taking charge in their own back yards. In September 1996, Rwanda and Uganda, weary of the cross-border raids by Hutu refugees into Rwanda that were destabilizing that country and deeply traumatized by the 1994 genocide of the Tutsi minority, started the uprising that spawned Mr. Kabila's rebellion. His Main Fighters: Foreigners on Loan After an early series of successes in breaking up Hutu refugee camps and routing Mr. Mobutu's ragged army, Mr. Kabila was plucked from obscurity and put in charge of the army that would eventually overthrow the terminally ill dictator. But the sources of Mr. Kabila's early strength also foreshadowed much of his weakness. Mr. Kabila arrived in Kinshasa only nominally in charge of an army whose principal fighters were foreigners on loan from Rwanda, or long-exiled members of Zaire's tiny Tutsi minority. In the capital, and eventually throughout much of the country, the image of Mr. Kabila as conquering hero quickly gave way to the humiliating image of the new leader as a hostage to Rwanda, a country one one-hundredth the size of Congo. The new troops did not speak the language of western Congo and were seen as unusually stern and trigger-happy. At first, Mr. Kabila appeared in public surrounded by Rwandan bodyguards. And to compound the problem, his Government contained what many Congolese said was a disproportionately large number of Tutsi ministers. Mr. Kabila's Rwandan problem was made worse by the fact that even before his victory, troops belonging to his Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo were accused of carrying out widespread massacres of the Hutu refugees. The international community was insisting on a thorough United Nations investigation of the accusations, something diplomats said Mr. Kabila's Rwandan and Ugandan allies could not have wished for. Aware that his heavy reliance on Rwanda was becoming a liability, Mr. Kabila increasingly turned to other African allies, particularly Angola. With its help, he resorted to a reflex heavily used by Mr. Mobutu himself, and one that would bring new problems of its own. Mr. Kabila, a southerner, stocked the army with ethnic kinsmen who had spent years of exile across the border in Angola and surrounded himself more and more with southern advisers. Soon Mr. Kabila's Tutsi troops began to react to their perceived loss of influence. And recent months have seen shoot-outs between predominantly Tutsi soldiers and units drawn from other parts of the country. In the country's far east, where native Tutsi are numerous, meanwhile, Tutsi units have mutinied outright. "For the Tutsi, the new Congo became a Frankenstein; something they helped create, but can no longer control," a Western diplomat said. "Now they feel as threatened as they did before the start of the war." Mr. Kabila's management of the country's political scene has scarcely brought brighter results. He has banned political activity by anyone but his own party, setting his new Government on an immediate collision course with the longtime civilian opposition to Mr. Mobutu and its popular leader, Etienne Tshisekedi. Less than a month after Mr. Kabila took power, student protests and increasingly vocal grumbling by citizens over the political restrictions had become the order of the day.  Despite these early troubles, Western governments largely kept faith with the new Government, promising large amounts of economic aid in return for major reforms. Despite crackdowns on the opposition, Washington praised Mr. Kabila's promise to organize elections within two years. And to the deep frustration of a political class prohibited from organizing, American diplomats counseled forbearance over sweeping restrictions. As if One Dictatorship Replaced Another "We felt as if one dictatorship was being replaced by another, and were surprised to hear the West telling us to give them the time to settle in," said Marcel Mbayo, a senior official of Mr. Tshisekedi's Union for Democracy and Social Progress, the country's largest political party. "That's like telling someone to stop breathing for two hours and afterwards you will feel better." The West's support for Mr. Kabila had its first serious test as the new Government tried to frustrate a United Nations investigation of the alleged wartime massacres by his troops. Patience with Mr. Kabila began to fray openly late last year, however, as Washington and other Western capitals grew increasingly embarrassed by a deepening streak of authoritarianism and a lack of any clear approach to the country's immense problems. When Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright visited Kinshasa in December, American officials still seemed largely protective of Mr. Kabila, volunteering to journalists that Washington was "interested in more than human rights" in Congo. Indeed, through various nongovernmental organizations, the United States has cleared the way for some $10 million in funds. Ms. Albright, however, was deeply embarrassed to learn of a wave of political arrests in the country, as well as by Mr. Kabila's dismissive reaction to the subject in a joint news conference with her. Vowing to arrest other critics, Mr. Kabila sneered, with an uncomfortable Ms. Albright at his side, "Vive la democratie." A few weeks later came a turning point in Washington's relations with Mr. Kabila, when President Clinton's special envoy to Africa, Jesse Jackson, visited Kinshasa and was rebuffed by Congolese officials for meeting with opposition politicians. Later, he was denied a scheduled meeting with Mr. Kabila. Within days of Mr. Jackson's departure, the Government arrested Mr. Tshisekedi, the leading opposition figure, and placed him in "internal exile" under guard in a village in central Congo. The 66-year-old lawyer was given a Government-issue harvester and seed and told that his "re-education" required that he begin to farm. Then came the arrest of several journalists and the banning of the Zairian Association for the Defense of Human Rights, Azadho. According to international human rights groups, Government agents arrested a judge they mistook for the director of Azadho, beat him and held him in detention before realizing their mistake. Government officials deny that any such mistake was made, but say the human rights groups, opposition newspapers and political parties that existed under Mr. Mobutu no longer have a raison d'etre, because under Mr. Kabila and his Alliance of Democratic Forces the country has already been "liberated." "Azadho is like all of those other organizations out there complaining -- they are opponents," said Abdoulaye N. Yerodia, Mr. Kabila's cabinet director. "But we are under no obligation to inherit the opposition to Mobutu." Since the April announcement of the withdrawal of the United Nations massacre investigation for lack of Government cooperation, the string of missteps by the Government has left even many of its most ardent supporters deeply embarrassed. Just days after the announcement of an International Monetary Fund agreement restoring badly needed financial assistance in return for Kinshasa's resumption of debt service payments, the Government denied that it had agreed to resume its payments. Now I.M.F support has been halted. 'An Awful Lot Of Darkness' Similarly, after months of courting its former colonial power, Mr. Kabila's Government publicly accused Belgium of being a "terrorist state" because of a small stockade of arms "discovered" at the Belgian consulate in Lubumbashi. Kinshasa was later obliged to acknowledge that the weapons had been brought into the country legally and were properly registered. No sooner has the dust settled from that incident than the Government was attacking the United Nations Children's Fund for collusion with rebels in Congo's still restive eastern border lands, giving further reason to an already aggrieved United Nations to review its cooperation with the country. "Our policy calls for supporting the Government, but at this point it is pretty much for lack of an alternative," a Western diplomat said. "That means searching around for the few bright spots, because there is an awful lot of darkness out there." Map of Congo showing location of Kinshasa: Newfound dreams of democracy have begun to fade in Kinshasa. (pg. A6)

COUNTRY: KENYA
TEXT: The head of Kenya's new anti-corruption authority has been suspended from office after a disagreement with the Finance Minister in a case that underscores just how difficult it is to root out graft here. President Daniel arap Moi suspended the official, John Harun Mwau, on Wednesday, just four days after Mr. Mwau had filed charges against four high-ranking Treasury Department officials, accusing them of a scheme to evade $3.9 million in import duties on wheat and sugar. The President's actions came after the Finance Minister, Simeon Nyachae, in a spirited defense of his accused subordinates, attacked Mr. Mwau in public, accusing him of starting a witch hunt. He defended the officials, who are accused of corrupt business dealings, maintaining that not only did they act within the law, but with the full approval of the Cabinet. Played out on the front pages of newspapers here, the disagreement has undermined the credibility of Mr. Moi's efforts to stamp out corruption, once again putting Kenya's shaky relations with international lenders in jeopardy. "This is not helpful," said one diplomat, insisting on anonymity. "This is an unfortunate development, distracting from the central issues this country faces. This is all a distraction, a sideshow." When the International Monetary Fund suspended aid to Kenya last year, one of its principal complaints was that the Government had done little or nothing to rein in rampant official corruption. In recent years, corrupt schemes have seeped into almost every level of government here, from bribes that traffic officers solicit from motorists to elaborate land grabs and import-duty scams involving cabinet members, diplomats say. In response to pressure from the I.M.F., Mr. Moi set up the Kenya Anti-Corruption Authority last December and put Mr. Mwau, a former police officer and an opposition gadfly, in charge. But Mr. Mwau's decision to prosecute the four treasury officials as his first high-profile case has raised questions about his sincerity and the viability of his authority, diplomats and financial officials said. Before the charges were leveled, the four accused officials were seen as part of a progressive, reform-minded wing of the governing party, a group led by Mr. Nyachae that stands firmly behind efforts to stamp out corruption. While diplomats and officials at international lending institutions said they could not say whether the charges were true, they did say they came as a surprise. "We have a feeling that these people who were to be arrested were doing their jobs and we have no reason to believe they were corrupt," one banking official said, speaking on the condition of anonymity. Whether or not the charges are true, several diplomats said the public contretemps was not likely to persuade the I.M.F. and World Bank to resume aid to shore up Kenya's shattered economy, which is reeling from a steep drop in tourism. On the streets of the capital, meanwhile, speculation has grown that Mr. Mwau purposely took aim at pro-reform officials first, instead of other officials suspected of corruption in order to take the wind out of the pro-reform movement's sails. A cartoon in Wednesday's Daily Nation newspaper showed Mr. Mwau and Mr. Nyachae as puppets, their strings being pulled by hands recognizable as the President's. A statement from the President's office said Mr. Moi would appoint a tribunal to "inquire into the proper performance" of the corruption authority. The statement said Mr. Mwau would be suspended until the tribunal had finished its inquiry. For his part, Mr. Mwau has fiercely defended the charges against the four officials and has said he will resign if they are not proved true in court. It is highly unlikely the case will ever be heard, however, since the Attorney General has dropped the charges. The accused officials are Joseph Kinyua, Njeru Kirira, John Msafari and Samuel Chebii. At the same time, Mr. Nyachae has accused Mr. Mwau of pressing the charges only to divert attention from the fact that he himself is under investigation by the Kenya Revenue Authority for evading duty on the import of automobile tires. Mr. Mwau denies any wrongdoing.

COUNTRY: ANGOLA (94%); NIGERIA (93%); AFRICA (92%); CONGO, THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE (79%); PORTUGAL (79%);
TEXT: Civil war has ruined Angola's economy, but the chaos wrought by conflict has been a boon for politicians and generals, providing a smoke screen for rampant corruption and mismanagement in the oil and diamond industries, financial analysts and diplomats say. This southwest African nation could well become Africa's number-one oil producer over the next decade, possibly surpassing Nigeria, the current leader. Diamond deposits along Angola's many rivers and in its ancient volcanic rock, though less lucrative on a large scale than oil, are among the highest quality and most sought gemstones in the world. But as in Nigeria, which has long been one of the continent's most corrupt nations, Angola's vast and largely unaccounted-for wealth moves through a shadow economy. Oil revenue simply disappears and is believed to be taken by government officials, business sources here say. And while it is common knowledge that the UNITA rebel movement has financed itself with the diamonds in its territory, diplomats and analysts say they believe that illicit deals are made by and between rebel leaders and army generals who, when dollars are not on the table, are otherwise at war. While corruption here may not approach the level of the utterly thieving regime of Mobutu Sese Seko, the late dictator of the former Zaire, analysts and diplomats say it has become systemic. Based on anecdotal evidence, the officially enforced dearth of budgetary data and official books that just do not add up, analysts say they believe that the trend toward corruption has been set by a powerful group around President Jose Eduardo dos Santos. The group is called the Futungist faction, for the Futungo presidential compound along the Atlantic coast south of the capital. "Everybody knows it," said a loyalist to dos Santos's ruling party, the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola (MPLA). The party loyalist described corruption as the MPLA's "life-insurance scheme," which took hold gradually but soon became commonplace. "Like a virus, you could not stop it," he said. As he described it, independence from Portugal in 1975 turned the MPLA's guerrilla fighters into politicians who had the best of intentions but found themselves mired in bureaucratic responsibilities. With a continuing war against UNITA wearing them down at the same time, they succumbed to the temptation of simply securing their own wealth. An analyst who has attempted to decipher Angola's chaotic economic system said there is little indication in government accounts of how oil and diamond revenue flows in and out of the budget. Controls and accounting procedures for government revenue are virtually nonexistent, reducing the budget to a document of fiction, the analyst said. Half of what the government says it spends cannot be traced to a revenue source, he said, and much of what is believed to be produced in oil revenue is unaccounted for. The analyst said oil produced about $ 1.5 billion in revenue last year, with two-thirds presumed to go toward defense, leaving $ 500 million unaccounted for. "It is not clear what really happens to this revenue," he said. "There's widespread speculation that a significant chunk of it leaks out." Leakage also is endemic in the diamond sector. No figures are available on precisely how much diamond revenue has been produced. UNITA rebels have controlled virtually all of Angola's diamond-producing territory in recent years, although the diamond-rich provinces of Lunda Norte and Lunda Sul have changed hands a few times in the past year's fighting. The economic analyst estimates that only 10 percent of diamond revenue reaches government coffers, with most of the rest going to UNITA and, to a lesser extent, to government generals. The traffic in uncertified diamonds has continued despite a U.N. embargo last June against diamond deals with UNITA. Global Witness, a Britain-based human rights group, has criticized the government for poor controls in the diamond industry and has accused international diamond conglomerate De Beers of trafficking in UNITA-mined diamonds, a charge that De Beers denies. The government rarely comments on its economic details. Officials here do, however, acknowledge that the economy is in chaos -- mired in debt and in need of reform. But when voices of criticism are raised from within the ruling party, they are silenced. Lopo do Nascimento, a former prime minister, was removed as party secretary general at a party congress last month when a reform movement loosely coalesced around him tried to open debate on the need for economic reforms, sources knowledgeable about party affairs say. Rather than entertain a reform agenda, dos Santos quashed debate on the issue and hammered at the need for unity in the face of the MPLA's chief nemesis and convenient bogey man, rebel leader Jonas Savimbi. Savimbi's UNITA -- the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola -- has been fighting the MPLA off and on since well before independence. Most government attention has been focused on checking UNITA's strength, as in the current round of fighting, which began last month with a government attempt to take UNITA's stronghold. More than two decades on a war footing has warped the economy. While defense spending is the focus of the budget, schools and clinics are not built, factories are not rehabilitated, roads -- except for a few in the capital -- are not repaired, and towns in the interior that have been destroyed by fighting stand as exhibits of the Angolan nightmare. Most of Angola's 12 million people live in utter rural poverty made all the worse by the land mines sown in the soil and the bandits who work the roads. It is notable, though mysterious, analysts say, that a private foundation established in 1997 by the president, the Fundacao Eduardo dos Santos, has been building schools with funds from an unknown source. Murky budgetary practices are one of the reasons that Angola cannot get loans from the International Monetary Fund, which has conditioned credit on more transparency and control in government accounts. Angola's external debt is about $ 10.5 billion, and the service on that debt accounts, on paper, for 20 percent of gross national product, one of the highest such percentages in the world, according to the World Bank. Angola is in such a deep financial mess that the government routinely rolls over its debt by seeking oil-guaranteed short-term loans that, in effect, mortgage future oil revenue, the financial analyst here said. The government also has no money to pay for imports, and cannot pay public servants and government contractors. But oil keeps flowing, with a host of international oil firms pumping out in the Atlantic Ocean or bidding here in the capital, Luanda, for the deep-water oil fields that industry analysts say will catapult Angola into the oil-production big leagues. Current production of 750,000 barrels per day is expected to double over the next decade. And the cost of doing oil business here also is going up, including hundreds of millions of dollars in "signing fees" that the government demands for oil exploration rights. Seven percent of U.S. oil imports come from Angola, and that amount is expected to double along with production. American companies, such as Chevron, are major players in the industry.

COUNTRY: KENYA (98%); TURKEY (79%);
TEXT: A day after his corruption-fighting predecessor quit in a major Cabinet shake-up, the new Finance Minister sought today to reassure investors and donors of foreign aid that he would continue on the path of fiscal reform. The statements from the new Minister, Yekoyada F. O. Masakhalia, seemed primarily aimed at the International Monetary Fund. Officials from the fund are to visit Kenya this month to decide whether to reinstate an important $205 million package of financial aid that was frozen in 1997 largely because of corruption and mismanagement of public money. Many experts here said they believed that the package would be restored as a result of improved fiscal policies put into effect by the departing Finance Minister, Simeon Nyachae. Today, Mr. Masakhalia, 61, an economist with a master's from Harvard University, said he would seek few substantive changes. "I would like to emphasize there will be no change to the ongoing policy thrust," he said at a news conference here. Mr. Nyachae resigned on Thursday in a surprise move. He is a leading politician, often mentioned as a potential successor to President Daniel arap Moi who, since he was appointed in January 1998, had cut Government spending and brought down interest rates. He also waged a highly public battle against corruption, even reporting the names of prominent Kenyans who had not repaid national bank loans. He said on Thursday that his resignation had "irked many people" and made his job as Finance Minister "even more difficult." He quit his post rather than accept Mr. Moi's decision for him to swap jobs with Mr. Masakhalia, who had been Industrial Development Minister. Mr. Moi shifted six other ministers and dismissed a few others, notably Immigration Minister Frank Kwinga, whose department controls arrivals like that of a Kurdish leader, Abdullah Ocalan. Mr. Ocalan was smuggled into Kenya on Feb. 2 and captured by Turkey this week. http://www.nytimes.com

COUNTRY: NIGERIA (95%); UNITED STATES (94%); FRANCE (79%); EUROPE (79%); AFRICA (79%); GERMANY (79%);
TEXT: The President-elect of Nigeria came to New York yesterday to say that his country, an international pariah for 16 years, is now headed firmly toward democratic rule, privatization of its huge oil industry and an end to decades of official corruption and severe human rights abuse. Olusegun Obasanjo, 61, whose election on Feb. 27 was welcomed by the West, appeared frank and direct as he spoke about the unsavory reputation Nigeria had acquired. But he declined to offer specifics on what he vowed would be sweeping reforms. "I'm sure you are used to bad news from Nigeria," he said, adding that his country had been "among the leading corrupt nations of the world." He said: "There is virtually no sector of our society that has not been wounded. We have to bind the wounds and bring conciliation and unity, give people hope and a sense of belonging and participation." Nigeria is Africa's most populous nation, with 108 million inhabitants. Under Gen. Sani Abacha it suffered five years of ruthless dictatorship, which ended last June when he died unexpectedly. His successor, Gen. Abdulsalami Abubakar, began reforms, allowing elections that ended in victory for Mr. Obasanjo, a retired general and former President. He is to be inaugurated on May 29. Mr. Obasanjo exuded charisma and self-confidence at a news conference yesterday, with his powerful frame cloaked in a majestic blue robe. He said his trip here, part of a world tour, was aimed at reassuring political and business leaders of his sincerity, skill and determination. He is expected in Washington today to meet with top American officials, including Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright and, tentatively, President Clinton, as well as leaders of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund. He arrived here from Europe, where he had offered his message of hope to the leaders and investors of France, Germany and Britain, among others. Large advertising spreads in international newsmagazines and on CNN in recent weeks have also sought to drive home the point that Nigeria, one of the world's largest exporters of oil, has embarked on a new course. Mr. Obasanjo was asked yesterday whether he would follow the South African model of healing society's wounds with the equivalent of a Truth and Reconciliation Commission to investigate the misdeeds of his predecessors and their aides. He declined to commit himself. "When I am on the saddle, then I'll make definitive pronouncements," he said. He added that he did not now have the information he needed. He was slightly more forthcoming in an interview with a syndicated columnist, Jonathan Power, that appeared in the Los Angeles Times on Sunday. On corruption, he said, "You must show that the practices you want to get rid of are punished," and added: "I will more than crack the whip. I will use the whip." Mr. Obasanjo, a Yoruba from southern Nigeria, is said to have close links to northern military leaders and was viewed during the election campaign as a bridge between the two regions. He is the only Nigerian ruler ever to have stepped down voluntarily, which he did in 1979. At the time, he set the stage for a democratic system, which was overthrown a few years later. http://www.nytimes.com

COUNTRY: NIGERIA (99%); AFRICA (94%); UNITED STATES (79%);
TEXT: When Nigeria's first civilian government in 15 years takes office Saturday, its most pressing task will be to grapple with the economic and political crises seizing Africa's most populous nation. But intellectuals and foreign analysts worry about how empty the new government will find its bank accounts following a spending spree by the departing military rulers. The outgoing administration of Gen. Abdulsalami Abubakar has won global applause for leading Nigeria back to elected government a year after taking power upon the death of a corrupt dictator, Gen. Sani Abacha. Yet Abubakar's military government has drained the country's foreign currency reserves by perhaps $ 3 billion in what business sources and the Nigerian press say was a burst of corrupt spending for the profit of senior officers and their business partners. The government says it has spent the money on essential projects or to fill the financial gap caused by low oil revenues. In any case, the spending deepens the financial hole from which the new government of President-elect Olusegun Obasanjo will have to dig itself. It also raises stakes for the United States and other Western nations that are negotiating, through the International Monetary Fund, the terms on which they will lend Obasanjo's government money to help stabilize the country. U.S. and African leaders stress that Nigeria's continued transition toward democracy is essential to improving stability and economic development throughout much of Africa. In January, Abubakar announced a painfully tight budget, noting low world prices for crude oil, sales of which supply about 80 percent of Nigeria's government revenue. All officials, he said, "must ensure that expenditures are incurred for only essential purposes." Abubakar's government signed an agreement with the IMF to limit spending as a first step to getting IMF loans. But Abubakar either proved unable to control the demands of military officers for financial favors or backed away from insisting on tight spending and accountability, Western diplomats and Nigerian analysts said. In March, Nigeria's state-owned oil company -- which was controlled by the military's ruling council -- allocated 11 oil exploration licenses without seeking competitive bids that would have brought the state a fair market price. The 11 licenses, for geologically attractive areas near existing oil fields, went to Nigerian companies linked to senior military officers or former Abacha business associates, according to government and oil industry sources quoted by Nigerian journalists and a London-based newsletter, Africa Confidential. One firm, Amni International, is run by Sani Bello, whose son is married to Abubakar's daughter, the newsletter reported. Others linked to the winning bids included the government's second-ranking officer, Adm. Mike Akhigbe; the chief of defense staff, Air Marshal Alamin Daggash; the chief of army staff, Gen. Ishaya Bamaiyi; former Abacha business partners Jack and Gilbert Chagoury; and Abacha's ex-oil minister, Dan Etete. Officials denied parts of the reported deals. Last week, Information Minister John Nwodo declared that "Air Marshal Daggash disassociates himself" from Anchorage Petroleum, the company to which he had been linked in press reports. To buttress the denial, Nwodo declared that the company was not even registered with the appropriate authorities, leaving it unclear how it won the license in the first place. Nwodo also said Akhigbe and Bamaiyi had issued denials. Government ministries also have pressed for allocations beyond the budget -- often for construction or other services by companies linked to influential military officers or their business. Last month, Finance Minister Ismaila Usman told donor countries that Nigeria's foreign reserves had dropped from $ 6.7 billion to $ 4 billion during the first quarter of 1999. And government officials leaked details of the spending to the Nigerian and British press. One leaked document was a list of about 50 projects -- costing more than $ 600 million overall -- approved in a ministerial meeting April 22. From that list, the weekly Newswatch noted an allocation of about $ 73 million to continue construction of a government-owned aluminum smelter -- regarded as a white elephant by foreign economists -- whose agreed price had suddenly doubled without explanation several years ago under Abacha. The April 22 list included almost $ 50 million to finish hundreds of official homes in Abuja for government ministers, civil servants and legislators, plus $ 33 million to finish a terminal at Abuja's airport. "It's uncertain how much of the money" appropriated April 22 has actually been spent, said a business analyst in Lagos, Nigeria's financial center. "We may not find that out until Obasanjo's people get in and actually see the books." Abubakar protested suggestions that his administration has been broadly corrupt. "It is very much unfair for somebody to . . . accuse this administration of looting the treasury," he said. "Everything we have done is there for anybody to see. . . . Anybody can go into the records . . . and see where we have spent the money."

COUNTRY: SIERRA LEONE
TEXT: Two things caught my attention about U.S. Secretary of State Madeleine Albright's visit to Sierra Leone [news story, Oct. 19]. First, Secretary Albright pledged $ 55 million in aid to this impoverished nation, and second, she challenged President Ahmad Tejan Kabbah's administration to embark on an International Monetary Fund (IMF) program to qualify the country for a waiver on its $ 65 million debt (subject to congressional approval). Many have criticized the United States for not doing enough to save this war-ravaged country from self-inflicted ruin. Critics have failed, however, to observe that Sierra Leone's eight-year war was not a rebellion targeted entirely at the political establishment but a war fought by bandits to gain control of mineral resources. Militia leaders Foday Sankoh, the new vice president, and his comrade, Johnny Paul Koroma led a campaign that brought carnage to the nation, destroyed its historical infrastructure, killed and maimed its citizens and halted democracy. Aid money must not be given directly to politicians. Aid should come in the form of technical assistance with direct involvement of agencies to oversee food and medicine distribution and infrastructure development. Only this strategy will prevent a repetition of the greed and corruption that have brought Sierra Leone to its present state. Silver Spring  While U.S. Secretary of State Madeleine Albright met with President Kabbah and rebel leaders in Sierra Leone, lending support to the reconciliation process [news story, Oct. 18], reports are of infighting and another abduction (of the bishop of Makeni and several aid workers and priests) by disgruntled rebel troops. The peace accord is an international capitulation to thugs and warlords at the expense of a democratically elected regime. However, the country is exhausted, the leaders of the parties to the conflict seem ready to collaborate and this accord is all there is. But for even this poor compromise to have a chance, peacekeeping must be funded. Currently, peacekeeping is being shouldered by the ill-equipped and financially strapped West African force for which U.S. support has been inadequate at best. The U.N. Security Council has yet to approve a proposed 6,000-strong peacekeeping force. The United Nations -- crippled by a $ 1.7 billion arrears in U.S. payments -- is stretched thin in Kosovo and East Timor. Stabilization also demands humanitarian relief for the displaced and mutilated civilian victims of the war. The Post reports, however, that the U.N. World Food Program, for lack of contributions, has cut emergency aid to Sierra Leone's refugees [World in Brief, Oct. 17]. Pressure must be brought to bear on our representatives to stop their obstruction of American foreign policy, to pay U.N. dues and to support humanitarian and peacekeeping programs for Sierra Leone. Washington

COUNTRY: GABON (94%); NIGERIA (92%); UNITED STATES (92%); PAKISTAN (92%); VENEZUELA, BOLIVARIAN REPUBLIC OF (79%); AFRICA (73%);
TEXT: In 1997, federal bank examiners were pressing executives at Citibank Private Bank to explain the source of more than $50 million deposited into a secret account controlled by the president of Gabon, Omar Bongo, bank and Senate documents show. Existing Citibank profiles said President Bongo's wealth was created as "a result of his position" and "donations" from a French oil company doing business in the African nation, according to the documents. But a draft report by Democratic Senate investigators found that in responding to regulators, Citibank produced a new profile showing other sources of the wealth -- information the report says is inaccurate and unverified. This week, Citibank's handling of private accounts like Mr. Bongo's will be the subject of Senate hearings. The Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations is examining the vulnerability of private banking to money laundering. In recent years, billions of dollars have left fragile economies, from Russia to Mexico, facilitated by Western bankers. The Senate hearings, whose witnesses will include Citibank executives and federal regulators, will offer the first detailed public look at one of the most secretive parts of the global financial system, private banking, in which wealthy customers are afforded extra discretion and care. The hearings come at a time when previously acceptable practices in private banking are undergoing new scrutiny. President Bongo's account is one of several the Senate is investigating that are tied to prominent foreign political leaders or their families, in Mexico, Venezuela, Nigeria and Pakistan as well as Gabon. Citibank's private banking clients included such controversial figures as the sons of Gen. Sani Abacha, the Nigerian dictator; Raul Salinas de Gortari, the brother of Mexico's former president, and Asif Ali Zadari, the husband of former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto of Pakistan. In 1997, federal examiners were looking at whether Mr. Bongo's transactions should be reported as suspicious. American law bans banks from moving money earned abroad from some crimes, like drug trafficking, but not corruption. A central tenet of banking is to know your customer, and banks are required to report certain suspicious transactions to regulators. Yet, the committee's staff report notes, "there is currently no statutory, regulatory or industry guidance of what is adequate due diligence." So in 1997 the regulators felt reassured after Citibank officials told them that Mr. Bongo's transactions "are normal for the head of state of an African country," according to portions of the examiners' report quoted by Senate investigators. Mr. Bongo's profile had been revised in 1997 to say his wealth stemmed primarily from government budgeted accounts and personal oil investments in Gabon and other African countries. Senate investigators, however, found the explanations unverified and, in the first case, "implausible and plainly contrary to Gabon's budget policy and actual spending," the draft report says. Citibank documents show that bank officials were aware of news reports that Mr. Bongo was under investigation for possibly accepting bribes from French oil executives, but they were reluctant to raise those reports with Mr. Bongo or regulators, according to the draft report. Mr. Bongo has not been charged with any wrongdoing. A spokesman for the Gabon Embassy in Washington declined to comment. A Citibank spokesman said bank officials believed that President Bongo's wealth came from legitimate sources and that he had been "considered a distinguished head of government, supported and embraced by U.S. presidents." Meanwhile, Citibank has moved to close Mr. Bongo's account, one of 40,000 at Citibank Private Bank. Citibank estimates that only 350 of the private bank's customers are public officials or their families. The closing of Mr. Bongo's account follows moves by the bank's senior management to tighten supervision of sensitive accounts and to keep the bank from being used for improper purposes. John Reed, the chairman and co-chief executive of Citigroup, the parent of Citibank, is expected to tell the Senate committee about Citibank's new measures against money laundering and a policy adopted last year to shy away from seeking out public figures as private bank clients, according to people familiar with his prepared testimony. He is also expected to discuss how regulators now find significant improvements in the private bank's internal controls. The Citibank documents make clear the potential pitfalls for one of the world's most powerful and prestigious financial institutions. The Senate inquiry is such a sensitive matter for Citigroup that it hired two former senior White House lawyers, C. Boyden Gray of the Bush administration and Jane Sherburne of the Clinton administration, to help the bank prepare and respond. One Senate investigator said Citibank had once lobbied to have a 1992 check for $1 million from Libya to a Bongo account offshore unfrozen by the United States government, contending that Citibank could lose its business in Gabon if the payment remained frozen by anti-terrorism statutes. Mark Musi, the chief compliance officer for Citibank Private Bank, said, "The Private Bank never has had a strategy to link efforts to get or retain a head of state's personal business in order to develop other business in that country." He added that Citibank's business in Gabon is "extremely small" and unaffected by the decision to close the Bongo account. But Raymond Baker, a guest scholar at the Brookings Institution who is scheduled to testify at the hearings, worries that when Western banks help the powerful elite in less developed countries to hide their wealth -- some of which may be ill gotten -- they undercut the efforts by Western governments and entities like the International Monetary Fund to help the economies of those poorer countries. "It is Western taxpayers who are paying it out over the table to these countries and the private banks who take it back under the table," Mr. Baker said in an interview. He is concerned that Western banks that move corrupt money out of poorer countries may aid the client in committing crimes like tax evasion, illegal capital flight and false trade invoicing, all of which fall outside the reach of American money laundering statutes. But this movement of money, Mr. Baker added, sucks $100 billion per year out of poorer countries. In many ways, the interest in Citibank Private Bank stems from its involvement with Mr. Salinas. Mr. Reed is expected to tell the Senate panel that the bank has learned a lot from the now well-known Salinas affair, even though it has never been cited for any legal or regulatory violations. Between 1992 and 1994 the bank moved between $80 million and $100 million through Mr. Salinas's accounts, using extra confidential methods that the General Accounting Office, the audit arm of Congress, later found "disguised" the "origin, destination and beneficial owner of the funds." Mr. Reed is to tell the committee that while Citibank failed then to follow its own policy, it now has much tougher rules. The Senate panel turned up some new details in the Salinas case, including transcripts of phone calls between Citibank officials. After Mr. Salinas's arrest in 1995 on murder charges -- he was later convicted of participating in the murder of his former brother-in-law -- the initial reaction of Citibank was to see whether his money could be shifted to Switzerland to make it more difficult for law enforcement officials to discover his assets, according to Senate aides. That idea was rejected, the aides said, when it was discovered that bank records in London and the United States, which could not be destroyed, would point to the Swiss accounts. The committee has also examined the case of Mr. Zadari, a former senator in Pakistan. Mr. Zadari, currently in jail on corruption charges, had about $40 million in Citibank Private Bank in Geneva. The bank has not been accused of wrongdoing, but internal Citibank audits as well as audits by federal bank examiners continually criticized managerial deficiencies in Citibank Private Bank in Switzerland, Senate documents show. Those audits and the investigation of the Salinas money led Mr. Reed to write to Citibank's board of directors in November 1997. "We live in a world where we have to worry about 'how someone made his/her money,' which did not used to be an issue," he said, according to portions of the letter excerpted in the Democratic draft report. "Much that we had done to keep Private Banking private becomes 'wrong' in the current environment." Another case study in the Senate inquiry involves the accounts of two of General Abacha's sons -- one of whom, Muhammad, has just been charged in Nigeria with the murder of the wife of his father's leading opponent. The New York private banker for the Nigerian account -- the same person who handled Mr. Bongo's account -- told staff investigators that for three years he thought his clients were Nigerian businessmen rather than the sons of Nigeria's military leader, the staff report says. When General Abacha died unexpectedly in June 1998, the Nigerian government began looking into his family's wealth and billions of dollars of missing money. With the corruption inquiry under way, Citibank got a request from one of the general's sons, saying he urgently needed $39 million from the London account, records show. But the money was in a time deposit that could not be redeemed for a while without a financial penalty, the staff report says. Citibank had long accommodated the Abacha family by setting up accounts with secret names like Gelsobella and Chinquinto. So the private bank found a way to immediately transfer the $39 million and avoid the penalty, documents show. Citibank records one month later say the transfer was meant to be the first step in the closing of the account by the client. But last March, before the account could be closed, a London court issued an order in a civil suit freezing all accounts related to General Abacha. Citigroup's lawyers have argued that the Senate committee is on shaky jurisdictional grounds because American money laundering statutes cover only proceeds of activities in foreign countries that fall under three categories of offenses: certain drug crimes, certain violent crimes, and fraud by or against a foreign bank, according to a letter last month to the committee from Mr. Gray. The letter goes on to say that the Democratic staff believes that money in the accounts of Mr. Bongo, General Abacha's sons and Jaime Lusinchi, a former president of Venezuela, may have been "derived from corruption or other improper acts against a foreign government." Even if true, Mr. Gray says in the letter, those offenses do not constitute crimes in the United States and thus fall outside the committee's jurisdiction. http://www.nytimes.com

COUNTRY: COTE D'IVOIRE (97%); EUROPE (79%); UNITED STATES (79%); WESTERN AFRICA (79%); EUROPEAN UNION MEMBER STATES (68%);
TEXT: Soldiers rampaged in the streets of Abidjan today, shooting wildly into the air, stealing cars and looting stores, apparently in a protest over unpaid wages. Residents dashed for cover as soldiers zoomed through Abidjan in stolen luxury sedans and four-wheel-drive vehicles, firing automatic weapons and shouting obscenities. Stores closed throughout the city, Ivory Coast's commercial capital, and barricades went up in some neighborhoods. More soldiers drove up and down the road leading east from Abidjan to Bingerville, a nearby town. Abandoned cars littered the deserted road, which is normally crowded with people and vehicles. Witnesses said the soldiers forced people from their cars and took off with the vehicles. "I am scared for my life and for my car," said a taxi driver, Koudjo Yao. "If I lose my car, I lose everything." Daniel Kadja, an official in the Ministry of Presidential Affairs, played down the rebellion, saying there was "no need to panic." The violence eased somewhat late tonight. A presidential official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said negotiations were under way with leaders of the uprising. The soldiers did not announce a reason for the protest, but individuals among them complained about unpaid salaries, poor living conditions and insufficient benefits like housing subsidies. Ivory Coast, a country of 19 million people, has long been considered a model of West African stability. But political and social turmoil have risen steadily as the country prepares for presidential elections, scheduled for next October. Earlier today, gunfire resounded near the national television and radio stations, which went off the air without explanation during the afternoon. Soldiers, some in uniform and others in T-shirts and caps, surrounded both broadcast centers. The gates of both were locked. United Nations staff members were trapped in their downtown offices across the street from the radio station, which appeared to be under attack, a United Nations spokesman, Fred Eckhard, said in New York. The gates to the American Embassy nearby were also locked. But the streets around the president's residence in suburban Cocody remained calm. The airport, on the southeastern edge of the city, continued to function normally. The rampage subsided as night approached, but sporadic gunfire continued and soldiers blocked off the main roads leaving the city. At least one tank was seen, and the thud of explosions could be heard in the distance. The State Department urged Americans in Abidjan to remain in their homes. The country has been plagued by mounting foreign debt and an economic downturn linked to the falling prices of its main exports, coffee and cocoa. Government coffers were depleted further this year when the European Union and the International Monetary Fund suspended aid because of corruption allegations. An opposition leader, Alassane Dramane Ouattara, accuses the government of harassing his political party. Last month, 12 leaders of his party, Rally of the Republicans, were jailed and a warrant has been issued for Mr. Ouattara's arrest. President Henri Konan Bedie says Mr. Ouattara is not eligible to run for president because his father was born in Burkina Faso. Mr. Ouattara denies the claim and says he has documents to prove his father's citizenship. Mr. Bedie, who has banned all outdoor demonstrations, went on national television on Wednesday to appeal for unity and calm. Looking nervous, he promised "reconciliation, peace, happiness and prosperity" if the opposition cooperated with the government.  http://www.nytimes.com Map of the Ivory Coast highlighting Abidjan: Troops in Abidjan fired weapons in the air and hijacked cars.

COUNTRY: COTE D'IVOIRE (96%); AFRICA (95%); WESTERN AFRICA (92%); FRANCE (90%); KENYA (79%); UNITED STATES (79%);
TEXT: Army troops in the West African country of Ivory Coast seized control of the capital, Abidjan, today and proclaimed a military government, an uprising unprecedented in a country long considered one of Africa's most stable. Soldiers began seizing government installations Thursday in what they said was a mutiny by an Abidjan-based unit over unpaid wages. Today, the former army chief of staff, Gen. Robert Guei, announced on state television that President Henri Konan Bedie was no longer in power. But Bedie said later in a radio interview that he retained power and was meeting with mutinous troops. Bedie appealed for popular resistance to the coup, but poor people in Abidjan's vast slums cheered his reported overthrow, said residents. Bedie's Democratic Party of Ivory Coast--the only party that has ruled there in nearly 40 years of independence--has lost support in the past decade over official corruption and rising demands for real democracy. Still, as some senior military officers and foreign diplomats reportedly implored Guei to halt the coup, independent observers found reason to hope that the crisis might be resolved peacefully. Ivory Coast--known officially by its French name, Cote d'Ivoire--has a large, educated middle class and civil society unlikely to support military rule. The strongest reason for optimism lay in how strongly the flavor of events once so common to transfers of power in Africa--dueling broadcasts, mutinous soldiers firing automatic weapons into the air and a man in uniform declaring the constitution null and void--now seemed out of place. Since the end of the Cold War, coups have become less frequent in Africa and, indeed, have never occurred in Ivory Coast. Self-appointed rulers who once could count on the United States or the Soviet Union to prop them up must answer to an array of Western donors, starting with the International Monetary Fund and World Bank. And their primary condition for foreign aid is at least the appearance of democracy. "That's the new atmosphere," said Herman J. Cohen, a former assistant secretary of state for Africa. "This general on the television doesn't seem to realize that." Ivory Coast, long ruled by the French troops and bureaucrats who created it, has remained one of France's most loyal former colonies in Africa. Its founder, Felix Houphouet-Boigny, ruled the country tightly for 33 years, permitting opposing political parties only when he could no longer prevent them without heavy bloodshed. Bedie, a bland machine politician in the ruling party, took power when Houphouet-Boigny died in 1993. Bedie won a disputed election and rode out protests and riots in 1995 after disqualifying his chief opponent. Soon after, Bedie dismissed Guei as army chief; officials alleged that Guei had been plotting a coup. On Thursday, soldiers drove into the state television station and fired into the air when some employees resisted orders to leave. Some of the employees fled to the U.S. Embassy's cultural center around the corner, and told Washington Post researcher Solomon Ababio that the troops were demanding back pay for their unit's service in a U.N. peacekeeping mission in the Central African Republic. In numerous parts of Abidjan, soldiers looted shops and were joined by impoverished civilians, residents said. No deaths were reported. Guei appeared on state television today, saying he had taken power at the troops' request. "From this instant, President Henri Konan Bedie is no longer the president of the republic," he said, and proclaimed the dissolution of parliament and other government institutions. A Military Committee of Public Salvation announced a dusk-to-dawn curfew and called on soldiers to cease looting. From a hiding place in the city's diplomatic neighborhood, Bedie responded in an interview on Radio France Internationale. He called on Ivorians to "resist and oppose this grotesque and retrograde military coup by all means possible," and vowed to remain at his post. He pledged to resolve the pay demands of the soldiers through "dialogue." An American reached by telephone in Abidjan described the mutineering soldiers as raucous, but said residents were calm. "There are [soldiers] roaring through the streets looking pretty ugly, with cars that have obviously been stolen," the resident said. "All the danger is potential danger, but the potential danger is there." The Christmas Eve crisis followed months of mounting opposition to Bedie. Like virtually all black African states created as European-ruled colonies, Ivory Coast is an artificial mix of ethnic groups. While Houphouet-Boigny ran an authoritarian government, he assiduously dampened ethnic tensions, partly by distributing wealth from the cocoa farms that are the pillar of the economy. But cocoa prices have fallen and the economy has struggled to keep up with a flood of immigration from Burkina Faso, Mali, Liberia, Ghana and other neighbors. In 1995, Bedie--an ethnic Baoule from the country's center--alienated many Muslim northerners by disqualifying northerner Alassane Ouattara from the presidential race, and tensions over that issue have revived as Bedie faces reelection next fall. "For a place where things are good, things are bad at the moment in Ivory Coast," said I. William Zartman, director of African Studies at the Johns Hopkins University's School of Advanced International Studies. He said the coup could yet be reversed or result in a more even-handed election than Bedie was prepared to allow. Correspondent James Rupert contributed to this report.

COUNTRY: COTE D'IVOIRE (99%); NIGERIA (92%); TOGO (79%); EUROPEAN UNION MEMBER STATES (79%); EUROPE (79%); UNITED STATES (79%); WESTERN AFRICA (79%); AFRICA (79%); FRANCE (76%);
TEXT: Portraying himself as a responsible leader, the former army chief who seized power here last week met today with foreign diplomats and vowed to honor Ivory Coast's huge foreign debts. Since the largely nonviolent coup, Gen. Robert Guei has been meeting with people from various sectors of society to outline his vision for the future. General Guei met with political party leaders on Monday and invited them to submit candidates for a transitional cabinet that he said could be announced next week. General Guei, who earlier had promised an "orderly" return to democracy, said today that he would improve on the record of the ousted president, Henri Konan Bedie, whose government was accused of rampant corruption that led the International Monetary Fund and European Union to cut aid this year. General Guei has not said, however, whether presidential elections scheduled for October would go ahead. An American Embassy official, speaking on condition of anonymity, cautiously praised General Guei for "making the right noises." But the official said the United States would continue to push for a return to constitutional rule and democracy. General Guei told diplomats that the coup had not been planned. He said he had merely responded to a spontaneous army uprising for better conditions and improved governance. "I had to make a choice to guarantee peace," General Guei said, and assure "security to all Ivoirian men and women." He also accused Mr. Bedie of deliberately fomenting political and ethnic divisions, including hiring private security companies to terrorize civilians. His claims could not immediately be verified. The Canadian ambassador, Don McMaster, however, condemned the overthrow. Canada has suspended all direct aid to Ivory Coast. Ambassador McMaster said: "Guei's response was: 'This wasn't a coup d'etat.' But whatever term you want to use, this is something we have to condemn." The military uprising began last Thursday with troops racing through the commercial capital, Abidjan, in seized luxury cars and shooting in the air. On Friday, General Guei declared that the military was in control and suspended the Constitution, courts and Parliament. He then appointed nine officers to a National Committee of Public Salvation that will oversee the country, with himself as president of the committee. Many Ivoirians welcomed the coup, saying they hoped that the army would improve Ivory Coast's declining economic and political conditions. Ivory Coast, a nation of 19 million people, had long been considered a model of stability in volatile West Africa. The military takeover was the country's first since it became independent from France in 1960. Political and social tensions have increased in recent months. President Bedie was widely criticized for banning outdoor political demonstrations and jailing opposition politicians. On Sunday, Mr. Bedie fled with family members to Lome, the capital of nearby Togo. The ousted president made a brief trip on Monday to Abuja, Nigeria, where he promised not to oppose the coup with violence and said he planned to spend his "forced asylum" trying to rally support for his government.  http://www.nytimes.com

COUNTRY: COTE D'IVOIRE (97%); EUROPE (94%); EUROPEAN UNION MEMBER STATES (90%); CANADA (79%); FRANCE (79%); UNITED STATES (79%); WESTERN AFRICA (79%); AFRICA (79%); NORTH AMERICA (79%);
TEXT: Accusing the ousted government of plundering state coffers, Ivory Coast's first military ruler, Gen. Robert Guei, said today that he was suspending the country's staggering foreign-debt payments. General Guei's announcement apparently reversed his pledge last week to honor international commitments inherited from the elected government that he ousted in a coup on Christmas Eve. "We have temporarily suspended payments of foreign commitments," General Guei said in a statement, explaining that coffers were empty. "Only after a thousand gymnastic moves were we even able to pay salaries." "As you can imagine, the pillage was immense and systematic," General Guei said in the statement. He said his administration had begun auditing state accounts to learn who is responsible for missing funds. He did not say whether Ivory Coast intended to resume debt payments later on to the World Bank, European Union, International Monetary Fund and other lenders. On Tuesday, General Guei named himself president and defense minister in an interim coalition government. The new cabinet was sworn in today. Ivory Coast, long one of Africa's most stable and prosperous countries, built up a huge debt -- estimated at $19.7 billion in 1996 -- during nearly four decades under the party of the ousted president, Henri Konan Bedie. The junta's move to halt debt payments threatens to aggravate the financial crisis. Last year, the monetary fund and the European Union slashed aid to the country after corruption allegations against the Bedie government. Since the coup, the United States and Canada have also cut aid to the West African country. France, the former colonial ruler, is scaling back its support. And the European Union's representative, Catherine Travin, said today that European officials were scheduled to hold talks with the junta that could lead to further aid cuts. The coup came during an economic decline linked to falling prices for Ivory Coast's main exports, coffee and cocoa. Tensions increased sharply during the final months of Mr. Bedie's government, which was widely accused of corruption and stirring ethnic enmities.  http://www.nytimes.com

COUNTRY: COTE D'IVOIRE (95%); FRANCE (93%); WESTERN AFRICA (92%); AFRICA (79%);
TEXT: In midswing, the construction hammers have fallen silent in this small town surrounded by the West African forest. The luminous Moroccan tiles have been set against the new mosque's walls, but concrete blocks bar the entrance to the unfinished staircase up the minaret. Across town, an inch of stagnant water sits at the bottom of the fountain in the shiny new multimillion-dollar conference hall, the residue of workers' testing the new plumbing. Will jets of water ever spurt joyfully from this fountain to splash against the green marble imported from Italy? Will the muezzin ever ascend the minaret to rouse the faithful to prayer? Those are the questions being asked these days in Daoukro, hometown of Henri Konan Bedie, recently ousted president of Ivory Coast, now in exile in Paris. Military coup leaders took power two weeks ago, in the country's first violent change of government since it won independence from France in 1960. They have accused Mr. Bedie of plundering the nation's wealth. The coup gained widespread support across the country, with the notable exception of Daoukro, its big loser. Since becoming president in 1993, Mr. Bedie, like his predecessor, Felix Houphouet-Boigny, had indulged in the longtime African tradition of spending lavish amounts of public money on his hometown. Despite its remoteness and population of only 14,000, Daoukro suddenly found itself with the best roads in the country and hugely expensive public works projects like a new hotel and a nightclub. Most of it remains a work in progress that, given the Christmas Eve coup, may no longer progress. Ivoirians grumbled about Mr. Houphouet-Boigny's excesses. But he was an autocrat with no political opposition. Above all, he was tolerated because he managed to turn Ivory Coast into the world's leading cocoa producer, the region's most stable country and French-speaking Africa's richest. He opened borders to poor immigrants from neighboring countries and deftly used ethnic politics to create harmony among the country's 60 ethnic groups. By contrast, Mr. Bedie proved a clumsy politician who presided over an increasingly corrupt government. He manipulated the 1995 elections, changing the laws to exclude his main rival, Alassane D. Ouattara, a prime minister under Mr. Houphouet-Boigny and until last year a deputy managing director at the International Monetary Fund. Most significantly, in the last year his party embarked on the xenophobic pursuit of so-called ivoirite, drawing distinctions between who was a pure Ivoirian and who was not. Clearly, Mr. Bedie's own ethnic group, the Baoule -- Mr. Houphouet-Boigny was also a Baoule -- were to be considered real Ivoirians, in contrast to the Muslim northerners who make up Mr. Ouattara's base. The xenophobic policies, coupled with the country's economic decline, worsened ethnic tensions. That was one of the reasons cited by the new military ruler, Gen. Robert Guei, a member of the Yacouba minority from the southwest, for staging the coup that made Daoukro a town of long faces. "You see those trucks there?" asked the assistant manager of a Shell gas station in the town center, pointing at two flatbeds parked across the street. "They've been idle there since the coup. They used to carry sand and gravel for all the construction. If they stay parked, that means no business for us." People have stopped coming here to pay homage to Mr. Bedie's family. At Le Zenith restaurant, as at others, business is slack. "Now the people who come don't even tip," said a waitress who gave her name only as Monique, making a face. "Nothing's working now. If nothing works here, we'll have to go somewhere else. Everything worked before." After Mr. Bedie became the country's second president since independence, and workers began breaking ground on several projects, the locals saw Daoukro grow into a town with few rural rivals. Some had even dared to dream that Daoukro would become another Yamoussoukro, a town of 15,000 that, as the birthplace of Mr. Houphouet-Boigny, was turned into the country's capital. "That was my wish," said Zacharia Sankara, 21, somewhat wistfully, as he peered through the wrought-iron gates surrounding the unfinished mosque that Mr. Bedie, a Christian, had offered as a gift to Mr. Sankara and his fellow Muslims. "But now it's not even sure that all the projects here will be finished. I am even asking myself whether this mosque will be finished -- or will it stay like this?" Yamoussoukro, a capital yet in the making, perhaps already in the unmaking, stands about 90 miles west of here. Mr. Houphouet-Boigny was a couple of decades into his presidency when he chose to elevate his hometown at the expense of Abidjan, which is by far the country's largest city and considered the most modern in West Africa. By 1983, the equivalent of moving Washington to Hope, Ark., had been done. And eventually what had been forest, cocoa and coconut plantations had a six-lane boulevard, luxury hotels, and a presidential palace surrounded by artificial lagoons alive with crocodiles. Most impressive, though, was the Roman Catholic basilica that Mr. Houphouet-Boigny had built, at an estimated cost of more than $300 million. The Notre Dame de la Paix basilica became the world's largest church -- even bigger than St. Peter's in Rome -- with handblown French stained glass in 4,000 different tints and tons of marble shipped from Italy to cover a 7.4-acre esplanade. The basilica's 7,000 seats each have individual air-conditioning ducts. But a decade after Pope John Paul II reluctantly sanctified the structure, cracks have appeared in the marble esplanade, and trees and shrubbery are growing unchecked. Only a couple of hundred faithful regularly attend Sunday Mass, and even on the major Christian holidays the basilica is only half full. (Christmas Mass was canceled last month because of the coup.) Yamoussoukro has generally been declining since Mr. Houphouet-Boigny's death in 1993. Embassies never moved there from Abidjan; neither did the government's own ministries. The luxury hotels and wide boulevards grew emptier still as political pilgrims dropped Yamoussoukro in favor of Mr. Bedie's hometown. Where they will go next is anyone's guess. General Guei, the coup leader, has promised elections but given no date yet. A transitional government has been named, comprising mostly military officials, technocrats and members of Mr. Ouattara's party, the Rally of Republicans. Laurent Gbagbo, leader of another opposition party, pulled out of the transitional government at the last minute, describing it as heavily tilted toward Mr. Ouattara's party and strongly suggesting what many Ivoirians suspect -- that Mr. Ouattara's party knew of the coup beforehand. "We realize that this is a coup d'etat by the R.D.R," Mr. Gbagbo said, using the Ouattara party's initials. "It is a government by the R.D.R." Mr. Ouattara, acutely aware as a former monetary fund official that being associated with a coup would create problems with international lenders, has denied any prior knowledge. Upon returning to Ivory Coast from a three-month exile in France, he immediately began describing the overthrow as a "revolution" of the Ivoirian people. Whatever it was, Mr. Bedie will probably not return here despite having declared that he will be his party's next presidential candidate. Authorities in his party said in a statement that they no longer recognized him as their leader. Mr. Bedie is "on leave," the statement read, with the usual French politesse. Even here in Daoukro, people seem resigned to the fact that its native son is history. During the coup they feared reprisals, and elderly women and children fled into the forest. Most have now returned, though soldiers and police officials still restrict entry into town. The authorities let a reporter in but forbade taking photographs of the mosque and the new Hotel de la Paix, with the three separate bungalows for private presidential meetings that will never take place. People milling around the mosque were philosophical. "In life, one man can't be in power forever," said Asate Konate, a woman in her 60's. "Maybe the new government will take pity on us and finish the mosque." Unlike others, Mamadou Sylla, a man in his 20's, said he had never dreamed the Yamoussoukro dream. "The times had changed," Mr. Sylla said. "There was multi partyism. Bedie would never have been able to push through the big projects that Houphouet created." "It was fair play," he said of Daoukro's status as the country's big loser. "It was fair play." It took an outsider, a police official assigned to Daoukro, to find the positive. "Little by little the country will be developed," the official said, adding that the next president would do the same thing in his home region. "Eventually," he predicted, "each region in the country will have its own Hotel de la Paix." The worry, the police official conceded, is whether the development can be maintained, or whether it will start slowly deteriorating as it has in Yamoussoukro. A new road leads east out of Daoukro, its dividing lines painted fresh, its shoulders meticulously marked off. Alongside are signs warning of schoolchildren crossing, setting speed limits, naming each little village at least three times -- extra touches unseen elsewhere in the country and certainly not in the potholed north. The road goes up and down lush reddish hills, cutting a swath through the region's verdant forest. It is a thoroughfare worthy of an American suburb, a drive pleasant enough to use in a Mercedes or Lexus commercial. About 25 miles east, the road comes to a year-old bridge over the Comoe River. The asphalt abruptly ends on the other side. Under the bridge, the engineers' chalk notes are still visible against the walls, near graffiti someone has scrawled: "Forgive us our sins." Koffi Kouakou, a cheerful 30-year-old farmer, crossed the bridge on his bicycle, drawn by the sight of a stranger standing with a notepad. "Oh, we loved him so much!" Mr. Kouakou exclaimed about Mr. Bedie. "Because he was a son of Daoukro, he took care of us. We now have the Hotel de la Paix. We could have never imagined that before. It used to take us three hours to get from the center of town to this bridge before the road was paved, and we had to cross on a ferry." "Look at this bridge," he added, knitting his eyebrows and pointing to some cracks that had already appeared. "They said they would fix this. But will they now? And will the road be completed?" Mr. Kouakou pedaled away, returning in the direction he had come from, toward the asphalt. The other way, for about 30 miles, the road runs past gutters that have already been dug in villages, past big red X's on houses condemned to accommodate the future asphalt. It is a dusty road of dirt and decay and pebbles, paved only in the imagination of a deposed president and the people of Daoukro.  http://www.nytimes.com

COUNTRY: AFRICA (94%); UNITED STATES (79%);
TEXT: Why shouldn't countries pay their bills? I have to pay mine. That's a critical question hanging over the "dump the debt" rally scheduled to take place on the Mall this afternoon, when demonstrators will urge international lenders to write off the hundreds of billions of dollars owed to them by the world's poorest nations. Without declaring bankruptcy and giving up control of our own finances, most of us cannot imagine being excused from paying back money we had borrowed--and if we did, we certainly wouldn't expect the bank to lend to us again. Even World Bank President James Wolfensohn--who supports a certain amount of debt relief himself--thinks it would be "whimsical" to cancel every nation's debt. "If you have a society based on debt forgiveness," Wolfensohn said in February, "who's going to invest in debt anymore? So you really screw up the market." In more than one Third World embassy here in Washington, the same fear has been expressed. Of course these diplomats want debt relief. But their countries are poor, many of them devastated by natural disasters or civil wars, and they will surely need to borrow more money to survive and develop. What bank would throw good money after bad? Let's consider that question. In particular, let's consider Africa, the continent where 33 of the 41 Heavily Indebted Poor Countries--the HIPC nations, so defined by the World Bank and International Monetary Fund--can be found, and therefore the continent on which much of the debt-relief campaign is focused. Having spent much of the last 20 years reporting and writing from Africa, I'll begin with a bit of history.  The bottom began falling out of African economies in the early 1970s. Most nations had been independent for little more than a decade, and either didn't understand--or didn't want to--that the boom in prices for their mineral and agricultural exports was not permanent. Inexperienced or corrupt leaders borrowed, spent and then borrowed some more, urged on by Western commercial lenders eager to start earning interest on the petrodollars that had been deposited in their banks by newly flush OPEC moguls. This symbiosis of greedy governments and overeager lenders meant that billions of dollars flowed into African nations for economic expansion, which often took the form of huge industrialization projects and ostentatious, politically visible structures in capital cities. In addition, about 20 percent of the funds lent during these Cold War years went to arms purchases. Debt was increasing but new governments did not feel it. The lenders were getting their initial paybacks. Good money was borrowed and thrown after bad whenever needed. Everyone was making out like bandits; everyone, that is, except poor African citizens, growing in numbers and generally not sharing the wealth of their rulers. Then came the oil shocks of 1973 and 1979, which triggered worldwide inflation and recession. Prices for African commodities collapsed; prices for basic necessities like fuel and fertilizer skyrocketed. By the early 1980s, Africa was reeling just as repayment on loans taken out a few years earlier came due. Most of Africa's debt at that time was owed to private banks. When these institutions realized African nations could not cover their debts, they lobbied multilateral agencies such as the IMF to lend African countries the money to pay off the debts. That's how Citibank got out of bad loans to the country then called Zaire (and it helped that Mobutu Sese Seko's Zaire was a Cold War ally of the United States). Citibank got bailed out, but Zaire (now Congo) didn't--it just owed money to a different lender.
