Some human rights monitors, like Amnesty International, have said they believe that Zimbabwe's refusal of further international aid is a prelude to the use of food as a bargaining tool to win support for the governing party in the elections next year. Last month's events in Lupane district hardly dispel that notion. Mr. Komichi said that as voters lined up on May 15 at the Lupane Business Center, the ramshackle commercial hub in Lupane village, they were greeted by stacked sacks of corn and government supporters handing out coupons to potential supporters. He and others say the Lupane election was marred by official fraud and manipulation. Starting in late March, the government bused in members of its feared Green Bombers youth militia to register as voters. The militia members were then dispersed throughout the province to wage a strong-arm campaign to get out the vote for the government candidate. As part of a nationwide campaign to build local support, the government has awarded the nation's influential traditional elders monthly salaries of 1.5 million Zimbabwean dollars -- about $450 at current rates -- and Mazda pickup trucks. The independent Zimbabwe Election Support Network reported that the elders and their subordinates, who control patronage and property in most villages, stood vigil at Lupane polling places last month, ostentatiously ticking off the names of villagers who arrived to vote. ''They're threatened by a simple thing: 'If you don't vote ZANU-PF, we will know it,''' Mr. Komichi said. ''And you will be chased away from your village, your home.'' On May 11, four days before the election, Mr. Komichi and other opposition workers were jailed after government supporters attacked young men putting up posters about a speech by the leader of the Movement for Democratic Change, Morgan Tsvangirai. Many were not freed until May 13, after the speech, which, like most opposition rallies, was ringed by ZANU-PF trucks and activists wearing party T-shirts. Mr. Komichi, a member of the opposition party since it was formed in 1999, said he was running some risk by complaining to a foreigner about the election irregularities. He added that after a half-dozen arrests and a beating, he did not mind. ''I am committed,'' he said. ''I am a politician. I have to be known. I am not violating any law by speaking. I am actually following the Constitution of my nation.''  URL: http://www.nytimes.com

COUNTRY: ZIMBABWE (99%); AFRICA (92%); SOUTH AFRICA (79%)
TEXT: Zimbabwe's parliament voted Tuesday to give President Robert Mugabe new constitutional powers to seize farmland and to restrict travel by government opponents in a country whose government is already regarded as among the most repressive in Africa. The parliament, flush with new members from Mugabe's ruling party after a March legislative election that was denounced by many international observers as rigged,  cast 103 votes for the constitutional changes, enough for the two-thirds majority needed in the body of 150 members. News reports from Harare, the Zimbabwean capital, said ruling party lawmakers began singing and dancing over the victory. The practical effect of the changes was hard to predict in a country where the government has already endorsed violent land invasions, demolished hundreds of thousands of homes, shuttered independent newspapers and threatened would-be protesters with arrest and attack. But opposition leaders predicted that Mugabe, who is expected to swiftly sign the changes into law, would soon revoke their passports, making it more difficult for them to lobby for international pressure against Mugabe's autocratic leadership. "We are the immediate targets," said Paul Themba Nyathi, spokesman for the opposition Movement for Democratic Change, speaking by phone from Bulawayo, Zimbabwe's second-largest city. "They are going to take away our passports. I'm sure of that." Nyathi and others, however, said the vote was mainly an act of defiance by Mugabe's government, which has increasingly been isolated by the United Nations and most of the developed world. In July, the United Nations issued a sharply worded report condemning Mugabe's Operation Murambatsvina, or "Drive Out the Rubbish," a demolition campaign that left 700,000 people homeless or without jobs. "This is them thumbing their nose at the rest of the world," Nyathi said of Tuesday's vote in parliament. Mugabe's spokesman, George Charamba, could not be reached by phone Tuesday. On state radio, Agriculture Minister Joseph Made praised the new legal restrictions placed on white former farm owners who seek to challenge government confiscations of their land. "Today is a happy moment," Charamba said, according to the Reuters news service. "This gives us an opportunity as Zimbabweans to be the true owners of the land and to be truly independent." Faced with hyperinflation, 70 percent unemployment and a paralyzing shortage of fuel, Mugabe has recently sought financial assistance from friendly countries, including South Africa and China. A team from the International Monetary Fund, meanwhile, has been making a final evaluation before deciding whether to expel Zimbabwe for failing to pay $295 million in debt. But Mugabe, 81, Zimbabwe's ruler since 1980, has steadfastly resisted any political reform, refusing even to meet with opposition leaders. Among the constitutional changes approved Tuesday was the creation of a 65-member senate, which opponents said would merely give Mugabe more opportunities for patronage by appointing members of his party. The measure limiting rights of appeal against government land seizures drew strong opposition from lawyers. It also touched a particularly raw nerve politically. Many Zimbabweans date the decline of their once-prosperous economy to the government-sanctioned invasions of white-owned commercial farms that began in 2000. Although the seizures have been popular with landless peasants who were given farms, agricultural production in Zimbabwe, once regarded as the region's breadbasket, has plummeted so dramatically that millions of Zimbabweans now rely on international food donations each year. The economy also has contracted by at least one-third in that time. Lovemore Madhuku, a government opponent who chairs a civic group called the National Constitutional Assembly, denounced the changes as contrary to the wishes of Zimbabweans. His group has led efforts to seek a comprehensive review of the constitution. "We are concerned that government continues to make law without consulting the broad section of our country," Madhuku said by phone from Harare.

Ivory Coast's ruling junta postponed its presidential elections today, saying the move was necessary to prepare for a "credible and transparent" vote to return the nation to civilian rule. The month-long postponement comes amid rising ethnic tensions and political uncertainty in the country, which was, until last year, an island of stability in the volatile West African region. Government spokesman Lt. Henri Cesar Sama announced on state radio that the vote, originally scheduled for Sept. 17, will not be held until Oct. 22. The National Electoral Commission requested the delay because it needed more time to prepare the balloting, he said. Diplomats and international observers had warned for several weeks that electoral preparations were far behind schedule and the timetable needed to be adjusted. The delay will likely heighten the tensions. Gen. Robert Guei, who took control after lower-ranking soldiers seized power on Christmas Eve, caused a national uproar this month by announcing his candidacy for the presidency, despite having initially pledged not to seek office. The United States and France took the unusual step of publicly urging Guei not to run, saying his candidacy would taint the electoral process because he would be in a position, as junta leader, to manipulate the results. Those opposing Guei say he is ineligible to run because he is an active duty military officer; Guei says he is retired. In a nationally televised address Tuesday night, Guei defended his bid for office, saying there "is much left to do" to rebuild the country and that his candidacy reflects no personal ambition. The coup d'etat Guei led in December was the first in this country, where long-time president Felix Houphouet-Boigny ran a one-party system that emphasized ethnic and religious harmony. Houphouet-Boigny ran the country from 1960, when Ivory Coast gained independence from France, until his death in 1993. Now, that unity seems to be jeopardized. Guei's main opponent is likely to be former prime minister and International Monetary Fund official Alassane Ouattara, a Muslim from the north. But his candidacy is being challenged under a controversial provision of the nation's new constitution, which says that both a candidate's mother and father must be Ivorian born. Ouattara's opponents argue that one of his parents was born in neighboring Burkina Faso, something he denies. In recent weeks, the military has been particularly harsh on Ouattara's party. This month, troops used whips and clubs to break up a legally authorized march by Ouattara supporters, stripping some naked and forcing them to crawl on their knees down the street. This week security forces summoned the nation's leading Muslim clerics, who support Ouattara, and accused them of trying to "destabilize" the government and plotting a coup. The other main candidate could be former interior minister Emile Constant Bombet. But Bombet is accused of corruption and could become ineligible if formal charges are lodged against him. The Constitutional Chamber of the supreme court has until two weeks before the election to rule on candidates' eligibility, but independent observers have challenged its impartiality because the chamber's president served as Guei's legal adviser before being appointed to the court.

When Gen. Robert Guei was drafted by mutinous soldiers to head an interim government after they ousted the elected leadership on Christmas Eve, Ivory Coast political parties and friendly governments welcomed his promises of a quick return to democracy. But now there is growing concern among political leaders and diplomats that Guei, who has pledged to remain neutral in a presidential election set for October, will succumb to pressure from the army's unruly, undisciplined and restless enlisted men and launch his own presidential bid--or simply abort the return to civilian rule. Either move, diplomats and analysts warn, would be a serious setback for West Africa, where most countries have histories of political instability, coups and corrupt military leadership. Until the Christmas Eve takeover--the first ever here--Ivory Coast was viewed as one of West Africa's few bastions of stability and progress. Last week in Senegal, another regional bright spot, the governing Socialist Party lost power after 40 years in a second round of elections, but the situation in the rest of the region is grimmer. The fragile eight-month-old civilian government in Nigeria, Africa's most populous country, is struggling with corruption and ethnic and religious strife. Most of the other countries, notably Sierra Leone and Liberia, are suffering from festering civil wars and political unrest, making a smooth return to democracy in Ivory Coast especially important, diplomats say. A Guei candidacy "would set a horrible precedent. . . . [He] will condemn the credibility of the entire transition if he has partisan interests to protect," said Christopher Fomunyoh, West Africa director of the Washington-based National Democratic Institute. "The only way to end this is for [Guei] to be clear and unequivocal about leading the transition in a neutral and transparent way." Following a recent tour of military barracks across the country, Guei has grown increasingly and publicly ambivalent about his plans, refusing to rule out a presidential bid because of pressure from the troops to retain power, according to people who deal regularly with him. That ambivalence, Ivorian and diplomatic sources say, is strengthening the military faction that wants to retain control, either through a Guei candidacy or by canceling elections. Guei's office did not return a reporter's phone calls. Rumblings from recent abortive coup plots coupled with an erosion of discipline in the army have weakened Guei's grip on the military, diplomats and analysts say. A disintegration of command and control structures was demonstrated recently when enlisted men defied Guei's direct orders to dismantle concrete and barbed wire barricades that were erected around radio and television stations during the coup. Enlisted men control the main military base, where the army's weapons are stored. Many here in the capital are most troubled by policemen and soldiers who regularly shake down motorists for small bribes in broad daylight. While petty corruption has long been a fact of life here, many residents say the new brazenness has heightened their sense of insecurity and uncertainty. Many of the soldiers on the streets are wearing new boots and uniforms from a lot of 800 provided by the U.S. military after a counter-terrorism training course that ended just before the coup. "You see policemen and soldiers drunk in the morning, wearing dark glasses and demanding money for nothing," said one businessman. "It never used to be like that. Never. They can act with impunity, and increasingly they do." Regional leaders, as well as French and U.S. diplomats, have warned Guei that international support for Ivory Coast, already tenuous, would dry up if he were to run or call off the balloting. The country's budget, about 30 percent of which comes from European aid and international lending organizations, has already been hit hard because much of the aid was suspended after the coup. The lack of resources and the growing deterioration of discipline in army ranks have made Guei's position tenuous, local and diplomatic sources say. The troops rioted in the first place because the government had withheld the pay they earned as U.N. peacekeepers in the Central African Republic. Since then, Guei has been unable to meet the soldiers' demands for increased pay and greater resources, so they have been trying to make money on the street. One diplomat described the army as "a multi-headed monster" in which "the officers are clearly not in charge." Thus, they say, Guei must tread softly to avoid a potentially bloody showdown. "The enlisted men mutinied and then brought Guei in, and they remind him constantly that he owes his position to them," the diplomat said. "They want their slice of the pie after years of neglect, and there is definitely a faction in the military that does not want a return to civilian rule." Senior political leaders--many of whom were initially sympathetic to the coup because of the authoritarianism and corruption of President Henri Konan Bedie's regime--are now growing uneasy. "What we want is for the military to return to its barracks as quickly as possible, with a good democratic transition and with a legal government in place," said one political leader in contact with the president. "But Gen. Guei is not alone, and there are a lot of voices competing to be heard. We still trust Guei, but he may be under too much pressure. If he gets it into his head to be a candidate, it will be a disaster." Guei's relationship with the country's leading political parties is also tenuous. While the Rally of Republicans--led by former International Monetary Fund deputy director Alassane Ouattara--generally supported the coup because the party was being challenged by the Bedie government, it has most to lose if Guei runs. "We still trust Guei," said one Rally leader, "but . . . if he gets it into his head to be a candidate it will be a disaster." Because of Guei's perceived closeness to Ouattara's party and the fact that several Rally leaders accepted cabinet positions in Guei's government, other parties distrust him. Opposition leaders routinely charge that Ouattara is the real power behind Guei and that Guei plans to run or postpone the elections because Ouattara cannot win. Guei reacted angrily to such charges, telling local journalists: "I am not a hostage of any political party or at the service of any political leader." He said he plans to "do the will of the people," a phrase he has used often.

War veterans shouted down President Robert G. Mugabe during a speech, stormed his party headquarters, and reportedly mooned one of his ministers to protest suspended disability pay. In parliament, Mugabe's ruling party has defied him. Disgruntled farm laborers have marched to demand better work conditions, and urban workers angered by tax hikes shut down this capital city for a day. All this discontent over the past year was just prelude. Last month, this city was hit by its first serious wave of unrest in 18 years of independence, as thousands of rioters angered by yet another price hike for maize meal, the staple food, caused such destruction and anarchy for three days that the army was deployed to restore order. As this formerly socialist nation undergoes a difficult transition to a free market, Mugabe finds himself not only in battle with an economy out of control, but with an increasingly restive populace. Zimbabweans once saw him as father of the nation -- he led the independence struggle against Britain -- but now want to know what he has done for them lately. Not enough, the riots seemed to say. Many people predict that if the government does not rein in the spiraling prices, a depreciating currency, rampant unemployment and creeping governmental corruption, then more unrest will likely follow. In Chitungwiza, a suburb 12 miles south of the city center where a large shopping mall was picked clean of virtually all products in the January rioting, a young woman named Florence said more riots were needed to force the government into action. "We want it to happen again, because nothing has changed." In this nation of 12 million -- peaceful during the years of socialist policies, which ended in the early 1990s -- scenes of rioters looting stores and battling with police would appear to represent instability. But this is a de facto one-party state in which Mugabe's party holds all but three of the 150 seats in parliament. Some analysts say the grass-roots protest movement represents a new form of unorganized political opposition that could bode well for democratization -- if it does not mushroom out of control. "They are not afraid anymore," Sam Moyo of the Southern African Regional Institute for Policy Studies said of the protesters. "This is a series of mutinies," said Morgan Tsvangirai, secretary general of the 300,000-member Zimbabwe Congress of Trade Unions, which called the one-day strike in December and has threatened to do it again. Even the government-run Herald newspaper has chimed in with criticism. It castigated government ministers for being out of touch and warned that Zimbabwe would see "a disaster unfold" if the government did not realize that the riots must represent "the end of the era of business as usual." In response to the riots, the government ordered the maize price increase rescinded. It had acted similarly in response to the December labor strike, when it withdrew a new wage levy. Mugabe also has established a ministerial commission to look into price levels, the crash of the currency, market competition and ways of creating jobs. Unemployment is 50 percent. The government also has assured international lenders that it will reduce state spending and privatize state assets. It will also attempt to restore confidence in the national currency, the Zimbabwe dollar, which lost 75 percent of its value against the dollar on one bleak day in November, and rebuild the foreign reserves which were so depleted that the government had trouble covering import costs late last year. The International Monetary Fund said last week that it soon may approve $ 176 million in balance-of-payments support to ease the crisis and help spur reforms. But the government has promised reform before, then abruptly shifted course for political expediency. The current crisis stems from the domino effect of a series of economic calamities set in motion by corruption charges last year. It began in March. Faced with allegations that Mugabe's ministers and other high officials had looted a disability fund for veterans of the liberation war, the government suspended payments while it investigated who got the money and why. A cabinet minister admitted that she received thousands of dollars she should not have from the fund. Veterans protested the suspension. To quiet the 50,000 veterans eligible for compensation, Mugabe promised them lump sums totaling $ 260 million -- from a national budget deeply in debt and in which no provision had been made for such an impromptu payout. Investors got jittery and the stock exchange began to flutter. Then, it was revealed that foreign reserves were so low that imports could barely be covered for November and December. In response, the currency fell like an anchor. Meanwhile, in a move a Western diplomat described as a "political diversion," Mugabe declared that his government would make good on its promise to acquire land for the rural poor by expropriating land of underutilized commercial farms, most of which are owned by whites. Whites are a 2 percent minority of the population but own 70 percent of the nation's arable land, much of it seized from blacks during the colonial era. With the announcement of the land plan, the economy shook further, since agriculture accounts for 40 percent of exports and fueled Zimbabwe's estimated 6 percent economic growth last year -- a growth rate that made it an economic leader in the region. At the same time, Mugabe's cabinet -- over the protests of parliament -- slapped a controversial levy on workers' salaries and more price hikes on consumer goods to cover the veterans' payout. This awakened the wrath of labor, which mounted its December strike. Then came January and housewives' discovery last week that the price of maize had been raised 21 percent, the third hike in four months. Maize is a staple of the Zimbabwean diet. Sadza, or boiled maize, which is similar to grits, traditionally is eaten only for supper and dinner, although many poor families unable to afford other food have begun eating it for breakfast, as well. "Those ministers, they eat and they have everything and we are suffering," said Kate Chawora, 26, a woman expecting her second child. Her husband works in a factory. "We are trying harder to buy everything. The money isn't enough. The wages which our husbands are paid cannot match with the prices." Some reports say mothers were among the most volatile elements of the population when the maize meal price hike was discovered in local markets. In the riots the followed, five people reportedly were killed. Information Minister Chen Chimutengwende blamed whites for the situation. He said they want to punish Mugabe for his land acquisition plan. "There was an element of massive profiteering and massive taking advantage of the situation by some businessmen who are mainly white," he said. "It's no longer market forces; it's cartels." Through it all, Mugabe has remained aloof, some say. A leader who views himself as an international statesman as much as a president, in part because he leads the Organization of African Unity, he spends much of his time abroad, including 22 foreign trips last year, by the Western diplomat's count. What happens next is largely dependent on Mugabe's next move, many here say. Within his government, "the culture now is such that no one questions his decisions," an economic analyst said. "No one challenges his proposals or ideas." They don't question him openly, but some here say that criticism of Mugabe has slowly and quietly begun to filter out of his ruling clique. And Mugabe may face yet another crisis soon: The trade union group has warned of another protest within the next month.

Warfare has escalated in Sierra Leone, underscoring a stalemate in diplomatic efforts to force the military junta to accept a return to civilian rule. In recent days, reports of battles in the jungles and rice-growing lands of the southeast have trickled out of Sierra Leone. They say thousands of people have been forced from their villages by the fighting, in which traditional tribal hunters, known as kamajors, oppose government troops. The biggest recent battle has been over Tongo, one of Sierra Leone's main diamond-mining towns. Kamajors captured Tongo on Jan. 17-18, forcing at least 4,000 civilians to flee, according to the International Committee of the Red Cross in Freetown, the capital. The junta seized power last May but agreed in October to hand it back to the civilian president, Ahmad Tejan Kabbah, on April 22. But a truce has failed to take hold, and a West African peacekeeping force that was to have deployed across the country by December has not done so. The government, an awkward alliance between the Sierra Leonean army and a longtime rebel movement, has been divided almost from the start on whether to hand back power, and analysts say it appears unlikely to do so by the deadline. Sierra Leone is an extreme example of many chronic African political ills. Colonial rulers -- in this case, the British -- built a centralized bureaucracy that held power only by military force and exploited the economy. The end of colonialism left a handful of political factions in the capital to struggle for control of the bureaucracy, which, through corruption, was the country's only source of wealth. During the nearly four decades since Sierra Leone -- and most other African colonies -- gained independence, the narrow concentration of power has excluded and impoverished rural peoples. The state's corruption and lack of popular support has left it unable to exercise control in the countryside. Last year, the United Nations' annual study of global development found Sierra Leone the world's poorest country. Its 5 million people are estimated to live, on average, 34 years, and only about 30 percent learn to read and write. Since the 1970s, deprivation has been most acute in the south and east -- and in 1991, a radical guerrilla group, the Revolutionary United Front, began an armed rebellion in those areas. A junta that seized power in 1992 proved unable to contain the rebellion. In Sierra Leone's biggest step toward pluralist, democratic rule, it held elections in 1996 and handed power to the winner -- Kabbah, a former diplomat. Kabbah negotiated a truce with the Revolutionary United Front and cut the state budget deficit as part of a program, with the International Monetary Fund, to stabilize the economy. Last May, low-ranking soldiers, paid as little as $ 18 per month, rebelled over army layoffs and cuts in rice rations. They chose a mutinous officer, Maj. Johnny Paul Koromah, to lead them and invited the Revolutionary United Front guerrillas to join them in a government called the Armed Forces Revolutionary Council. A unit of Nigerian troops, which had been based in Freetown to provide security and technical help to Kabbah's government, briefly fought the coup before retreating to hold the main airport. Koromah declared he would keep power until 2001. But international sanctions, divisions between the Revolutionary United Front and the Sierra Leonean army, and opposition from Kabbah supporters have prevented the junta from gaining full control. In rural villages, many of which suffered heavily from years of Revolutionary United Front raiding, traditional tribal hunting associations have formed a militia, under Kabbah's main military aide, to support the ousted president. Nigerian troops, warships and warplanes have periodically shelled or bombed the country -- and they enforce a semi-effective economic blockade. Neighboring states and the United Nations have isolated the junta, imposing an embargo on arms and oil sales. This month, President Clinton barred members of the ruling junta or their families from traveling to the United States. In Freetown, "the sanctions are biting hard, but people are coping," said Babsy Coker-Gibbs, editor of a local magazine. Despite the blockade, small boats smuggle in enough oil to run the city's power plant and fuel cars, "although [auto] fuel is four to five times the normal price," she said by telephone. Both sides in the conflict reported the fighting at Tongo, although both now claim to control the town and its diamond deposits -- one of the economy's few sources of wealth. About 4,000 to 6,000 refugees have fled toward the eastern town of Kenema, said Alexandra Mateevich, of the Red Cross in Freetown. Travelers reaching Freetown have described burned villages and bodies by the road. The government said last week it had captured Grima, a small town near Koribundu, and other clashes have been reported but not confirmed. Koromah's government has refused to disarm its forces as the October accord requires, saying that Nigeria should free the Revolutionary United Front leader, Cpl. Foday Sankannah Sankoh, who it has detained since the coup. Koromah also says Nigeria has taken sides in the dispute and should not be permitted to keep its leading role in the West African peacekeeping force.

President Daniel arap Moi's swearing-in ceremony in the next day or two will cap a tumultuous week in which irregularities fouled Kenya's third multi-party election since its independence 35 years ago. Yet the story is far from over. This election -- which could have reassured foreign governments, domestic and international investors, and Kenyans themselves -- instead has cemented a sense of deepening social and political crisis in this country of 27 million. Once considered one of East Africa's more stable countries, it now is judged among the more fragile states. Its economy has imploded. Corruption is pervasive. The infrastructure is a wreck. Urban unemployment has skyrocketed. Basic government services, such as schools and health care, are a shambles. Ethnic tensions have sharpened. Thus far Kenya has remained relatively peaceful in the face of a disorganized, ill-managed election, accusations against the government of vote-rigging and the opposition's rejection of provisional results. The electoral commission announced late Friday that Moi, who faced 11 challengers, had garnered 39 percent, with most of the vote counted. He is followed by Mwai Kibaki, a former vice president, with 33 percent and Raila Odinga, with 11.5 percent. It also appeared that Moi easily would gain a required 25 percent of the vote in five of Kenya's eight provinces. At least eight people have died in election-related violence, but most of the nation remains calm. Yet no one is taking bets on how long the peace will last. Increasingly urgent political and economic uncertainties and problems are prodding Kenya toward "social instability," one diplomat said. "Everybody's patience has a breaking point. If these trends continue, that breaking point could come sooner, rather than later." Not long ago, Kenya was the jewel of East Africa, despite Moi's authoritarian rule. It boasted decent roads, strong telecommunications, a fine education system, a blooming economy, a vibrant middle class and a safe, well-kept capital. Things worked. It was known for its spectacular greenery and its rich wildlife. Numerous international organizations placed regional headquarters here. The turmoil that paralyzed surrounding countries only burnished Kenya's image. Sudan was enmeshed in a decades-long civil war. A brutal communist dictatorship was strangling Ethiopia. Uganda was emerging from civil war. Somalia was hurtling toward one. Today, as countries such as Ethiopia, Uganda and Tanzania have tugged themselves toward relative stability, Kenya is tumbling in the opposite direction. On recent trips to East Africa, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright and first lady Hillary Rodham Clinton bypassed Kenya. One primary problem is an economy crippled by corruption, mismanagement and political uncertainty. Last year, government corruption compelled the International Monetary Fund to suspend a $ 205 million loan, and political unrest caused tourism -- the government's main source of foreign exchange -- to plummet by 60 percent. Foreign and domestic investment has halted, and economic analysts say that this election will only further wither the confidence of potential investors. Meanwhile, the government is racing toward bankruptcy. The decimated tourism industry, settlement of a national teachers' strike and election-related spending -- much of it allegedly used to aid the ruling party -- have helped wipe out the government's revenue. It faces a growing deficit, and interest rates, already prohibitive, are expected to keep climbing. These pressures squeeze a country that is the 22nd poorest in the world. Some 500,000 to 700,000 job seekers enter the employment market annually, only to find pitifully few jobs. The government has corraled inflation in the past year or so, but prices for most basic foodstuffs have doubled or tripled this decade. As she waited to vote at a Nairobi polling station last Monday, Christine Gathoni, 23, said she is paying twice as much for milk, bread, rice and corn meal, compared with recent years. She pays nearly three times as much for sugar. Gathoni, a receptionist, is eight months pregnant. She was not planning to vote for Moi. "If we get another president, things will change," Gathoni said. A new president would "make life easier. We need jobs." However, she was resigned to Moi retaining power and convinced that he and the ruling party would rig the vote. "We're just voting, but we know he'll be back again," she said. A smooth election would have surprised Gathoni and would have provided Moi with something he and his floundering country desperately need: a legitimate government. Moi, who took power in 1978 after Kenya's first post-independence president died, returned the country to multi-party rule in 1991. He now has won two multi-party votes this decade -- the first in 1992 -- in which he did not come close to getting 50 percent of the vote. And both contests were tainted by confusion and vote-rigging charges. "Moi will not be able to say yes, I truly won this, or yes, I truly lost it," said George Nyamweya, deputy secretary general of the Democratic Party, whose presidential candidate will finish second behind Moi in this election. "There's a question about his mandate." Two theories prevail as to Moi's post-election strategy. One is that he will toughen up, as he did after the 1992 elections, when he arrested enemies, shackled the independent media and blocked political rallies. The other theory holds that he will assuage foreign governments by attacking corruption and embracing political and economic reforms fully. But analysts fear that Moi's lack of legitimacy will weaken him as he grapples not only with Kenya's bleeding economy but also with social problems such as ethnic tensions. Those tensions are expected to grow fiercer as the economy slides further. Others fear that the mismanaged election has clobbered Kenyans' confidence in the election process. Thousands of voters waited for hours -- sometimes returning a second day -- to cast their ballots. Some Kenyans worry that their fellow citizens' extraordinary patience may be fraying. Kenyans are "hopelessly dissatisfied," said Paul Muite, a founding member of the opposition Safina party, which has accepted the election's results. They are frustrated with a system in which "the economic and social situation is divorced from politics . . . [and] people are interested in political power for its own sake." At some point, "people will get tired of analyses and philosophies," Muite said. "They'll want solutions."

For the first time since Kenyan opposition groups started agitating for constitutional reform earlier this year, thousands of people were allowed to assemble peacefully in a dusty park this afternoon and listen to speeches from their leaders lambasting the authoritarian President of this East African country. The rally was a major victory for the loose coalition of civil rights leaders, opposition politicians and clergy members who have been staging protests since late May to press the Government to open up Kenya's repressive political system. The coalition -- known as the National Convention Assembly -- is seeking to scrap several archaic laws that give President Daniel arap Moi sweeping powers to crush protests, jail dissidents and ban political parties. The members also want to change electoral rules that they maintain make it impossible for a challenger to unseat the incumbent. Mr. Moi, 73, has ruled Kenya as a personal fief since 1978 through his party, the Kenya African National Union. He only begrudgingly endedthe one-party state and instituted multiparty elections in 1992 after a similar round of violent confrontations drew international condemnation and a freeze on foreign aid. The peaceful rally today contrasted starkly with the riots that racked this country in late May and again on July 7, when Government paramilitary police officers crushed protests across the country, killing at least nine people in the worst political violence here since 1991. The Government decided on Friday night to let the rally go ahead without interference, after heavy pressure was brought to bear from at least 22 foreign embassies. The statements from Western diplomats contained an underlying unspoken threat that Kenya's foreign aid might be cut off if Mr. Moi did not allow greater political freedom. Also on Friday, the International Monetary Fund threatened to hold up a $36 million loan disbursement to the country, saying that Mr. Moi's Government had made little progress in stamping out corruption. Though the rally was considered by many to be a moral victory for its organizers, the turnout was modest -- about 3,500 people in a teeming city of 800,000 people known as an opposition stronghold. As the afternoon wore on, the oratory became more and more vitriolic. As they rose one by one to the wooden dais to speak, the opposition politicians appeared to be making stump speeches rather than talking about constitutional issues. The crowd chanted "Moi Must Go!" and "No Reforms, No Elections!" For the most part, the Government maintained its distance today. Only a handful of police officers patrolled near the grounds. A group of about 30 members of the ruling party's youth wing made a half-hearted attempt to disrupt the rally before it began, but they were run off by the opposition leaders' security guards. At the end, the crowd broke up and scattered quietly. Many residents who had watched from the sidelines breathed a sigh of relief.

The president and his cronies are accused far and wide of using the treasury as their personal bank account. Buses don't run. Phones don't work. The jungle is fast overtaking many roads. But the people of Zaire, despite decades of corruption and ineptitude, have found ways to adapt. Education has all but collapsed in parts of the country where teachers are not being paid. To fill the void, parents have started their own schools or, if they can afford it, are paying teachers' salaries themselves. Ambulances are few, so when a disaster happens -- such as the plane crash here in the capital this month that killed as many as 350 people -- private citizens take the injured to the hospital in their own cars. To prevent soldiers from stealing civilians' food, people in one town have taught the soldiers how to harvest crops themselves. Money is so tight that some families have been reduced to feeding their children every other day. Rich in diamonds, copper and other minerals, and vast enough to border nine other nations, Zaire -- with an area the size of the United States east of the Mississippi and a population of 44 million -- has long been considered one of Central Africa's pivotal countries. During the Cold War, the United States and other Western nations eagerly backed the country's anti-communist leader, President Mobutu Sese Seko. But as superpower rivalries have withered and the excesses of Mobutu's 30-year rule have taken their toll, his standing has diminished at home and abroad. As he and his opposition remain stalemated in their protracted five-year transition to democratic elections, government has lost meaning for many Zairians as they attempt each day to secure survival and thereby accept what elsewhere would be unacceptable. That point is driven home routinely when one of the overloaded and unregulated trucks that are used as buses crashes and kills dozens of passengers. Zairians are "pioneering new coping mechanisms," said Ian Brown, head of the Oxfam relief agency, one of several nongovernmental organizations, including churches, whose educational, training and medical services are virtually supplanting the collapsed and paralyzed state. "The leaders are struggling with each other instead of taking care of the real situation of the country," said Sidonie Memba, 37, who grows corn by the side of a road and sells it to passersby. A mother of 10, she said she earns the equivalent of about $ 10 on a good day. "If I do not sell, I won't get anything to eat, so I don't care much about politics because I don't get anything from the fight." Zaire's economic and political squeeze is hard to live with, but nothing can be done about it, said Sophie Kanku, 28, who sells shoes in a large outdoor market. Like several Zairians interviewed at random, Kanku freely expressed her disaffection with the president and his power. "He has got guns," she said. "We have no guns. And he has got money. We are empty-handed." Kanku and Prisca Nta, 22, together expressed the fear that the truck accidents and plane crashes that have taken so many lives recently are a kind of extension of Mobutu's power to wear down the will of people who might oppose him. In response to this sense of powerlessness in the face of a seemingly larger-than-life leader once known as "the Guide," Zairians have mobilized in hundreds of small ways to eke out a living. Children beg in the streets but also shine shoes for cash. Men sell rusted tin cans and rags for reuse. Families or neighbors share food to help each other out. With the degeneration of government, more people are using any pretext for demanding cash, making for a nation on the take: Perhaps the airport workers who demand cash at the baggage X-ray machine have children at home in need of food; or perhaps they are just taking out of greed. That pervasive greed has given Zaire the label of "kleptocracy," a reference to the system of thievery that those with intimate knowledge of Zaire say has characterized the official approach to the public purse for several years. The kleptocracy has rendered this vast, resource-rich nation unable -- and apparently unwilling -- to provide basic services. The telephone system, for example, does not work because "money to be used for maintenance has been stolen," said U.S. Ambassador Daniel Simpson. "Instead of laying the cables, they stole the money." Zairians now rely on cellular phones -- if they can afford them. The same can be said of the national airline, transport corporation and copper mines -- all bankrupted by a combination of mismanagement and corruption. Copper production, which used to account for 70 percent of export earnings, has fallen from about 488,000 tons a year in 1988 to less than a tenth of that today, said Mabi Mulumba, head of the Zairian equivalent of the General Accounting Office. He said his office has documented the "misallocation" of 30 percent of the state budget in 1994. Diamond mining has increased in recent years, but it is largely controlled by foreign interests or syndicates. So out of control was the state treasury in the early 1990s that two-thirds of the currency in circulation was counterfeit, said Prime Minister Kengo wa Dondo, who is lauded by the Clinton administration for reining in the central bank and breaking up Lebanese and Zairian syndicates that flooded Zaire with counterfeit cash. Because of the economic mess, all foreign assistance to Zaire has stopped. U.S. law bars direct aid to a government in arrears on U.S. loans; Zaire owes the United States $ 800 million. The European Union also closed the aid pipeline when Mobutu reneged on his promise to share power with the opposition. Under intense international pressure -- the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund also stopped giving aid -- Mobutu agreed in 1990 to put an end to the one-party state and open the way for multi-party democracy. Since then, transitional governments have changed so often that people here have lost count. The Clinton administration, meanwhile, is looking to Kengo for reform. He was selected as prime minister by the transitional parliament after its original choice, Etienne Tshisekedi, was fired by Mobutu despite a pledge to accept the opposition's choice. Although Kengo is highly unpopular because of a manner that some here describe as dictatorial and because of his ties to Mobutu, for whom he was prime minister twice before, Washington views him as a safe bet on the grounds that he is ineligible for the presidency and thus presumably cannot be corrupted by ambition. By law, the presidency is reserved for people of Zairian parentage. Kengo was born of Polish and Zairian parents. The stern-faced prime minister, however, smiled when asked in an interview if his ambitions are being thwarted by the parentage law. Noting the fluidity of the transition and the recent appointment of an electoral commission, he said: "The electoral law is not yet set." Supporters of Tshisekedi fault Kengo for his ties to Mobutu and for not improving life for Zairians through gains in schools, hospitals and salaries of government employees. "The Westerners who are supporting Kengo are doing their best not to talk about the bad aspects," said Mukenda wa Mulumba, an aide to Tshisekedi. "I'm not blaming the Westerners for what may happen, but they have part of the responsibility for supporting a bad scheme that doesn't lead the country toward success or improvement." Mobutu, meanwhile, remains the Big Man presiding over Zairian politics but spends most of his time at his jungle palace in the equatorial town of Gbadolite, from which he ventures only rarely. He has promised to travel around the nation to campaign in advance of elections that are to take place by July 1997.

Since coming to office nearly two years ago, President Henri Konan Bedie has publicly declared his ambition of turning the Ivory Coast into West Africa's economic powerhouse. He has even suggested a nickname for his country of 14 million: the "Elephant of Africa." Under his guidance, he promises, this beast will soon be pulling the rest of this mostly poor region into the 21st century. Judging by how he organized the vote on Sunday that gave him his first electoral mandate to run the country, however, Ivoirian and foreign political analysts say Mr. Bedie's vision of his country seems to allow little room for democracy. Although Mr. Bedie's supporters say that turnout was high and that the President, who took office when his predecessor died in December 1993, won more than 90 percent of the vote in a contested election, many foreign experts and many Ivoirians came away with an almost opposite conclusion. Even if it is true that the incumbent won, they note, few Ivoirians seemed to bother to vote in what many saw as an empty formality. And if Mr. Bedie managed to score nearly as highly as his predecessor, the country's founding father, Felix Houphouet-Boigny, customarily did in ritualized single-party plebiscites, the victory came only after Government rules eliminated the President's most viable rivals. If the Ivory Coast, with its skyscrapers, glass-smooth highways and relatively prosperous middle class is virtually alone among African countries in its stated objective of following Asia's "economic dragons" into prosperity, Mr. Bedie is far from alone among African leaders in seeking to hold on to power by manipulating election rules. All across a continent that was swept dramatically by the winds of multiparty politics at the turn of the decade, incumbents have been rewriting the rules of the game, bullying opponents and restricting the press in order to hold on to power regardless of their popularity or the success of their programs. In Zambia, as the country's second democratic elections approach, President Frederick J. T. Chiluba has begun to arrest critics, including a journalist, Fred Mbembe, who was recently sentenced to 100 years in prison for his coverage of Government corruption. Mr. Chiluba's aides also recently sought the arrest or expulsion of his electoral rival, the former President Kenneth D. Kaunda, on charges that he was not Zambian. This, despite the fact that Mr. Kaunda led Zambia's independence struggle from Britain and served as President for nearly three decades. In Kenya, supporters of the longtime leader, President Daniel arap Moi, who was pressed earlier in the decade by international creditors to accept a more open multiparty system, have taken to assaulting rivals, notably Richard Leakey, the paleontologist, who began organizing an opposition party earlier this year. When the military in Nigeria, Africa's most populous country, decided it could not stomach the result of democratic elections two years ago, it canceled the results. The widely assumed winner, Moshood K. O. Abiola, was imprisoned on treason charges after he insisted that his mandate be respected. Here in the Ivory Coast, Mr. Bedie has called his own brand of politics "democratie apaisee." The President's aides might translate the slogan as "peaceful democracy." But for the Government's critics, the President's use of security forces to round up dissidents, his tight control of electronic media, the arrest of journalists and his rewriting of electoral laws suggest something more akin to "pacified democracy." Taking a page from Mr. Chiluba in Zambia, Mr. Bedie's supporters wrote a new electoral code that insisted that any candidate have purely Ivoirian parents. The widely understood intent was to block the candidacy of the man who was Prime Minister at Mr. Houphouet-Boigny's death in 1993, Alassane D. Ouattara. Mr. Ouattara, who Mr. Bedie insists is of foreign extraction, is deputy director of the International Monetary Fund in Washington and was widely seen here as the politician with the best chance of unseating the President in a fair election. "President Bedie has tolerated irregularities that do not honor our country," said Diegou Bailly, editor of Le Jour, an independent newspaper. "Politics are intimately linked to economics, and the 'African elephant' that the Ivory Coast seeks to build must first be built on the basis of confidence, right here at home." If early in this decade many African countries briefly felt pressure from the West to apply widely recognized standards of democracy, African human rights advocates and Government opponents say that more recently, the West has quietly dropped these standards. Experts from the National Democratic Institute for International Affairs, a nongovernmental group in Washington, canceled its election observer mission to the Ivory Coast after the Government's refusal to accept proposals by local church and human rights groups on a legal framework to restore confidence in the elections. The United States Embassy here has declined to comment on the elections. Many Africans say that nowhere has the shrinking Western commitment to democracy in the continent been greater than in France, however. African intellectuals liken Paris's political attachment to its former colonies here, no matter how corrupt or undemocratic, to Washington's support for Central American dictatorships during the cold war. The only difference, they say, is that where Washington saw a Communist under every bed, France imagines foreign plotting to usurp its role in a region it has long dominated. In the Ivory Coast, the cornerstone of France's former holdings in West Africa, on a day when security forces shot dead two demonstrators during the campaign earlier this month, the French Minister for Cooperation, Jacques Godfrain, gave a speech in which he said of Mr. Bedie, "France will be by your side, Mr. President, for the long period that lies ahead of you." Abou Dramane Sangare, a leader of the Ivoirian Popular Front, one of two main opposition groups that boycotted the elections, said, "France does not play the game of democracy in Africa." "De Gaulle said France has no friends, only interests," he added.  "Now we have Chirac, who believes that democracy is a luxury that Africa cannot afford."  TYPE: News Analysis

In the tally of scandals surrounding President Frederick Chiluba, let's start with the one about drugs: International donors on which Zambia is dependent forced Chiluba to cut loose a trio of top officials believed to be involved in illicit drug trade. The collapse of Zambian Airways did not help Chiluba much either, as thousands of workers lost their jobs. Soon thereafter, confidence in the economy took another blow: Depositors lost millions when the nation's fourth-largest bank went under despite the government's attempt at a bailout. Then came sex: Lusaka's crusading newspaper, the Post, alleged Chiluba had had an extramarital affair and a child whom he refused to support. And on top of it all came a bizarre twist; the Post reported: Chiluba may not be Chiluba at all and not even a full-fledged Zambian, but a man who took the identity of another and turned his back on his own foreign father. All this intrigue, plus deepening economic hardship as the country undergoes an internationally imposed structural adjustment, has eroded Chiluba's credibility so much that what once seemed unthinkable is happening. The labor leader who swept into office four years ago on a reformist wave that ended 27 years of autocratic rule under Kenneth Kaunda and buoyed hopes for democracy's spread on the continent now faces perhaps his stiffest opposition from none other than the Big Man himself. Kaunda, known here as K.K., wants his country back. Kaunda, 71, who used to publicly weep for Africa and style himself a benevolent patron to the people he helped liberate from British colonialism in what was then called Northern Rhodesia, represents the first generation of post-independence African leaders. He clung to power, developed a cult of personality, squashed opposition and imposed tight state control of the economy -- to the benefit of Zambians for a while, until fiscal strangulation ensued. Although he seemed a discredited has-been when Zambians rioted over skyrocketing food prices, ransacked his home, then booted him from office in 1991, Kaunda this summer regained the leadership of his party and has garnered the support of several important leaders within the Bemba tribe, which represents 35 percent of Zambia's nearly 9 million people. While some observers feel it unlikely that Zambians will choose to return to Kaunda and the failed socialist policies he represents, others say that the despair of the masses, especially in rural areas suffering under the dual burdens of state mismanagement of agriculture and a debilitating drought, gives Kaunda a solid shot at taking back his country in elections to be held next year. Zambians are widely disaffected by unfulfilled political promises and struggling under crushing economic hardship, which means democracy here is far less a priority than food and jobs. Four years ago, Chiluba emerged as the only leader who could oust Kaunda, and he did so with nearly 80 percent of the vote. "The issue is just as it was in 1991," said Lucy Sichone, founder of the Zambian Civic Education Association and a former member of Kaunda's party. "The only person who can get rid of Chiluba is K.K." "We haven't built up democratic institutions," said Sichone. "That's why I'm afraid that K.K. cannot be dismissed." Kaunda has yet to outline what economic policies he would pursue, but he is getting much mileage out of Chiluba's credibility problems, saying in a recent interview that Chiluba's Movement for Multiparty Democracy "is a cartel for organized crime" and that the Chiluba government contains two dozen officials whom Kaunda detained for trafficking in Mandraax, a sedative for which Zambia has become a primary transit point en route to South Africa. But Chiluba, 50, is striking back with some heavy artillery of his own. His government this month revealed what it called underground torture chambers constructed beneath State House, the presidential residence, during Kaunda's reign, when political opponents were routinely imprisoned. The government repeatedly has denied Kaunda permits to hold rallies and has arrested him for defying the ban. Chiluba's party also has floated a constitutional proposal that would place the presidency off-limits to candidates of non-Zambian parentage. Kaunda's parents were born in Malawi. As for his own parentage, Chiluba denies the newspaper report questioning his identity, as he denies all the other scandals that have tainted his presidency. What cannot be denied is the economic hardship that has fallen on most Zambians. Chiluba inherited an economic mess from Kaunda at a time when the World Bank and International Monetary Fund, which had been unable to persuade Kaunda to comply with earlier structural adjustments, imposed one of the strictest adjustment programs on the globe. "This country has undergone economic surgery without anaesthetic," said Gedion Nkojo, the World Bank chief here. Under Kaunda, Zambia fit the classic mold of the command economy. Through companies it controls, the state ran virtually everything, from the cultivation of maize to the baking of bread to the mining of copper. Payrolls were heavily padded, with employees receiving housing, cars and free airfare on the national airline. Even food was subsidized. But Zambia's population skyrocketed, from about 3.5 million in 1964, when Kaunda came to power, to nearly 9 million today, and the price of copper, which accounted for 90 percent of Zambia's foreign exchange earnings and as much as 50 percent of government revenues, plunged. Kaunda began to borrow heavily from international donors, sinking Zambia into a black hole of debt. Under World Bank guidance, Chiluba largely has succeeded in meeting the program's goals by lowering inflation and interest rates and stabilizing the once wildly fluctuating local currency, the kwacha, said Nkojo. He also has ended state subsidies in education and health and slowly is selling off the state-controlled companies. Such reforms have laid the groundwork for more private investment in the country and the ultimate improvement in socioeconomic conditions. But within Chiluba's own circle there are those who complain of the continued influence of state spending and patronage. For example, said Mundia Sikatana, a Chiluba adviser and a founder of the Movement for Multiparty Democracy, the government continues to provide vehicles to hundreds of civil servants, including the fuel to run them. The government, he said, "cannot abandon the old habits. The [structural adjustment program] is not doing enough." Try telling that to ordinary Zambians, for whom the end of price controls has meant a 40-fold increase in the price of maize over the past few years. Seventy percent of all Zambians live in poverty. Infant mortality is up, and adult life expectancy is down -- defying the trend in most of the rest of the world. The despair of ordinary Zambians will likely translate into widespread apathy, predicted Sichone. Or it could leave some voters longing for what seemed the good old days of Kaunda. The choice facing Zambians, said a former Zambian diplomat, may lead to the same end. If the economy continues to decline in the face of structural adjustments, eventually mass uprisings will occur. And if Kaunda wins and returns to the policies of the past, and international lenders pull out and stop propping up the economy, the same anger may explode. "We do have a serious political crisis," the diplomat said. "People are starving. It is tough. And frankly, I don't know how much longer it can go on."

Count the white faces in the boardrooms of the sleek skyscrapers, on the verandas of the gracious sports clubs and around the tables of the chic restaurants. Then submit to a pop history quiz: Who won the liberation war, anyway? Blacks did. But 15 years after Rhodesia became Zimbabwe and the second-to-last bastion of white-minority rule in sub-Saharan Africa vanished, it's easy to be confused. Whites, who make up less than 1 percent of Zimbabwe's population, own an estimated 97 percent of the private wealth here. By many standards, they are living better than ever. Meanwhile, the black masses disproportionately bear the burden of a rising unemployment rate, now at 25 percent, steep inflation, punishing droughts and deep cuts in social spending. The tenacity of white economic domination in the teeth of black political empowerment offers what some here regard as a cautionary tale for Zimbabwe's neighbor to the south. "If our pattern holds in South Africa 15 years from now, there's going to be trouble -- and I doubt it will wait 15 years to break out," said John Makumbe, a professor of political science at the University of Zimbabwe. "They have a much more entrenched culture of protest than we do. Our political culture is docile." Certainly Zimbabwe's politics proved docile last week. Voters went to the polls yesterday and today for their fourth parliamentary election since independence in 1980. Despite the mounting economic woes of the masses, President Robert Mugabe's ruling party, the Zimbabwe African National Union-Patriotic Front, is predicted to win all but a handful of the 150 seats against weak and divided opposition. The party currently holds 147. The only mystery of this election is the turnout. Critics such as Makumbe and a host of human rights groups accuse Mugabe's party of rigging electoral laws, intimidating political opponents, stifling free debate and allowing corrupt government ministers to plunder the treasury and forge cozy alliances with white business. Despite news media that are largely government controlled, these accusations have circulated widely among Zimbabwe's well-educated population of 11 million. Yet they have triggered only episodic racial tension and no discernible political reform movement. Indeed, many black Zimbabweans count their blessings. Politics are stable, racial tensions are low, and ethnic violence has been nonexistent since a post-independence tribal war led to a coalition government incorporating the Shona and Ndebele tribes. On the economic front, the International Monetary Fund and World Bank have prevailed upon the government to adopt an economic structural adjustment program. Its initials, ESAP, and its effects, have spawned the rueful nickname Ever-Suffering African People. Despite the short-term pain, however, it gives the economy a chance to climb out of an investment-stifling debt trap. "Zimbabweans take the long view -- the work we have to do in terms of black economic empowerment, we have forever," said Strive Masiyiwa, a black businessmen who runs an electrical engineering company. "We know what war has done elsewhere in Africa. As long as we have peace and stability, we know our sons will bear the economic fruits of our political liberation." Not all blacks are as patient. "There is going to be a lot of noise, consumer boycotts and street protest after the election," predicted Phillip Chiyangwa, president of the Affirmation Active Group, which has been pressing the government to change the rules of the economic game here to favor black businesses. That process is known in Zimbabwe as the "indigenization" of the private sector. Since 1990 -- after Mugabe's government began to deemphasize socialist ideology -- the concept has received a great deal of official lip service. So far, black businessmen say it's all talk. They say they are as hobbled as ever by 35 percent interest rates and by banks that march to the tune of the multinational corporations that own them. Laws designed to funnel government contracts to black companies are a sham, said Masiyiwa. And the hope that privatization of state-owned utilities would produce black owners has proven illusory. The most contentious issue is rural land ownership. About 4,000 white farmers own roughly 30 percent of Zimbabwe's best farmland; on it, they produce virtually all of Zimbabwe's commercial crops. Seven million blacks live on farmland hardest hit by drought and have trouble eking out a subsistence. Land was the driving issue behind the guerrilla war that toppled Ian Smith's white-minority government in 1980. Blacks forced to relocate during a century of white settlement yearned to till the same soil their forefathers did. The Mugabe government's first wave of postwar land redistribution was a bust. In 1992 the government passed a law allowing it to appropriate -- with compensation -- the land of commercial farmers for resettlement purposes, triggering great fears in the white community. But so far, said Peter MacSporran, president of the Commercial Farmers' Union, not a single commercial farmer has been forced to sell his land against his will. "After an initial period of confrontation, we're working well with the government to identify suitable land for resettlement," he said. Despite the drought, commercial farmers have reasons to breathe easily these days. The economic liberalization of IMF structural adjustment has meant fewer hassles with government marketing boards, more access to customers abroad and a wider range of imported equipment to purchase. "Five years ago, if you wanted a tractor here, you were looking at a three-year wait," said MacSporran. "Now, you go to the dealer and he asks, 'What color do you want?' " The dozen-plus skyscrapers built in Harare in the last five years, which give this capital city the most impressive skyline in sub-Saharan Africa, stand as a vote of confidence by the multinationals in the long-term future of the economy. The vast majority of the white-collar workers in these office towers are blacks who took advantage of the Mugabe government's investment in black education to become clerks, accountants, salesmen, middle-level managers. But there aren't nearly enough jobs. With the official unemployment rate running at 25 percent -- unofficial estimates say it is closer to 40 percent -- Zimbabwe has the dubious distinction of housing the best-educated unemployed work force in Africa. Young blacks appear to be getting discouraged. With no jobs available for high school graduates, and with the government having to impose new school fees to satisfy IMF demands to end budgetary deficits, the school dropout rate has doubled in a decade. All of this seems to be a recipe for unrest. And for a brief stretch late last year and early this year, as the country headed toward this election, there was a sharp rise in anti-white protests. A handful of militant black college students vandalized some downtown clubs and restaurants that whites frequent. The government newspaper carried angry anti-white letters to the editor and anonymous ads that called for the expulsion within a decade of all of Zimbabwe's 80,000 whites -- down from a peak of 270,000 before independence. But as suddenly as the campaign began, it ended. In mid-January, after passions had come to a boil with the conviction of a white doctor for using his black patients as guinea pigs in medical experiments, the government-controlled Herald newspaper announced it would no longer accept letters that inflamed racial passions. A big anti-white rally fizzled. The widespread assumption, said Makumbe, is that Mugabe's government played the anti-white card to divert attention from its own failings. Then when international lending institutions and multinational corporations put out the word that enough was enough, the campaign folded. That explanation may be a bit simplistic. But there's no denying that, 15 years after liberation, Zimbabwe is run by a sometimes stormy marriage of a white economic and black political elite. Even without black ownership of the private sector, there's a big enough patronage base in the civil service and parastatal companies, which together account for about 35 percent of the economy, for the Mugabe government to keep a firm grip on power. Ministers get rich, political opponents get weary, the masses get poorer. The country is stable. Might the same arrangement evolve in South Africa? Comparisons are risky. There are 80,000 whites here; 5 million there. South Africa's economy is 15 times bigger than Zimbabwe's. Race relations have always had a harder edge in South Africa. The black masses there are more urbanized and politicized, and there is a much quicker trigger for violence. But there's one compelling similarity. These are two countries where a small minority of whites own the economy and a large majority of blacks own the politics. It is an inherently unstable arrangement, and so far there's only been one model for achieving stability. It's the Zimbabwean model.

The once elegant, European-style boulevards of this capital are overrun with debris. Largely abandoned government buildings are obscured behind elephant grass and overgrown trees. In a perverse reversal of the usual development maxim, an opulent colonial capital is being overtaken by the bush. Kinshasa was carved out of the jungle. Now the jungle is coming to claim the land back. As sub-Saharan Africa struggles to find stability in the 1990s, Zaire offers a poignant -- and ominous -- lesson. Unlike Somalia and Liberia, this big, rich country has not collapsed into civil war. It has not, like tiny Rwanda, imploded after a brutal campaign of tribal slaughter. But Zaire, the region's second-largest country and one of its potentially wealthiest, is equally desperate: It has crumbled from official corruption and greed, incompetence, neglect and decay. The institutions that once defined the Zairian state have all ceased to function. Civil servants and teachers are not paid, roads and bridges are left in disrepair, public hospitals are not supplied, the public telephone system has disintegrated. Child malnutrition is on the rise, and the country is ravaged by AIDS and a rebirth of sleeping sickness that has caused entire villages simply to lie down and die. "Precolonial" is how one Western resident described Zaire. "It's like Europe in the Dark Ages," said another Westerner, a diplomat with long experience here. "Zaire just proves that societies don't depend on the existence of a state. Societies can function on their own." While the causes of Zaire's crisis may be distinct -- and the extent of its free fall extreme -- this country in many ways stands as a microcosm of what many Africans and others say is a continent-wide phenomenon. Since the United States and the Soviet Union ended a rivalry that shaped the politics of sub-Saharan Africa through much of the last 30 years, the region has struggled to find a new basis for stability and development free of foreign tutelage. Some progress has been made. But governments, economies and even whole countries artificially forged by European colonizers in the 19th century, and propped up since achieving independence a generation ago by the patronage of outside powers, are beginning to fragment. Like most countries of the developing world, and in the former communist bloc of Eastern Europe, African states have tried to adopt the non-communist world's formula for success. Most have pledged to open their economies and adopt free-market policies, and many have begun talking about giving up autocracy or one-party rule for democracy and pluralism. A few -- most famously South Africa -- have succeeded. Yet as much of the rest of the Third World appears poised to enter a new era of rapid economic growth and stability, Africa is still struggling to shake off the burdens of the past, ranging from the borders drawn by the European powers to the corruption and economic mismanagement engendered by post-colonial dictators backed by Moscow, Washington, Paris or Beijing. In many places, the old order is crumbling but nothing is taking its place. "There's too much talk about development and not enough about decay," said Peter Lyon at London's Institute for Commonwealth Studies. Zaire, he said, "may be the classic case."  Obstacles Old and New For two years, Zaire for all practical purposes has had no working government. Its longtime president, Mobutu Sese Seko, has been abandoned by the United States, his backer during the Cold War, and no longer can impose order on his sprawling country. But his political opponents have been too weak to remove him. There are two competing prime ministers, neither of whose authority is accepted by the army or the bureaucracy. Soldiers have destroyed much of the infrastructure of the capital in riots over pay, and whole regions populated by distinct ethnic groups have simply taken over their own affairs. For some Africans, the crisis reflects fundamental problems of statehood that have lingered in African countries since they gained independence in the 1960s. "It raises profound questions about the nature of these governments and the nature of these states," said Rakiya Omaar, a Somali who is co-director of African Rights, a London-based human rights group. "The problem in Africa has been these predatory, strong central governments that never cared about their own people." Similar political breakdowns are happening around the region. Somalia has not had a government since its U.S.-backed dictator, Mohamed Siad Barre, was chased out of power in January 1991. Liberia is still in the throes of an on-again, off-again civil war over who, and what, should replace the late Samuel Doe's dictatorship. Angola and Sudan both seem hopelessly locked in civil wars that have effectively divided those countries along geographic lines. And Rwanda, Zaire's neighbor, has been in a state of anarchy and civil war since April 6, with no effective government in place, since President Juvenal Habyarimana was killed in an unexplained plane crash. Other countries, from Sierra Leone to Uganda, from Ethiopia to Mali, are waging small-scale wars against guerrillas, ethnic separatists or armed bandits that have made large chunks of territory impassable and lawless. One key cause of this turmoil is Africa's loss of what was arguably its most important resource: its relevance. During the Cold War, the continent was a playground for the proxy conflicts. The Americans, the Soviets, the Chinese, the Israelis, the Arabs, white South Africans, white Rhodesians, even the Taiwanese searched for allies and brought in aid, arms and advice. Much of the attention lavished on Africa proved destructive -- fueling civil wars, as in Angola, or backing dictators, as in Somalia, Liberia and Zaire. But the outside attention also meant that highways were built, hospitals were kept supplied and a generation of Africa's elite were given access to education at home and abroad. African autocrats were able to play East against West, Arabs against Israelis, Chinese against Taiwanese in a bid for foreign largesse. The game was always to find who would give the most aid, and some despots played it deftly. With the end of the East-West conflict, the dismantling of South Africa's racist policies of apartheid and the move toward peace in the Middle East, Africa has become more marginalized than at any time since Europeans first set foot here 500 years ago. Zaire tells the story: After years in which the United States, France and Belgium lavished aid on Mobutu, almost all foreign assistance has been cut since 1990, and most expatriate workers have departed. In June, Zaire was expelled from the International Monetary Fund. The lack of foreign interest and investment, combined with the difficulty of implementing new economic and political models, means that even outside war zones, Africans are struggling to come to terms with longstanding social and economic ailments: # According to the World Bank, the four poorest countries in the world, in terms of gross national product, are in Africa; seven of the world's 10 poorest countries are in Africa. From 1980 until 1991, African economies actually shrank an average of 1.2 percent each year, meaning Africans have gotten poorer over the last decade. # African countries have the world's highest illiteracy rates, and they put the least public money per pupil into their education systems. # Agricultural production has declined in most African countries over the last two decades, leaving Africa less able to feed itself and more dependent on foreign food aid. The World Bank estimates it will take 40 years for some African countries just to climb back to their pre-independence level. # Africa is ravaged by disease. AIDS has become the most common cause of death for Africans, and in a dozen African cities, 20 to 30 percent of the adult population is infected with the virus that causes AIDS. More than 10 million of the world's 15 million people infected with the AIDS virus are in Africa. Not all African countries are in a downward spiral. While Angola is in the grip of full-scale civil war, Malawi recently conducted a peaceful election that ousted an entrenched autocrat. The death of the president of Rwanda sparked an explosion of tribal massacres, but the death of the president of Ivory Coast caused barely a political ripple. There are many economic problem areas, but some countries, like Ghana, are on the mend. Still, it is the absence of outright conflict in most African countries that makes their social and economic decline so remarkable. In state after state, public institutions have collapsed, health care has diminished, infrastructure has fallen into disrepair and poverty has deepened -- not because of civil war, but simply because poorly supported, inefficient and sometimes corrupt governments have been unable to manage their countries' daunting problems. In other words, the pattern in Zaire may not be the exception but the rule. "In Somalia and Liberia, it was violent," said a European diplomat in Zaire. "Here, it's a slow implosion. But the result is the same. Here, it's just crumbled." The Road to Anarchy Although its descent into near-anarchy was touched off by the end of the Cold War, Zaire's deterioration as a state began shortly after the country gained independence from Belgium in June 1960. An early secessionist movement in the region of Katanga, which provoked U.N. troops to intervene, underscored the fragility -- and artificiality -- of the new nation of 200 separate tribes. Still, in the late 1950s and early 1960s, Zaire -- then known as the Congo -- provided Western countries with 69 percent of their industrial diamonds, 49 percent of their cobalt, and other strategic minerals, making it "a very important piece of real estate," according to American University's Sanford J. Ungar in his book, "Africa." From that commanding position as a wealthy and strategically important Western supplier, the country entered a long era of Western-backed autocratic rule -- and slow decline.
